DOC.HEAD: Suspect Says He Knows Who Killed Two College Students, Paper Reports
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 23 grafs to UPDATE with newspaper report that suspect had knowledge of first two killings and gave identity of one of his multiple personalities; defense lawyer's quotes, other details; minor editing. Picks up 16th graf pvs: `Dr. Michael . . .'
DOC.TEXT: A suspect in the killing of five college students said he knew who killed two victims and gave a name police believe is one of his multiple personalities, a newspaper reported Friday. Edward Lewis Humphrey, 18, has been held in the Brevard County Jail on charges of assaulting his grandmother but has not been charged in any of the Gainesville killings. The Florida Times-Union in Jacksonville, citing unidentified sources, said in its early Saturday editions that, after he was arrested Aug. 30, he talked to officers about the killings of the first two victims _ Christina Powell, 17, and Sonja Larson, 18. They were found Aug. 26 in their Gainesville apartment. He said he knew who killed the two and blamed one of the personalities he has appeared to exhibit, the Times-Union reported. The newspaper did not print the name, but during a bond hearing Thursday, a jail guard had testified that Humphrey referred to himself as ``John.'' Humphrey's lawyer, public defender J. R. Russo, told The Associated Press he was unaware of any such statements by his client. ``It's news to me,'' he said. He added that he had been concerned all along about Humphrey's initial interrogation, which took place with no lawyer present. So far, authorities have refused to discuss publicly what Humphrey said in any statement. Meanwhile, police said Friday that they have gathered ``promising'' evidence, but cautioned that they don't expect any immediate results. Police would provide no details about what information was gathered in searches of Humphrey's Gainesville apartment, his car and his grandmother's home in Indialantic, a coastal city about 180 miles southeast of Gainesville. ``We did not leave empty-handed,'' Lt. Sadie Darnell said, but added that lab tests will take time to tell if they have anything useful as evidence. Besides the searches of the homes and car, agents obtained a personal search warrant for Humphrey that could yield evidence on bodily fluids, fingerprints and hair. Agents spent Thursday searching Humphrey's apartment and the 13-room, two-story house in Indialantic. Humphrey's car was loaded onto a flatbed car carrier and taken to a state crime lab in Jacksonville where it was to be searched. ``Evidence gathered at both scenes and in Brevard County is promising,'' Ms. Darnell said. Despite the intense interest in Humphrey, police continue to say he is one of eight suspects and no arrests are imminent. Police canceled weekend news briefings, saying no significant developments are expected. ``We are not going to identify anyone as a No. 1 suspect,'' Ms. Darnell said, adding police had received 3,670 leads so far. New charges of aggravated assault have been filed against Humphrey as a result of a confrontation the night before the first two bodies were discovered. Greg Herskowitz and Rob Lipvak, two 18-year-old Pi Lambda Phi pledges, claim Humphrey threatened them with a knife at the fraternity house Aug. 25. Humphrey is being held on $1 million bond in an attack on his 79-year-old grandmother. He also faces charges in Indian River County of armed burglary and attempted sexual battery two years ago. Police disclosed for the first time Friday that Manuel Taboada, the only man killed by the serial slayer, was asleep in bed when he was slain. ``He was apparently surprised by his attacker,'' Ms. Darnell said. Besides Larson and Powell, the other victims were Christa Hoyt, 19, and Taboada's roommate Tracy Paules, 23. Dr. Michael West, who spent 1{ days studying the three murder scenes, said he believes the killer was wearing gloves because he left virtually no trace of himself. ``I thought I'd seen everything,'' he said in a taping of the ``Donahue'' show that was broadcast live in Gainesville Friday. ``When the full story is released, you'll be shocked and amazed.'' The show was almost knocked off the air when a man riding a bicycle stopped and cut cables to five of six cameras, police said. The man was not caught.

DOC.HEAD: Rooftop Sniper Kills Self After Holding Police at Bay
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 2nd graf, `Paul A. . . .' to UPDATE with victim's age and hometown.
DOC.TEXT: A gunman who held police at bay for 5{ hours Friday ended the standoff by shooting himself in the head and falling from atop a 16-story building in one of the city's busiest neighborhoods, authorities said. Paul A. Fisher, 30, of Pittsburgh was propelled forward off an apartment building's roof by a single shot from a handgun about 5:10 p.m., said Police Chief Mayer DeRoy. He was pronounced dead at the scene. No one on the ground was injured. ``He said he was going to jump since we wouldn't assassinate him,'' DeRoy said. Fisher, who had a history of mental illness and problems at home, apparently was trying to draw attention to himself on the apartment building's roof, DeRoy said. He wore a bright orange hat and blue short-sleeved shirt, and had 50 rounds of ammunition in a duffel bag, DeRoy said. About noon, Fisher fired one shot from a .22-caliber rifle at an unmarked police car and 11 other rifle shots into the air, police said. Two Roman Catholic schools were evacuated, and a four- to five-block area was blocked off to traffic. Police believed they were making progress 15 minutes before Fisher killed himself because he turned over the rifle to police negotiators. Fisher climbed a drainpipe to get to the roof's tallest parapet and smoked a cigarette on a ledge, DeRoy said. ``He then put the gun to his head and pulled the trigger,'' the chief said. ``I told him we weren't interested in prosecuting him criminally. We were only interested in getting him help.'' Fisher killed himself before hundreds of onlookers and several TV crews. Local Pittsburgh newscasts did not air the videotape, while national CNN Headline News did. He told police he was up on the roof half an hour with weapons and no one was paying attention to him, so he fired at the unmarked police car with the .22-caliber rifle. DeRoy said the man threw scrap paper over the side of the building to see how long it took to fall to the ground. Fisher fired the first shot at an unmarked police car shortly before noon, said Assistant Police Chief Donald Aubrecht. Over the next several hours, he fired several other rounds into the air and occasionally pointed the rifle at the ground without shooting. Police sharpshooters took up positions on rooftops near the 16-story Moorehead Towers, said public safety spokeswoman Margaret Philbin. The building houses the elderly and handicapped in the city's Oakland section. Four police officers tried to talk with the sniper from a stairway on the outside of the building, Ms. Philbin said. ``All he wants is a Coke and cigarettes. They threw him a bunch,'' she said. More than 50 police officers were at the scene and cordoned off an area of about four or five blocks around the building, snarling traffic in the heavily populated area near the University of Pittsburgh. Students at two Roman Catholic schools near the apartments were led out the schools' back doors to safety and continued classes at another school, also in Oakland.

DOC.HEAD: Swiss Financier Outlines Iran-Contra Profits
DOC.TEXT: A former CIA agent earned at least $843,000 for supplying weapons during the Iran-Contra affair, according to prosecution evidence presented Friday. The government is trying to prove that Thomas G. Clines, 62, of Middleburg, Va., failed to report all of his Iran-Contra earnings on his tax returns. Clines also is charged with failing to report his overseas financial accounts to the Internal Revenue Service. Clines reported gross earnings of $265,000 for the tax year 1985 and $402,513 for 1986, according to a four-count indictment returned here in February. According to documents presented in court, Clines received $423,534 for helping procure arms for the Contra rebels in 1985. He earned $420,238 in 1986, according to testimony. When the trial in U.S. District Court resumes Monday, the government will call witnesses expected to testify about additional profits Clines and the other Iran-Contra figures earned. During six hours of testimony, Swiss financier Willard I. Zucker identified dozens of financial documents and memos outlining how the arms deal profits were split among retired Maj. Gen. Richard Secord, Iranian-born businessman Albert Hakim and Clines. Zucker, who works at a Geneva-based financial services company that handled money for the arms deals, testified that Hakim and Secord asked the firm to alter some records. ``Cash would come into the accounts. It was never explained to us what that cash was used for or where it was from,'' Zucker said. ``When cash was going out, no one explained to us why we were making that payment. We didn't receive invoices. ``We were told by our clients that this was a White House covert operation. We were not encouraged to ask questions. We were supposed to keep track of the money. We did the best we could,'' he said. Zucker testified that Hakim asked the company to revise account statements, but he did not know when the changes were made or what they included. He said financial documents presented at Clines' trial were not among those altered. The Iran-Contra affair was disclosed to the public in November 1986. Congressional investigators used Hakim's financial records to trace the paper trail of the scheme, during profits from arms sales to Iran were diverted to rebels trying to overthrow the Nicaraguan government, despite a congressional ban on such funding. Secord testified Wednesday that he believed some of the ledgers recording the Iran-Contra arms transactions were falsified but said he had never seen a forged document related to Clines' profits. Secord and Hakim each earned $1.39 million during 1985 and 1986, the documents showed. In addition, $141,084 in profits was received by Scitech, a company jointly owned by Hakim and Secord, according to the documents presented in court. Secord pleaded guilty last year to a felony count of making false statements to the Iran-Contra congressional committees. He was sentenced in January to two years' probation. Clines faces up to 16 years in prison and fines of up to $1 million if convicted.

DOC.HEAD: Air Force Conventional Weapons Smarter, Deadlier Since Vietnam
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Saturday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: If hostilities erupt in the Middle East, the Air Force will be armed with ``smart'' and deadly high-tech weapons developed as a result of hard lessons learned the last time America went to war. ``The Southeast Asia conflict changed armament development forever,'' said Julie Massoni, historian for the Air Force Development Test Center at Eglin Air Force Base in the Florida Panhandle. The Air Force gave low priority to conventional bombs, missiles and guns before the Vietnam War, focusing on aircraft development and nuclear arms, Massoni said. As a result, high-performance jets were saddled with outdated munitions, some dating to World War II, that limited their capabilities in Vietnam. In the late 1960s, U.S. jets armed with iron bombs flew more than 800 sorties against the Than Hoa Bridge, losing at least 10 aircraft and failing to bring down the span. In 1972, four F-4 Phantom II jets took only 15 minutes to destroy the bridge with the first ``smart bombs.'' The laser-guided Paveway I glide bombs were used with similar success against a second bridge. ``The precision guided munitions that took out the bridges have been termed by some as the most revolutionary change in the art of warfare since the nuclear bomb,'' Massoni said. Eglin's Development Test Center, established in 1968, has been responsible for many of those weapons and has even more formidable bombs and missiles in the final stages of development. ``In general these weapons tend to work extemely well if no countermeasures are taken,'' said Steve Kosiak, a senior analyst with the Center for Defense Information, a private think tank in Washington, D.C. The problem, he said, is most have not yet been tried in battle against opposing military forces that can use electronic trickery to fool radar-guided weapons, or smoke to mask targets from television- and laser-guided bombs and missiles. One exception has been the successful use of laser-guided bombs in the U.S. raid on Libya. Kosiak said the high cost of ``smart'' weapons limits their use to high-value targets. Old-fashioned iron bombs may still be the weapon of choice against such targets as factories and massed armies, he said. However, merely having a high-tech weapon, even if it doesn't work all the time, may inhibit an enemy, Kosiak said. Opposing forces may not turn on anti-aircraft radar to avoid having it destroyed by a radar-seeking missile. The Air Force arsenal of ``smart'' weapons now includes the Paveway III, an advanced laser-guided bomb, and the GBU-15, an even more accurate television-guided glide bomb. In tests, a GBU-15 hit a billboard-type target measuring 40 feet by 40 feet after being dropped five miles away. Eglin has completed development of a rocket-powered version, the AGM-130 missile, that can be launched from at least 15 miles. No decision has yet been made on production because of the cost, according to Maj. Wayne Warren of Owensboro, Ky., lead engineer for the project. The Air Force already has a television-guided, infrared missile, the Maverick, introduced in 1972, but it is a relative lightweight at 426 pounds. The AGM-130, like the GBU-15, actually is a kit for converting existing 2,000-pound bombs, of which there are thousands. A TV guidance pod bolted to the nose makes a bomb ``smart'' and adding the rocket motor to the tail turns it into a missile, Warren said. Another weapon developed during the Vietnam War is the Shrike missile that homes in on enemy radar used to guide anti-aircraft missiles. An advanced version known as the HARM, or High Speed Anti-Radiation Missile, was deployed in 1983. For air-to-air combat, U.S. fighters are armed with the intermediate range, radar-guided Sparrow and the short-range, heat-seeking Sidewinder missiles. The Sidewinder was deployed in 1953 and the Sparrow 10 years later, but each has undergone numerous modifications to improve performance. The new Advanced Intermediate Range Air-to-Air Missile, or AMRAAM, will give pilots ``launch and leave'' capability because it has its own tiny but powerful radar for guidance. It also allows pilots to fire at more than one target at the same time. About 175 AMRAAMs have been built, but a reliability problem has delayed full-scale production, said Brig. Gen. Charles Franklin, AMRAAM project director. Improvements in the manufacturing process are curing the problem and the first operational versions are expected to be delivered later this year, he said.

DOC.HEAD: A Month In Arabia: Boredom, Loneliness Challenge Morale
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Saturday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: The paratrooper recalls stepping off the plane a month ago, among the first American soldiers to reach Saudi Arabia. ``Instant sweat. It had me wishing we were back in Panama,'' the 24-year-old North Carolinian said, asking that his name not be used. ``But we were pumped, ready for instant war ... Our feeling then was that war was inevitable,'' he said, interviewed at the camp first named All-American City and then changed to Champion City because of Saudi objections. Now, uncertainty has replaced inevitability. With no enemy to fight, the desert heat and deepening boredom are the most common foes. ``We'd like to know how long we're going to stay,'' said Marine Maj. Drew Bennett of New Orleans. ``We don't know anything.'' Morale remains generally high among U.S. troops, but keeping it high as Operation Desert Shield drags on could be a daunting challenge, exacerbated by Saudi customs that prohibit alcohol and discourage women from venturing into Saudi communities. ``They need to tell me when I'm going home,'' Air Force Staff Sgt. Kenneth Williams said. ``I've got a wife and two kids.'' Among the troops _ whether Air Force personnel sleeping in air-conditioned tents, Army infantry in trailers or Marines under the desert sky _ come the usual complaints: the food, the heat, the slow mail service and the shortage of recreational facilities. ``There's not a whole lot you can do and there's no time to do it in anyway,'' Air Force Sgt. Chris Jessen said during a break from working on an F-15 fighter jet. After weeks of grumbling, a mail system is taking shape. But that means some soldiers without letters have to watch others savor the words from loved ones. Military chaplains are trying to collect and evenly distrubute mail addressed to ``any soldier, any sailor or any airman.'' Air Force officials believed they scored a morale-boosting coup when they won time for the troops _ even women _ at an $80 million Saudi military recreational facility that includes a swimming pool, bowling alley, weight room and other equipment. Some women are upset because they have to enter through the back door because of Saudi sensitivities. ``Being able to get the ladies in there at all is amazing,'' said Air Force spokesman Lt. Col. Tom Sack. The military brass is also trying to do more for morale. Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf made a tour of several camps last week. And word is circulating that Gen. Colin Powell, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, may visit next week. The U.S. Consulate is trying to help out by arranging a talent show. ``We'll have to do some different things to keep up morale,'' said Col. John LeMoyne of the 24th Mechanized Infantry Division. ``Everybody would probably like a cold beer right now, but that's just not the name of the game over here.'' Every unit seems to have an entertainer or comedian among the ranks. At the 82nd Airborne, one of the men entertains the troops by reciting lines from old war movies. A member of a security patrol at a Saudi airbase hopped out of his vehicle the other day during a sandstorm to etch a message on the sand-crusted back window. ``Beach Party '90,'' the soldier wrote. ``Tide's Out _ Way Out.''

DOC.HEAD: Combat Suits Are Chic But Not Always Functional
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Saturday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: American troops are clad in the latest in combat clothing _ stylish two-piece suits specially designed for desert duty _ but some soldiers are not convinced their fashionable duds are functional. ``They're very hot and very uncomfortable,'' said Army Lt. Col. Gene W. Cole, clad in his jumpsuit. ``It's hot and it makes me sweat,'' complained Lt. Col. Ned Longsworth. Said Air Force Capt. Becky Colaw, ``There's a big difference wearing it for work and wearing it to be cool.'' The uniforms _ with a pattern called ``chocolate-chip camouflage'' _ are 50 percent cotton and 50 percent nylon, a combination designed to make the material tough but breathable. They come in varying tints. The lightest blends in well with the sand and is the most popular. But the fabric is too heavy for the 100-plus desert temperatures, troops say. GIs generally keep their tunics on when they're outside to prevent sunburn. The American women have been told to stay covered so as not to offend Saudi sensibilities about bare skin. A rumpled forage hat, visored cap or jaunty beret is de rigeur. A cotton scarf to wipe sweat from the brow or guard against a sunburned neck is another must-have accessory. Slung around the soldiers' waists are the trappings of desert life: a chemical gas mask, canteen, flashlight, knife. An M-16 slung over the shoulder is part of the uniform for some soldiers. Soldiers give the uniforms high marks for comfort. The baggy trousers have six pockets, including cargo pockets for notebooks and assorted items. The tunic top has four pockets. ``They're designed to wear well even when they're dirty,'' said Maj. Peggy Sweet, an Air Force logistics officer based at Myrtle Beach, S.C. But the fit can be a problem for some. Like couturier outfits from Paris and Milan, the outfits hang best on those who are tall and thin. ``It's a problem if you're short and fat,'' said Ms. Colaw. Troops from all services were issued two or three uniforms before they left the United States. The outfits were specially designed for desert situations, and this is the first time they have been used in a deployment. T-shirts and underwear were not part of the package provided soldiers, so Ms. Colaw said she bought herself male boxer shorts because ``they're cooler than the women's kind.''

DOC.HEAD: Judge Sends Reporters Scurrying for Dictionary, Again
DOC.TEXT: Court reporters scurried for dictionaries _ again _ after a federal judge with a penchant for flowery language uncorked another obscure term that bedeviled the uninformed. Judge Ferdinand Fernandez, who sits on the 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals, was speaking Friday about a death penalty case when he said, ``I will not undertake to burden, bore or ensorcell the reader by glossing what the Montana Supreme Court actually wrote.'' Ensorcell, which is unlikely to pop up in everyday conversation, means to bewitch, enchant or bedevil. Fernandez was responsible for introducing facinorous (atrociously wicked) and brume (mist) into the legal record in a July ruling.

DOC.HEAD: What Might Have Happened In Persian Gulf, Without Perestroika
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Saturday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union is standing together with the United States and other Western governments in the Persian Gulf crisis. But things could have been different. What if Mikhail S. Gorbachev had not become president and introduced political and economic reforms? How would former Soviet leaders, who sent tanks into Czechoslovakia and troops into Afghanistan, have reacted to the actions of Iraqi President Saddam Hussein? Moscow News, nicknamed the ``glasnost weekly'' for its frequent muckraking and acid commentary, has suggested a scenario that is both humorous and chilling. The newspaper's ``political fantasy,'' published Aug. 26, begins with staunch Soviet support for Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. It ends with Soviet and Western ships steaming toward a military showdown. Along the way, it satirizes communist rhetoric and official pronouncements. In reality, Gorbachev condemned the Iraqi invasion, cut off arms shipments to Saddam, endorsed an economic embargo against Iraq and supported a U.N. Security Council resolution allowing navies to use force to maintain the embargo. Here, in abbreviated form, is Moscow News' fictional scenario of what might have happened if Leonid Brezhnev, or someone like him, were still running the Soviet Union:
DOC.HEAD: Aug. 3
DOC.TEXT: The official Soviet news agency Tass reports that ``the entire Soviet people unanimously greet the victory of the socialist revolution in fraternal Kuwait over the rotten monarchic regime and express class solidarity with socialist Iraq, which rendered disinterested aid to the people of Kuwait.''
DOC.HEAD: Aug. 4
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Foreign Ministry informs the American ambassador that any U.S. aggression against peace-loving Iraq shall be regarded by the Soviet government as an act against the USSR and the entire world liberation movement.
DOC.HEAD: Aug. 5
DOC.TEXT: Soviet media report that ``spontaneous mass protests against the aggressive actions of the imperialist governments'' take place in front of the U.S. and British embassies.
DOC.HEAD: Aug. 8
DOC.TEXT: The military newspaper Red Star exults over the use of Soviet-supplied weapons by Iraq. ``Berlin in 1953, Budapest in 1956, Prague in 1968, Kabul in 1979, El-Kuwait in 1990: these are the cities and years which can be proudly fixed on the armor of Soviet tanks,'' it says.
DOC.HEAD: Aug. 9
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet government announces an ``air bridge'' to supply Baghdad with arms and spare parts. It also agrees to transport Iraqi oil on Soviet tankers to break through the ``imperialist blockade.''
DOC.HEAD: Aug. 10
DOC.TEXT: Workers in the Russian city of Sormovo request that the government freeze their bank deposits and allocate 20 percent of their monthly wages to the State Defense Fund, according to official reports.
DOC.HEAD: Aug. 11
DOC.TEXT: A well-known Soviet journalist says the Kuwaiti revolution and international solidarity with Arab socialism are ``new evidence of the general crisis of capitalism.''
DOC.HEAD: Aug. 12
DOC.TEXT: The special department of the Health Ministry that takes care of top Communist officials releases a statement of support for Iraq from ``outstanding leaders of the international communist movement'' including Nicolae Ceausescu of Romania, Erich Honecker of East Germany, Gustav Husak of Czechoslovakia and Todor Zhivkov of Bulgaria.
DOC.HEAD: Aug. 13
DOC.TEXT: TV flashes report that warships operating under the aegis of the United Nations are approaching dangerously close to the Soviet squadron in the Persian Gulf. The whole world is waiting with horror: Will this be World War III?

DOC.HEAD: National Baptists Urge Negotiated Settlement to Gulf Crisis ^By DAVID BRIGGS ^Associated Press Writer
DOC.TEXT: The United States needs to solve the Persian Gulf crisis at the negotiating table rather than on the battlefield, the nation's largest black church body has declared. ``We recall that our Christ reminds us that he or she who lives by the sword will perish by the sword,'' said a resolution approved Friday by delegates to the 110th annual meeting of the National Baptist Convention U.S.A. Inc. The 7.8 million-member denomination supported President Bush's decision to send U.S. troops to the Middle East, but said the nation must deal with Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein at an international conference table. ``I just can't see lives being taken, fighting over oil,'' the Rev. T.J. Jemison, convention president, said after the vote. The resolution was unanimously approved without discussion by about 1,500 delegates representing the nation's third largest Protestant denomination. The Baptist convention said Bush was correct to send troops to the Middle East after Iraq's invasion of Kuwait to enable the nation to negotiate from a position of strength. But there are other moral issues involved, the resolution said. ``We contend that if the United States wishes for the world to move toward a democratic society, no matter how horrific the position of Saddam Hussein might appear, we must deal with him in a manner that he and all powers concerned in the Middle East are led to the world conference table for a meaningful negotiated settlement of the conflict,'' the resolution said. Pursuing a negotiated settlement through diplomacy will save lives and billions of dollars best spent to ``feed the hungry, clothe the naked, heal the sick, train the unlearned, house the homeless and encourage the lonely,'' the resolution added. The denomination also commended the Rev. Jesse Jackson for helping secure the release of some hostages. The Rev. Amos Brown, chairman of the Human Rights Commission, said the vote sends a message that U.S. foreign policy needs to be consistent and not ignore human rights violations in nations such as Kuwait, Saudi Arabia and Israel. ``For instance, we're not invading South Africa'' to halt apartheid, he said. Most major religious groups have responded cautiously to the U.S. military deployment in the Middle East, balancing a condemnation of the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait with concerns that the United States act out of humanitarian motives rather than to protect oil interests.

DOC.HEAD: Questions Mount About Lack Of Allied Ground Troops in Arabia
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Saturday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Asked why they have not deployed ground troops in Saudi Arabia alongside U.S. forces, America's allies have an easy answer _ the Saudis haven't invited them. This reply, however accurate, has failed to prevent increasingly strident calls in the United States for its allies to share more of the military burden _ and the risks _ in the showdown with Iraq's Saddam Hussein. Britain says it plans to send more forces to the Persian Gulf, possibly including ground troops. But other Western European countries show no signs of similar action, citing the lack of a formal Saudi invitation and various other reasons. France, which has mounted the second-largest Western deployment in the gulf in the form of a naval task force, says it will not help finance the U.S. effort and would probably join ground operations only under U.N. auspices. Portugal, which has committed one naval support vessel to the gulf, says its ground and air units wouldn't be effective. West Germany and Japan say their constitutions bar them from deploying forces in far-off regions, although the Germans have suggested the possibility of a constitutional amendment. Greece, Italy and Australia, which have dispatched a total of nine warships to the gulf, say no one asked them to send ground troops and the subject hasn't been considered. ``It wasn't necessary,'' said Vittorio Surdo, an Italian Foreign Ministry spokesman. ``We think our contribution is important enough in other respects.'' U.S. officials say the cost of the 100,000-strong American force in the region is about $1 billion a month. They are lobbying hard for larger financial contributions from allies. The nations of the European Community agreed Friday to give $2 billion in economic aid to Turkey, Jordan and Egypt to compensate them for trade lost as a result of sanctions against Iraq. However, the 12 EC states made no promises to contribute to the cost of deploying U.S. troops in the Persian Gulf. After the meeting, Italy's foreign minister, Gianni De Michelis, told reporters, ``We want to contribute to the burden-sharing in an independent and direct manner and not to the expenses of a separate country, even though it is an ally.'' So far, President Bush's administration has handled the issue of ground troops with restraint. It has praised countries for even modest naval contributions and made no specific public requests for allied infantry units. But Secretary of State James A. Baker III, during a Senate hearing Wednesday, conveyed growing impatience. ``We'd like to, frankly, see perhaps a few more ground troops in there,'' he said. ``I think that there's a good chance that there will be additional ground and air forces.'' His comments followed blunt remarks from several senators, including Democrat John F. Kerry of Massachusetts. Kerry recently visited U.S. troops in Saudi Arabia and told Baker he was upset by what he found. ``I didn't notice any of our other allies, and that disturbs me,'' Kerry said. ``It is one thing to be in the Persian Gulf on a ship somewhat removed from the first line, and another to be up there in the desert bearing that heat and the immediate risk.'' Harsher commentary came Thursday in an editorial in The New York Times. ``The arguments some Europeans and Japanese make for vacillating are almost as repellent as the vacillation,'' said the editorial, depicting such allies as ``sideline soldiers or deadbeats, eager for us to protect their oil with our blood.'' The Saudi government has been tight-lipped about details of its requests for Western military aid. Diplomats say these requests are based on the kingdom's specific needs and on past military dealings with individual countries. For example, Britain and France were involved previously with Saudi air defense and thus were asked to help in that field. Britain sent aircraft rather than ground troops ``because this is what the Saudis asked us for, and this is all by invitation,'' a British Defense Ministry spokesman said. ``They operate the same type of Tornado (fighters) as we do and therefore have the ground force facilities for those.'' Britain has sent four warships to the Persian Gulf, one squadron of Tornados to Saudi Arabia and one to Bahrain, a Jaguar squadron to Oman, and a surface-to-air missile unit to Bahrain. Its total force of just over 2,000 military personnel is the only significant Western deployment aside from the United States and France. Several Western countries, among them Denmark and Norway, say they might contribute ground troops to a U.N. peacekeeping force, but not a U.S.-commanded force. Baker told Congress the United States does not want to put the military effort under U.N. command.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Members who used a0431 of Sept. 6, slugged PM-Sex Questions, a sidebar to the New York-datelined PM-Sex Test, may wish to use the following.
DOC.TEXT: The phrasing of a question and answer in a sex knowledge survey released Wednesday by the Kinsey Institute, and reported by The Associated Press, may have been misleading. The true-false question stated, ``There are over-the-counter spermicides people can buy at the drugstore that will kill the AIDS virus.'' The correct answer given was ``True.'' That does not mean the spermicides will cure AIDS, the Kinsey report says. Instead, many health care professionals say using the spermicides along with a condom may help protect against transmission of the AIDS virus during sexual intercourse, the report says. The spermicides include an ingredient called nonoxynol-9 that can kill the AIDS virus in the test tube, the report says. June Reinisch, director of the Kinsey Institute, said, ``It is very likely to work in people.''

DOC.HEAD: Aylwin Goverment Rejects Pinochet Criticism Of German Army
DOC.TEXT: The goverment has criticized comments by army chief and former president Gen. Augusto Pinochet, who said the German army has soldiers who are ``marijuana smokers, drug addicts, long hairs, homosexuals and unionists.'' Pinochet's comments ``may seriously jeopardize the friendly relations between Chile and West Germany,'' Acting Foreign Minister Patricio Rojas said Friday. Rojas said he relayed the government's position to German charge d'affairs Hans Ulrich Spohn during a meeting Friday. The same day, Bonn formally protested Pinochet's comments made during a speech Wednesday. Pinochet later recanted, saying he did not intend to offend the German army, and that his words were probably misinterpreted. Pinochet, who handed in power to President Patricio Aylwin last March, has refused to step down as head of the army. He is sheltered by a special clause in the 1980 constitution written by his military regime, which lasted 16 years.

DOC.HEAD: Brady Returns From Global Fund-Raising Effort
DOC.TEXT: Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady is declaring his global fund-raising effort a success even though he received no specific pledges of new assistance. Brady's delegation returned to Washington on Friday night following an 18,500-mile journey that saw him hold hurried consultations with world leaders in Paris, London, Seoul, South Korea and Tokyo. In addition to Brady's mission, Secretary of State James A. Baker III made a whirlwind tour seeking support from the oil-rich countries of the Middle East. The United States is trying to raise more than $25 billion to defray the costs of the American military buildup in the Persian Gulf and provide emergency assistance to Egypt, Jordan and Turkey, three countries which have been hard hit by the trade embargo against Iraq. In each of the capitals Brady visited, he delivered the same message and received virtually the same response. Brady was thanked for coming forward with a plan for coordinating assistance and was politely told the country in question would have to study the proposal further before making any additional commitments of aid. Brady insisted he was not daunted by the lack of specifics because he believed the delegation had made a convincing case at each stop. He said the cost of failing to protect the Middle Eastern oil fields was far higher than the sums being sought in the U.S. aid package. ``Our principal message throughout this trip has been that there is a cost which all must share in maintaining a freely flowing source of oil,'' Brady said. He said that for Japan alone a $10 jump in oil prices represents almost $20 billion in higher fuel bills. For South Korea, the annual cost in higher fuel bills was estimated at $2.5 billion. Brady said he used those figures in his meetings Friday with South Korean President Roh Tae-woo and Japanese Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu. Both countries are heavily dependent on the flow of Middle Eastern oil. Oil, which was selling for around $18 per barrel before the Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait, has been trading around $30 a barrel in recent days. Flying home from Tokyo, administration officials were upbeat about their chances of ultimate success although one conceded that full acceptance of the plan ``might take a little longer than we had hoped.'' The administration officials, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said that Tokyo was being asked to increase substantially its initial pledge of $1 billion. The officials said the total amount being sought from Japan was higher than $2 billion with one official saying the request was for ``billions of dollars'' although he refused to quantify the number any further. One official said he ``wouldn't be surprised if we got very close'' to the figure being sought, even though Japanese officials during Brady's visit had a lot of questions about how the economic assistance money would be distributed. The administration had been expressing unhappiness privately about the amount Japan has committed, given the fact that the country has sent no troops to the Persian Gulf and has a vibrant economy which imports 70 percent of its oil from the troubled region. For its part, Japan has announced it will contribute $1 billion to support the military forces in the Gulf and has indicated it is willing to give humanitarian aid as well. While Kaifu made no specific commitment on additional funds, U.S. officials said they were satisfied that their proposal would get a serious review by his government. One official conceded that the various reports of dissension over the details of the plan did not help that effort, but he insisted the impact would be temporary. ``It's where you are a month or two from now that counts,'' said the official on Brady's plane, who declined to be identified further. ``He will understand billions of dollars'' in Western support for the military and trade embargo.

DOC.HEAD: Vietnam To Return Sets of Suspected Remains Of Americans
DOC.TEXT: Vietnam next week will turn over 20 sets of remains that may be those of Americans missing from the Vietnam War, a U.S. Embassy spokesman said today. A U.S. military team will go to Hanoi, Vietnam's capital, to receive the remains Thursday and fly them to U.S. facilities for analysis, said spokesman James Williams. It would be the largest return of remains since 28 sets were handed over June 21, 1989. The United States withdrew from Vietnam in 1973, after losing almost 58,000 lives in a failed attempt to protect the South Vietnam government from the communist North Vietnamese. The communists won and reunified the country in April 1975. The Pentagon lists 2,300 Americans as missing in action, or MIA: 1,677 in Vietnam, 534 in Laos, 83 in Cambodia and six in China's coastal waters.

DOC.HEAD: Back-To-School Fashion in New York City: Bulletproof Jackets
LaserPhoto NY10
DOC.TEXT: Bulletproof back-to-school clothes are the latest thing for New York City children who run a dangerous gauntlet to and from class. School blazers, windbreakers and other jackets fitted with bullet-resistant Kevlar 129 pads are providing a feeling of security to parents undaunted by price tags ranging from $250 to $600. Added shielding from flying bullets can be had from a bulletproof book bag or clipboard. They're offered by former New York City police officer Stephen D'Andrilli, whose security firm, Guardian Group International Corp., is fielding inquiries about the jackets in New York and in similarly crime-plagued Chicago and Los Angeles. Hairdresser John DeLoca, 41, is a satisfied customer who recently bought $450 jackets for himself and his two sons, age 8 and 4. ``God forbid if they should be caught in a crossfire or a random shooting, then $450 would seem like a pretty good investment,'' he said. ``We're talking about my children's lives and the bottom line is: You can't buy another kid.'' Guardian Group has taken nearly three dozen back-to-school orders, with hundreds of telephone inquiries promising more business, D'Andrilli said. Demand comes after a rash of summertime child deaths in New York, often by random gunfire. Four children were slain in an eight-day period in August. New York is on its way to a record number of homicides for the third straight year. There were 1,905 homicides citywide in 1989. Kevlar is a synthetic material five times stronger than steel and relatively light. It is used in police bulletproof vests and vehicle armor. Its composition is a closely guarded trade secret, but recent technological advances made it 25 percent lighter and 40 percent thinner than before, so it is less noticeable and more comfortable. D'Andrilli admits no clothing is ever truly ``bulletproof,'' but demonstrates that Kevlar pads will stop slugs and can save lives. ``See here,'' said D'Andrilli, pointing to a swatch of Kevlar fabric showing dents from two Uzi bullets. ``You may get bruises from the impact, some trauma such as broken ribs, but the bullets won't pierce the body,'' he said. In his office, D'Andrilli has a row of fashion dummies sporting jackets, vests and T-shirts with panels of Kevlar concealed in pouches. Joining the back-to-school lineup are Kevlar-lined fur coats and business suits, briefcases and umbrellas. The line of fur and leather coats starts at about $3,000 and tops out with a Russian sable coat for $80,000. The bulletproof clipboard goes for $300. An 8-year-old boy named Palmer, in bow tie and red-and-white pinstriped shirt, snapped on a denim jacket featuring Kevlar ``Silent Armor'' and said it felt only slightly heavier than normal. ``It feels good, it feels like you have good protection and nobody even knows you have it on,'' Palmer said, patting the hidden panels. His 6-year-old brother, Trevor, tried on a bright red Kevlar-filled windbreaker and proudly announced: ``I might be an undercover cop.''

DOC.HEAD: `Chrome Domes' Gather in Morehead City
DOC.TEXT: John Capps III knows all too well what it's like to be lonely at the top. He's president of Bald Headed Men of America, a 20,000-member organization in which it doesn't pay to get thin-skinned about being thin-haired. This weekend, the organization is holding its 17th annual Bald is Beautiful convention in Morehead City, the natural host for such a meeting. ``We're growing because of lack of growth,'' Capps said. ``We're proud of every hair we don't have.'' About 200 bright and shining members are coming from as far away as England to trade bald jokes and hold such contests as the Solar Dome competition for best-tanned head. Winners are inducted into the Bald of Fame. Society takes baldness too seriously, Capps insists. And that can lead to some not-so-funny consequences. In the fourth hair-free generation of men in his family, Capps got started early. At 15, he was already well on his way to baldness. Although his family didn't make him feel out of place, Capps, 48, didn't find the rest of the world so understanding. He founded the organization after being turned down for a job by a large Atlanta financial institution. Even though he was just out of college, Capps said he was told the company was looking for a ``youthful, dynamic personality. And a baldheaded man, even one just out of school, didn't fit in to those plans. ``Society can be pretty cruel,'' said Capps, who runs a print shop in Morehead City. And so, along with the gags, conventioneers this weekend will participate in workshops on baldness, self-esteem and sexuality. ``Baldness should be treated with positive mental attitude,'' he said. ``What's in the head is more important than what's on top of it.''

DOC.HEAD: Sudan Supporting Iraq To Pay for Previous Iraqi Military Aid
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Sudan, traditionally Egypt's closest friend, has broken with its big brother to the north by refusing to denounce Saddam Hussein. The junta is paying back favors to Iraq and trying to avert explosive domestic problems. But Sudan's strongman, Lt. Gen. Omar Hassan el-Bashir, is increasing his own isolation among Arabs and within the international community by joining the small group of nations sympathizing with the Iraqi president. Western experts say the policy is calculated to increase el-Bashir's popularity at home. He wants to draw attention from Sudan's tottering economy by focusing on domestic sentiment against the U.S.-led international military presence in the Persian Gulf, they said. Aside from Sudan, the only Arab League members supporting or willing to put up with Saddam's Aug. 2 invasion of neighboring Kuwait are Jordan, Yemen, Tunisia, Algeria, Mauritania, Libya and the Palestine Liberation Organization. El-Bashir refused on Aug. 10 to join Egypt and 11 other Arab League members in condemning the invasion. Since then he has made trips and speeches denouncing the Western military buildup in Saudi Arabia and calling for an Arab solution to the occupation of Kuwait. On Thursday, el-Bashir told scholars and politicians in Sudan's capital, Khartoum, that the buildup was meant ``to change the geopolitical situation in the area.'' It's already changed in Sudan, said a Western diplomat in Khartoum who follows that country's military affairs closely. In recent years, he said by telephone, Iraq has become one of the Sudan government's main sources of weapons to fight a 7-year-old insurgency in the south. Sudan, in northeastern Africa, is the continent's largest country, the size of the United States east of the Mississippi River. As el-Bashir drew the country away from its traditionally close ties with Egypt and the United States after his coup on June 30, 1989, Saddam filled the vacuum. The diplomatic source said Saddam last year sent el-Bashir Soviet-made T-54 and T-55 tanks and artillery rockets. This year, a loan of Iraqi transport planes, ammunition and other military hardware prevented the Sudanese rebels from capturing the southern capital, Juba, the source said. But he and other experts denied recurrent reports that Iraq has based soldiers, warplanes and Scud surface-to-surface missiles in Sudan since the Gulf crisis began. Sudan's government also has denied the reports. Other specialists on Sudan agreed that keeping a new-found friend happy might have something to do with el-Bashir's position. But they said more important is his desire to exploit the gulf crisis to gain popularity. ``Although Iraq did them a favor, the regime's primary concern is the domestic situation,'' said Peter Woodward, a lecturer at the University of Redding in England. ``They believe the anti-Western, anti-American sentiment can bring them local popularity.'' So far, el-Bashir's extreme martial-law rule has gained him little popularity except from the small but well-organized Moslem fundamentalist National Islamic Front. His harsh treatment of dissidents and summary execution of 28 officers after an alleged coup attempt last spring brought international outrage and intensified his isolation. Since the gulf crisis began, thousands of Sudanese have demonstrated in support of Saddam, and the Sudanese strongman has visited Baghdad several times trying to mediate a diplomatic solution.

DOC.HEAD: FBI Director: Asian Organized Crime Groups Becoming More Powerful
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th graf to CORRECT spelling of heroin, sted heroine. Pick up 6th graf, `Unfortunately, Asian ...'
DOC.TEXT: Law enforcement agencies must spend more time and money fighting Asian crime syndicates, which are becoming one of the most powerful criminal forces in the United States, the FBI director says. Asian organized crime groups traditionally choose victims in their own ethnic community, FBI Director William Sessions told a gathering of business leaders Friday. ``Now they are extending their tentacles out to the rest of American society,'' he said. ``Indeed, Asian crime groups are networking and interacting not only with each other but with La Cosa Nostra and Colombian drug cartels as well,'' he said. The FBI first became aware of the extent of Asian organized crime when agents seized 900 pounds of 90 percent pure heroin worth more than $1 billion in February 1989, Sessions said. ``Unfortunately, Asian criminal organizations are gaining larger and stronger footholds around the country,'' Session said. Japanese, Vietnamese and Chinese organized crime groups are the strongest in the United States, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets and Japan Say Relations Warming, But Problems Remain
DOC.TEXT: Japan and the Soviet Union view Mikhail Gorbachev's coming trip to Tokyo as a sign frayed relations are on the mend, but a territorial dispute over a group of small islands remains a roadblock to normalization. Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze on Friday returned to Moscow after three days of meetings in Tokyo, where he set an April date for the Soviet president to visit Japan. It will be the first visit by a Soviet leader to Tokyo. Both sides noted a warming of long-strained relations during Shevardnadze's visit and pledged to work toward closer ties. In a joint statement released Friday, the countries said ``both sides must make efforts to make the visit to Japan by the Soviet president a major turning point in Japan-U.S.S.R. relations.'' But it was unclear whether the countries were any closer to resolving a territorial dispute that has prevented the signing of a peace treaty to formally end hostilities after World War II. ``I could not find any practical change in the attitude of the Soviet Union on the territorial issue,'' Japanese Foreign Minister Taro Nakayama said Friday after two days of talks with his Soviet counterpart. For years, Tokyo has insisted that the sparsely populated Kuril islands off northern Japan seized by the Soviet Union at the end of the war must be returned before there can be any real progress in economic or political ties. The chain of islands were Japanese territory from 1875 until after the war. Shevardnadze, speaking at a news conference Friday, hinted that Moscow was willing to talk and possibly make concessions. ``On a bilateral basis we may introduce some change, some further amendments, but only in the spirit of negotiations and based on a rational dialogue,'' Shevardnadze said. He also said the two countries were ready to discuss ``new principles'' with Gorbachev's visit. That appeared to echo comments attributed to Gorbachev in recent weeks that he was willing to talk about anything in a summit with Japanese Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu. The Soviet Union has long sent conflicting signals on whether it was willing to negotiate the fate of the islands. As recently as July, Gorbachev refused to discuss Japan's claim to the disputed islands, saying the issue had been decided after World War II and the Soviet Union abided by postwar arrangements. Some analysts say they expect the Soviets to seek a resolution to the territorial issue to gain access to Japanese economic aid and investment to help shore up the faltering Soviet economy. Moscow has said it wants increased Japanese economic cooperation, particularly in remote Siberia. Japanese newspapers today applauded the apparent Soviet flexibility toward the territorial dispute but noted that resolution of the issue still seemed far away. The English-language Japan Times said in an editorial that Shevardnadze's visit ``has produced a little brighter hope that Japan and the Soviet Uion may manage to narrow differences'' over the islands. The Daily Yomiuri said it agreed with Shevardnadze's assessment that resolving the dispute would take a long time. ``There is no need for impatience,'' it said in an editorial. ``On the other hand, the promotion of improved relations should never be used as an excuse to put off the territorial issue.'' The Kuril islands were Japanese territory from 1875 until 1945, when they were awarded to the Soviet Union at the Yalta conference of Allied powers.

DOC.HEAD: Youths Given Probation in Assault on Studds
DOC.TEXT: Two Maryland teen-agers are being sentenced to probation and community service work for the June 7 beating of Rep. Gerry Studds. U.S. Magistrate Patrick Attridge told the two youths Friday that he seriously considered sending them to prison. He opted for probation, saying drunkenness impaired their judgment at the time of the assault. The two had pleaded guilty and Attridge also said their admission of guilt played a part in his decision. James L. Byrne, 19, of Silver Spring, faces one year of probation, 100 hours of community service and will pay $170 in restitution. Thomas E. Carter, 19, also of Silver Spring, will serve three years of probation, provide 100 hours of community service, pay $170 in restitution and enroll in a program for alcohol abusers. Attridge said Carter received a more severe sentence because he had an undisclosed prior record. Studds' spokesman, Steven Schwadron, said he is certain the nine-term liberal Democrat is ``glad that justice has been done.'' Of the decision not to order prison time, Schwadron said, ``That was a decision for the judge.'' Byrne and Carter faced a maximum of one year in prison and a $100,000 fine for assaulting a member of Congress. The attack took place as Studds was walking home alone from a dinner party. The two youths, according to their own admissions, had been drinking in a bar near Studds' residence, emerged from the bar and were unable to remember where they'd parked their car. Carter said they became frustrated at being unable to find the car and, for no particular reason, took out their frustration on Studds. The congressman was punched in the face, knocked to the ground and kicked, according to prosecutors and witnesses. Studds suffered bruises and lacerations to the face and body but was not hospitalized. The youths said they did not learn that they had attacked a congressman until after the assault. They insisted the attack had nothing to do with Studds being gay. Studds also said at the time that he had no indication that the attack was a gay-bashing incident.

DOC.HEAD: Trial Ordered for Elderly Man Held in Mercy Killing Case
DOC.TEXT: The lawyer for an elderly, California man accused of helping his wife commit suicide says he doubts a jury would convict him since he acted out of love. Bertram Harper was ordered Friday to stand trial on murder and conspiracy charges in the Aug. 19 death of his wife, Virginia, in a motel room. Harper, 72, could receive a life sentence. Harper's lawyer, Hugh Davis, said the murder charge wouldn't stand up because Harper's help in securing a plastic bag over his wife's head lacked the key element of malice. ``I don't think a jury's going to convict this man of anything,'' Davis said. ``I don't believe an act of love is a crime. This is a case of love and death, and which shall prevail? We believe love will.'' Mrs. Harper planned her suicide after learning she was terminally ill with breast and liver cancer, her husband said. The murder case against Harper rests largely on his telling police he had put the bag over his wife's head and secured it around her neck after a non-lethal combination of pills and alcohol put her to sleep. The official cause of death was asphyxiation, the Wayne County medical examiner's office said. District Judge Henry Zaborowski ordered Harper tried on one count of open murder, which may be defined at trial as first- or second-degree murder or manslaughter, and one count of conspiracy to commit murder. Under Michigan law, first-degree murder is punished by mandatory life imprisonment; second-degree murder by up to life imprisonment; and manslaughter by up to 15 years imprisonment. Harper told police they came to Michigan from their home in Loomis, Calif., because they believed Michigan had no law making it illegal to assist in a suicide. Under California law, such an act is a felony punishable by up to five years in prison. Shanda McGrew, 40, Mrs. Harper's daughter and Harper's stepdaughter, flew to Michigan with them and was present at her mother's death. She is an unindicted co-conspirator in the case. Zaborowski let Harper return to California under $25,000 bond. He probably will not have to return to Michigan until his trial begins in late October or early November, Davis said.

DOC.HEAD: Watchdog Group Says Cuban Police Harassed Human Rights Activists
DOC.TEXT: A Cuban human rights group says Cuban security agents harassed and threatened its five-member delegation during a United Nations conference on crime-fighting in Havana this week. The International League for Human Rights, which does consultation work for the U.N., said its delegates were prevented from attending the weeklong Seventh Congress on Crime that closed Friday. The Cuban government of Fidel Castro had no immediate public comment on the incidents. Dispatches on the conference by the official Cuban news agency Prensa Latina from Havana, monitored in the Mexican capital, made no mention of them. All five league delegates, including three Havana residents and prominent Cuban human rights activists opposed to President Castro's communist regime, were previously approved by the U.N., the league said. One of them, Yndamiro Restano, is a member of the Cuban Commission for Human Rights and National Reconciliation. Another, Antonio de Varona Batlle served as defense counsel for commission leader Elizardo Sanchez when Sanchez was recently tried for ``disseminating false news against international peace.'' Jorge Bacallao, the third, is a legal adviser to the Cuban Human Rights Committee, another non-government group. The other two are Robert Cox, associate editor of the Charleston, S.C., Courier Post, and Dianne Orentlicher, a lawyer who taught at Yale, Harvard and Columbia universities. Both are on the league's board of directors. The delegates were not allowed to attend the conference despite a personal invitation by U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar, the league said Friday in a news release from its base in New York City. It quoted Cox as saying that state security groups, who appeared to be ``out of control, ... harassed, intimidated and threatened'' the delegates throughout the meeting. Acting Foreign Minister Rolando Lopes del Amo also threatened both Cox and the league, saying ``his government would oppose the league's continued consultative status at the United Nations,'' the league said. One of the Cubans ``was physically pushed out of the conference hall'' and all three ``were physically detained temporarily by security police in a hall off the conference site.'' A security official named Felipe Zilla ``intimated to (Cox) that Mr. Restano was in danger,'' the league said, and expressed concern that the Cubans, ``threatened and followed by security officials, may suffer reprisals'' now that the conference ended. The week long congress, held by the U.N. every five years, aims at formulating guidelines on fighting crime while protecting prisoners from abuse and their lawyers from reprisals in countries under authoritarian governments. A Prensa Latina dispatch Friday only said 1,700 delegates from 129 nations held 14 plenary sessions and approved about 30 resolutions _ one of them praising the Castro government and the Cuban people for their hospitality _ before it closed. Cox, an Englishman and editor of the Buenos Aires Herald at the time, was awarded the United Kingdom's Order of the British Empire for denouncing rights abuses by right-wing military regimes during Argentina's ``dirty war'' against suspected leftist subversives in the 1970s. Founded in 1942, the league has been accredited to the U.N. for more than a half-century, working worldwide to combat rights abuses. Soviet dissident Andrei Sakharov was its honorary president until he died last year.

DOC.HEAD: Treaty Questions Raised by Planned Anti-Missile Test
DOC.TEXT: Critics say a planned Star Wars test in the South Pacific comes close to violating a 1972 treaty outlawing major missile defenses. Near the middle of the month, a Boeing 767 equipped with a 3-ton infrared sensor will make its first attempt to track a mock warhead on an intercontinental ballistic missile fired from Vandenberg Air Force Base, Calif. The plane is scheduled to depart Boeing Field in Seattle on Monday for a two-day trip to Kwajalein Atoll, an Army missile test range in the Pacific. Anti-ballistic missile radar is prohibited by the 1972 ABM Treaty between the United States and the Soviet Union. John Pike, head of space policy at the Federation of American Scientists and a Star Wars critic, said the aircraft ``appears to be the functional equivalent of an ABM radar.'' Pike said the Soviets may be justified in questioning whether the airborne sensor is a treaty violation. ``If we saw the Russians doing this kind of thing, we would be pretty bent out of shape about it, and if the Russians were giving the explanation we are, we wouldn't believe them,'' Pike said. The Army says the airborne sensor is not a prototype for an anti-missile sensor system. It also argues that the aircraft could not substitute for an ABM radar because of technical limitations in its infrared sensor and its on-board computers.
DOC.HEAD: Administration Reiterates That 1973 Decision Should Be Overturned
DOC.TEXT: A new administration broadside aimed at legalized abortion suggests pro-choice advocates have much to fear from Supreme Court nominee David Souter, says the executive director of the National Abortion Rights Action League. In a Supreme Court brief filed Friday, Solicitor General Kenneth Starr defended Reagan administration regulations that prohibit government-financed family planning clinics from providing abortion counseling. The regulations promulgated by the Department of Health and Human Services in 1988 have been challenged by family planning clinics, Planned Parenthood and other organizations. The solicitor general said ``we continue to believe'' that Roe vs. Wade was ``wrongly decided and should be overruled.'' But he stopped short of asking the justices to do so in pending cases involving New York City family planning clinics. ``This is direct evidence that there is reason to fear Judge Souter,'' said Kate Michelman of NARAL. ``The administration must feel confident they will soon have the votes to overturn Roe.'' The clinics are financed under a $200 million-a-year program under Title 10 of the Public Health Service Act. The law forbids the clinics from performing abortions but earlier regulations had allowed counselors to advise women that terminating a pregnancy was an option. The court is considering two cases from New York City in which the 2nd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals upheld the 1988 regulations on a 2-1 vote. But some other federal appeals courts have ruled the regulations were unconstitutional.
DOC.HEAD: Lawmakers Want to Revive Windfall Profits Tax
DOC.TEXT: The oil jolt from the Persian Gulf crisis is renewing calls in Congress for a windfall profits tax. Sen. Bob Packwood, R-Ore., and Rep. Paul Kanjorski, D-Pa., have announced separate measures to restore the tax, which was repealed in 1987. Kanjorski's measure directs the tax revenue to pay the government's cost of insuring depositors of failed savings and loans. He estimated that it would raise $15 billion annually. Like Packwood's bill, Kanjorski's measure would impose a tax of up to 70 percent on excessive profits from oil sales. Packwood gave no estimate of how much money his measure would raise, but he said it would be based on the earlier tax. Both measures face stiff opposition from representatives of oil-producing states. They say such a tax discourages exploration and production at a time when the domestic industry should be trying to grow.

DOC.HEAD: Chronology of Superpower Summits
DOC.TEXT: The meeting Sunday in Helsinki, Finland, between President Bush and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev will be the 22nd superpower summit. Summits began in World War II as the Allies debated the shape of the postwar world. Here is a list: _ Tehran, Iran, Nov. 28-Dec. 1, 1943: The Big Three _ President Roosevelt, British Prime Minister Winston Churchill and Josef Stalin of the Soviet Union _ discuss the war against Germany. Stalin presses for a second front to relieve Soviet armies. _ Yalta, Soviet Union, Feb. 4-11, 1945: Roosevelt, Churchill and Stalin discuss the postwar world, granting Stalin influence over the nations that ultimately form the Soviet bloc. _ Potsdam, Germany, July 17-Aug. 2, 1945: President Truman and Clement Atlee, Churchill's successor, face Stalin. Truman tells Stalin the United States has a powerful new weapon, but doesn't say what it is. _ Geneva, July 18-23, 1955: President Eisenhower meets with Soviet Premier Nikolai Bulganin and the leaders of England and France to discuss occupied Germany. _ Camp David, Md., Sept. 25-27, 1959: Nikita Khrushchev, as Soviet premier, meets Eisenhower during a two-week visit to the United States. They agree to reopen talks on the status of Berlin and issue a communique calling disarmament an important issue. _ Paris, May 16, 1960: The meeting collapses on opening day when Khrushchev demands an apology for the American U-2 spy plane shot down over the Soviet Union. He withdraws an invitation for Eisenhower to visit the Soviet Union. _ Vienna, Austria, June 3-4, 1961: President Kennedy and Khrushchev meet, but talks on a nuclear test ban and arms control produce no agreement. They issue a joint communique affirming their support for a neutral Laos and willingness to maintain contact. _ Glassboro, N.J., June 23-25, 1967: President Johnson and Soviet Premier Alexei Kosygin meet but resolve no differences over the Vietnam War, the Arab-Israeli war and nuclear arms. _ Moscow, May 22-24, 1972: President Nixon and Soviet President Leonid Brezhnev meet, the first time a U.S. president has visited Moscow. They sign agreements on health, the environment and space and scientific cooperation. _ Washington, June 18-25, 1973: Brezhnev and Nixon sign a pledge to seek agreement to end the nuclear arms race in 1974 and a pledge to cooperate in avoiding confrontations. _ Moscow, June 27-July 3, 1974: Nixon and Brezhnev sign a number of documents on nuclear weapons, including one limiting underground nuclear explosions. Secretary of State Henry Kissinger says impeachment proceedings hamper Nixon. _ Vladivostok, U.S.S.R., Nov. 23-24, 1974: President Ford and Brezhnev reach tentative agreement to limit the number of strategic offensive nuclear weapons and delivery vehicles, including multiple-warhead missiles. _ Helsinki, Finland, July 30-Aug. 2, 1975: Ford and Brezhnev are among leaders of 35 nations meeting on European security. They report progress on strategic arms issues. _ Vienna, June 15-18, 1979: President Carter and Brezhnev conclude seven years of strategic arms limitation talks with the signing of the SALT II treaty. _ Geneva, Nov. 19-21, 1985: President Reagan and Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev spend far more time in private sessions than planned but do not reach any breakthrough on major issues. Reagan calls it a ``fresh start'' in relations. _ Reykjavik, Iceland, Oct. 11-12, 1986: Reagan and Gorbachev hold detailed talks on eliminating nuclear weapons but disagree over the U.S. strategic defense initiative, known as Star Wars. _ Washington, Dec. 8-10, 1987: Reagan and Gorbachev sign a treaty to eliminate intermediate-range nuclear forces, but disagreement over Star Wars blocks progress on a strategic arms reduction treaty. _ Moscow, May 29-June 2, 1988: Reagan and Gorbachev exchange the ratified texts of the INF treaty, discuss strategic and conventional arms and stroll in Red Square. Reagan softens his criticism of Soviet human rights abuses; Gorbachev complains of missed opportunities. _ New York, Dec. 7, 1988: Reagan, Gorbachev and President-elect Bush meet on Governor's Island in New York harbor to discuss Gorbachev's announcement at the United Nations that the Soviet Union will reduce its armed forces by 500,000 men and withdraw 50,000 from Europe. Gorbachev rushes home to cope with the earthquake in Armenia. _ Marsaxlokk Bay, Malta, Dec. 2-3, 1989: Bush and Gorbachev meet aboard a Soviet cruise liner for dockside talks that produce no breakthroughs in superpower relations. They agree it is time to end the Cold War, and Bush pledges to take steps to ease U.S. tariffs on Soviet exports. _ Washington, May 30-June 3, 1990: Bush and Gorbachev seal agreements to slash long-range nuclear weapons, halt production of chemical weapons and lift trade barriers against Moscow. The two also discuss Lithuanian independence, German unity and other developments in Eastern Europe.

DOC.HEAD: Finns Taking Higher International Profile
DOC.TEXT: Finns are taking a more active role in international politics now that they don't have to worry so much about upsetting the superpower next door. This democratic, free-market society has always been cautious about swimming in the turbulent waters of international politics for fear it would be caught in the Cold War battle. But with the recent changes in the Soviet Union, and with the Soviets and the West getting along better, the Finns are getting their feet wet. ``We are now driven to take stands on international issues. It has been less so previously in the circumstances of the East-West conflict,'' said Jaakko Blomberg, head of the political department of Finland's Foreign Ministry. President Mauno Koivisto, whose nation plays host to the U.S.-Soviet summit this weekend, gave a taste of things to come in an unusually strong criticism of Iraq on national television. Manni Manninen, special counsel to the president, said that ``we have chosen our policy to not get involved in issues over which the superpowers disagree themselves.'' Government officials, activists and academics now say there is no longer the same basis for being quiet. For decades, successive Social Democratic-dominated governments have repeated the canon that neutrality _ coupled with a security and cooperation agreement with the Soviet Union _ was in Finland's best interest. The policy was seldom debated in this country which shares an 800-mile border with the Soviet Union. Many ``Finns on the street'' still believe that keeping a low international profile is the best policy for their country, which fought from 1939 to 44 in order to remain independent. But the changes in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe have opened up whole new areas for discussion. One of them is the possibility of Finland joining the European Community. ``Such a debate would not have taken place before. Let's be frank,'' Blomberg said. ``For the first time in a long time, a real substantial foreign policy debate is evolving,'' said Max Jakobson, Finland's ambassador to the United Nations from 1965-72. Jakobson was the Scandinavian governments' candidate for U.N. secretary-general in 1971, but there was speculation abroad that the Soviets blocked his appointment because of his right-wing leanings. ``In earlier periods there was a sense of living under a certain threat and there was a strong consensus in Finland that it was important to support the policy of neutrality,'' said Jakobson, who is not a member of any party. Presidential counselor Manninen said, ``The Finnish doctrine has been, and still is, that Finland strives to keep herself outside superpower conflicts, not to involve herself with issues in which the superpowers disagree between themselves.'' Now that the confrontation between the Soviet Union and the United States ``has more or less ended and is moving toward cooperation, as manifested in the present gulf crisis, this doctrine cannot any more be applied because the superpowers agree, rather than disagree,'' he said. ``That doesn't automatically mean we are going to start chatting about everything, shooting from the hip at everything that moves,'' Manninen said. Blomberg said of the Persian Gulf crisis, ``You could imagine what the consequences would be if the Soviet Union and the United States had not seen it the same way.'' ``We would in that situation seek a role that we traditionally serve, that of peacekeepers,'' he said. ``That's what we do.'' Finland has contributed to every United Nations peacekeeping operation and currently has more troops on U.N. duty than any other country. While the Finns now have more options in reacting to international events, they know that circumstances change. ``Our policy has always been, and will always be, that we are cautious,'' said Manninen. ``We cannot change our geography so we will always be neighbors with (the Soviet Union) and they will always be a great power.'' ``Neutrality is like an umbrella you carry with you in case it rains,'' said Jakobson. ``You cannot throw it away when the sun shines.''

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: Actress Kirstie Alley, whose pregnancy was going to be part of upcoming ``Cheers'' episodes, has suffered a miscarriage, the show's publicist confirmed. The star of the popular NBC sitcom disclosed her pregnancy two weeks ago in a televised interview with Maria Shriver. The baby had been due in March and ``Cheers'' producers had planned to eventually integrate it into the show. ``Cheers'' publicist Bob Myer said Alley had a miscarriage but is back at work and doing fine. Alley and her husband, actor Parker Stevenson, will continue trying to have a family.

Barbara Bush will take her literacy campaign to the air waves, reading stories to children during a 10-week radio series beginning later this month. The first lady will read children's tales to a cartoon character during the 25-minute ``Mrs. Bush's Story Time.'' Literacy tips and an interview with a celebrity will follow on the once-a-week show beginning Sept. 16 on the ABC Radio Network. ``Education experts tell us about the value of reading aloud to young children,'' Mrs. Bush said. ``And it's a wonderful way for parents and children to spend special time together.'' The program is a joint production of the non-profit organization Children's Literacy Initiative of Philadelphia, ABC Radio Networks and Capital Cities-ABC's Project Literacy U.S.

Blues guitarist B.B. King, opera singer Beverly Sills, painter Jasper Johns and choreographer Merce Cunningham will receive the National Medal of the Arts next week, the White House says. Actress Jessica Tandy and her husband, actor Hume Cronyn, are other winners to be honored Monday by President Bush. The medal, established in 1984, is intended to honor those who have encouraged the arts and offered inspiration to others through distinguished achievement, support or patronage.

An attorney for Rodney Dangerfield says the comedian will press on Monday with a lawsuit against Caesars Palace after negotiations over an out-of-court settlement fell apart. The lawyer, Barry Langberg, said Friday the talks ended last month when attorneys for Caesars filed court papers claiming Dangerfield was a chronic cocaine, marijuana and alcohol abuser. ``The chances of a settlement are almost nil now that Caesars has chosen to take the tack they have,'' Langberg said. The lawsuit claims gross negligence and breach of contract stemming from a March 1988 incident in which Dangerfield says he suffered eye damage after being scalded in a steamroom at the hotel. Caesars has filed a breach of contract countersuit against Dangerfield that seeks $100,000 plus punitive damages. The trial on Dangerfield's lawsuit was scheduled to begin Monday.

When ``Dallas'' begins its 13th television season this fall, family matriarch Miss Ellie will be missing, at least for a while. Actress Barbara Bel Geddes announced earlier this year she would not return as Miss Ellie, but a Lorimar Telepictures spokesman said Friday she may appear later in the season. The show's first 12 episodes will explain her absence by saying she is on a European vacation. In 1984, a heart attack kept the actress off the show for an entire season.

The Beach Boys have donated $7,000 to the Isle of Palms Volunteer Fire Department to help rebuild a fire station destroyed by Hurricane Hugo last year. Department officials had hoped to raise $50,000 during a concert with the Beach Boys, the Rivieras and The Marshall Tucker Band, but the event only netted about $1,500. The department could barely pay the Beach Boys their $75,000 minimum charge. Fire Chief Larry Britton said Thursday he received a $7,000 check from Brother Records, management for the Beach Boys. Britton also said Brother Records promised a larger check in about two weeks. He said he has no idea how much it might be.

Kitty Dukakis says she would not object to her husband running for president again. ``You know, I look at other political leaders who have said they would never do such and such,'' Mrs. Dukakis, wife of Massachusetts Gov. Michael S. Dukakis, said in an interview Friday with Barbara Walters on ABC's 20-20. ``I think it's a mistake to make those kinds of pronouncements. I don't know what's going to happen tomorrow,'' Mrs. Dukakis said. Mrs. Dukakis chronicles her problems with drug and alcohol abuse in a new book, ``Now You Know.'' She described herself as manic-depressive and said she would not have been able to handle the pressures of being first lady had Dukakis won in 1988. ``Not so long ago (I) came perilously close to becoming the first lady of the United States. I say perilously only for myself, not the country,'' Mrs. Dukakis told Walters.

DOC.HEAD: Rushdie Publisher to Issue Book That Answers `Satanic Verses'
DOC.TEXT: An Islamic scholar has written a book he says will refute ``The Satanic Verses,'' the novel that sent author Salman Rushdie into hiding to escape death at the hands of enraged Moslems. The new book is scheduled for release next April by Penguin, which also published the Rushdie novel in 1988, setting off worldwide protests, riots, diplomatic standoffs and debates on freedom of expression. The Bombay-born Rushdie, now a naturalized British citizen, has been in hiding since Feb. 14, 1989, when Iran's late leader, the Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, ordered Moslems to execute Rushdie for blasphemy. Rafiq Zakaria, a Bombay Moslem whose 70,000-word manuscript has been accepted by the London-based Penguin publishing company, said his book is to expose the ``baselessness of whatever Rushdie attributed to the prophet'' Mohammed. He described his book, ``Muhammad and the Quran,'' as ``a case for Islam.'' ``I believe that the evidence is so overwhelmingly against what Rushdie has written that the best answer is to convict him intellectually and not physically,'' Zakaria said. Moslems worldwide objected to Rushdie using the names of Mohammed's wives for prostitutes in his novel and the implication that the prophet wrote the Koran _ Islam's holy book _ instead of receiving it from God. A week after Khomeini's death edict, Bombay became the flashpoint of anti-Rushdie protests that spread to other Indian cities.
