In the following days, at least 19 people died in riots and clashes with police in India and neighboring Pakistan. India, Pakistan, Iran and several other countries banned ``The Satanic Verses.'' Later, Iran severed diplomatic ties with Britain, accusing the British government of supporting Rushdie. ``I have traced the campaign of calumny against Islam right from the birth of the prophet and culminating in Rushdie's book,'' said Zakaria. A senior editor of Penguin Books Ltd. in London said a paperback edition of ``Muhammad and the Quran'' will be published by April. The editor said, however, the book was not planned as a reaction to ``The Satanic Verses.'' ``It is an incredibly impressive study of the thinking of Islam looking at Western prejudices,'' she said, speaking on condition of anonymity. Zakaria, a 64-year-old academician and author of seven previous books, described his latest effort as ``maybe a reaction to the vituperative attacks and innuendos by Rushdie and his predecessors.'' ``I have tried to show how most of it is based on deep-rooted prejudice first between Moslems and Jews and then between Moslems and Christians,'' he said. The author attributed the ``unfortunately'' large sales of Rushdie's book to Khomeini's death threat but said he neither condemned the order nor upheld it because, ``by doing so I take a pontifical position.'' Nobody can take a pontifical position in Islam because the religion does not recognize priesthood and teaches that there is no intermediary between man and God, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Georgia Mother Says Son Was Shot in Iraq
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 4 grafs to CORRECT Mrs. Hoffman's home state to Georgia, sted Ohio, and to ADD her hometown. Pick up 5th graf, `On Thursday ...'
DOC.TEXT: A Georgia woman has identified her son as the American wounded by Iraqi troops while trying to avoid capture in Kuwait this week. The State Department refused to identify the American shot Thursday while trying to flee from his apartment in Kuwait City. Mrs. Cullen Hoffman, who would not give her first name, identified the American as her son, 33-year-old Miles Hoffman, a financial analyst and investor for the Kuwaiti government. Mrs. Hoffman, from Columbus, said she didn't know her son's condition. She said State Department officials told her Friday they were trying to get American authorities in to see him and that he was expected to be discharged soon from a hospital but will remain in Iraqi custody. On Thursday, State Department spokesman Mark Dillen said an account of the shooting was provided to a U.S. consular officer who interviewed a friend of the victim. The friend, taken into custody by the Iraqis, said the American was shot in the forearm while trying to escape through an apartment window. He was taken initially to one hospital in Kuwait and then to another. Dillen said Iraqi officials in Baghdad confirmed the injury Thursday but said it was not serious. ``They say that he will be discharged from the hospital within 24 hours, but will remain in their custody. They promise us consular access at that time,'' he said. Family members last talked to Hoffman on Aug. 4, two days after Iraqi troops invaded Kuwait. He told them he was not afraid for his life but for his job. Hoffman, engaged to marry British school teacher Nikki Murgatroyd on Aug. 17, went to work for the Kuwait government in 1987. ``He met someone at a cocktail party who told him of all these opportunities in Kuwait. Next thing I know, he's heading over there,'' Mrs. Hoffman said. ``He was home to visit us in July and he couldn't say enough nice things about Kuwait.''

DOC.HEAD: China Adopts First Copyright Law
DOC.TEXT: China has adopted its first copyright law, according to official reports today. The law was approved by the standing committee of the National People's Congress, China's legislature, when it ended an 11-day session Friday. It goes into effect June 1, 1991. The law protects an author's right to publish, sign and revise work. It guarantees the author's control of distribution and claim to royalties. The law covers literature, art, natural sciences, social sciences, engineering and technology produced in written, oral, musical, photographic, cinematographic, video or computer software format. The copyright of a work is valid during the author's lifetime and for 50 years after his death. Material banned by Chinese law is not protected.

DOC.HEAD: Rooftop Sniper Kills Self in Pittsburgh
LaserPhotos PG3,5 of Sept. 7
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of people looked on as a man shot himself in the head and tumbled from the top of a 16-story building after a standoff with police. ``All he wanted was attention,'' Police Chief Mayer DeRoy said after the gunman committed suicide Friday. ``It ended in tragedy and we're sorry about that.'' Paul Fisher, 30, shot himself after holding police at bay for 5{ hours with a rifle and a handgun from the rooftop of an apartment building near his home in the city's densely populated Oakland section, authorities said. ``This is a suicide note. I just wanted the police to kill me,'' said a message that WTAE-TV reported was found on Fisher's body. ``He said he was going to jump since we wouldn't assassinate him,'' DeRoy said. Fisher, who had a history of mental illness, fired at least 12 shots, one at an unmarked police car and 11 randomly into the air, authorities said. No one was injured by those shots. Fisher climbed on the roof of Moorehead Towers before noon with the two guns and 50 rounds of ammunition in a duffel bag, DeRoy said. After telling police he wanted a few minutes alone, he climbed to the roof's tallest parapet, dangled his feet over a ledge and smoked a cigarette. Staring into space, Fisher put a .25-caliber pistol to his head as DeRoy pleaded: ``Paul, Paul, don't pull the trigger.'' The impact of the gunshot hurtled Fisher into the air as onlookers gasped and police and medics sped to the scene. Police said they could not immediately say why Fisher committed suicide because he refused to be specific with negotiators. Pittsburgh's three network-affiliated television stations _ WTAE, WPXI and KDKA _ filmed the scene but did not broadcast their videotape because of company policies against showing suicides. In 1986, Pennsylvania Treasurer R. Budd Dwyer killed himself at a news conference he called in Harrisburg to discuss a federal indictment against him. He put a gun in his mouth and pulled the trigger, a scene that was broadcast by some Pennsylvania television stations. CNN Headline News showed footage of Fisher's last moments. ``The reason we did it is that we were covering the story when it first broke and we were continuing to tell the story,'' said Meg Andre, a supervising producer at Headline News. Today's Pittsburgh Post-Gazette had a front-page photograph of Fisher tumbling from the high-rise. The Pittsburgh Press planned to run a photograph of Fisher just after he shot himself on an inside page of today's newspaper, said Tom Birdsong, night city editor. The Associated Press transmitted two photographs, one showing Fisher falling and the other showing him holding a rifle as he stood on the building's edge.

DOC.HEAD: Most Mail Reaches U.S. Troops In 5-8 Days, Officers Say
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Despite persistent problems, U.S. officers say mail is reaching most U.S. troops in Saudi Arabia within eight days. The officers say that's a considerable improvement over the average eight to 10 days of the last few weeks, but they acknowledge smaller units still don't get mail regularly. Outgoing mail has been impeded by small problems, such as stamps sticking together in the desert heat, the officers said. The U.S. Postal Service said Friday it was sending self-adhesive stamps that don't curl and stick together. But overall, the system is working smoothly, officers said. The military on Friday lifted a 12-ounce limit on packages sent to troops in Saudi Arabia, saying there was now a sufficient postal system and airlift capability in place to handle a larger volume of mail. Air Force Maj. Michael Whitaker, commander of the main Central Command postal operation in Saudi Arabia, said the military postal service agency would notify all post offices in the United States of the change. Over the past five weeks since the U.S. began sending troops to Saudi Arabia, many soldiers have complained of poor mail service. Marines in the most forward positions appear to have more problems than the army or air force. ``There's always going to be some glitches no matter how good the system is,'' said Capt. Bradley J. Seibel, 30, of Edwardsburg, Mich. His 129th Postal Company is handling six tons of incoming mail daily and the load is ``steadily increasing.'' He said, however, that incoming mail is processed in 12 to 24 hours. On Friday, 10 clerks sorted mail at the base post office. Mailbags were stacked up, but there was nothing to suggest a huge backlog. For American civilians living in Saudi Arabia and other Persian Gulf Arab states, mail to and from the United States usually takes at least a week, more commonly 10 days or more. Seibel said the typical military unit arriving in the kingdom ``doesn't get a whole lot of mail until they've been here a couple of weeks.'' He said the army is expanding mail deliveries and will soon augment his unit with a reserve company of clerks from Athens, Ga. Marines and Air Force personnel distribute their own mail after picking it up at an airbase. Postal officers said the Saudis were helping with mail processing and were considering a U.S. request that they work on what would normally be their days off including Friday, the Moslem sabbath. All packages are opened by Saudi customs officers who look for contraband, including alcohol, tobacco, pornography and religious items such as crucifixes and the New Testament. Under Saudi law, pornography includes any magazine with pictures of scantily clad women, including mail order catalogues. Siebel said he knew of only one case of a soldier facing discipline for smuggling liquor, after his wife sent a package containing two bottles of whiskey and one of vodka.

DOC.HEAD: Revealing Statue Pulled From Art Show
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Note contents in 3rd graf.
DOC.TEXT: A statue of a partially nude woman was removed from a sculpture exhibit in the same city where rappers 2 Live Crew were arrested on obscenity charges. The 42-piece exhibit that opened Thursday at the Art and Culture Center did so without a life-size statue called Ms. America. The statue's exposed nipples are pierced with hoops held together by a gold chain and the torso is covered with colorful tattoos. After consulting with Mayor Sal Oliveri, center Director Wendy Blazier decided this week to pull the statue from the show, Oliveri said. The mayor said Blazier, a city employee, told him she was concerned the sculpture would offend someone. Oliveri, who has had no qualms about criticizing art and music in Hollywood, said he never implied to Blazier that Ms. America be banned from the exhibit, which features the work of Florida artists. ``She showed me the statue and asked me if I thought it was offensive,'' Oliveri said. ``I told her that it was being displayed in the right place, an arts center. I just told her I didn't think children should see it, but I never meant for her to pull it from the exhibit.'' In June, Oliveri suggested 2 Live Crew not be allowed to perform its racy lyrics at a downtown nightclub. The concert did go on and the Miami rap group was arrested for performing songs from their million-selling album ``As Nasty As They Wanna Be,'' which a federal judge ruled obscene. Oliveri said he did not know why Blazier even sought his opinion on the statue, created by Sarasota artist Jack Down. But he said he suspected it was because last month he suggested that a motel owner alter a roadside mural showing the bare backsides of a man and a woman. Oliveri said he wanted to promote a family-style image for the city and that the mural did not fit with that image. Blazier would not comment.

DOC.HEAD: Current Quotations
DOC.TEXT: ``Paul, Paul, don't pull the trigger.'' _ Pittsburgh Police Chief Mayer DeRoy, urging a sniper not to kill himself before the sniper pulled the trigger and hurtled 16 floors.

``He was home to visit us in July and he couldn't say enough nice things about Kuwait.'' _ Mrs. Cullen Hoffman, who identified her son, Miles Hoffman, as the American wounded by Iraqi troops while trying to avoid capture in Kuwait City.

``They're not career criminals, just kids who basically decided that they wanted the plate ... so they'd have some part of White Sox park for their unborn grandchildren.'' _ Police officer Sharon Gaynor, after two young men tried to steal home plate from Chicago's Comiskey Park.

DOC.HEAD: CALCUTTA: as saying.
DOC.TEXT: Pleading old age and ill health, Mother Teresa had said she was stepping down as head of her order two weeks after her 80th birthday and a year after she suffered a near-fatal heart attack. Pope John Paul II, who had rejected her earlier pleas to step aside, accepted her resignation last March. More than 100 nuns were to cast secret ballots today at the Kennedy Center for retarded women and children in Calcutta, where the Yugoslavian-born Mother Teresa founded the order in the late 1940s.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: CALCUTTA: late 1940s.
DOC.TEXT: The Missionaries of Charity grew from Mother Teresa's calling 43 years ago to leave convent teaching and plunge into Calcutta's most impoverished sections. She became known as ``the saint of the gutters.'' The simplicity of her religious life was often contrasted against the complexity of world events and controversial issues. In 1982, she helped evacuate mentally retarded children from Beirut, Lebanon, during the height of battles between Israeli troops and the Palestine Liberation Organization. Her order has also stressed Vatican-approved natural family planning methods despite the severe overpopulation in India and other nations. Mother Teresa has been Pope John Paul II's ambassador against abortion but led most other church groups by opening centers for AIDS victims. She won the Nobel Peace Prize in 1979. Mother Teresa suffered a serious heart attack in September 1989 and received a pacemaker in December.

DOC.HEAD: Americans Airlifted Out of Kuwait Describe Ordeal
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The 165 Americans who stepped off a plane from Kuwait leaving behind possessions and lives have brought harrowing tales of life under Iraqi occupation of the oil-rich emirate. U.S. Officials said the former detainees, who arrived in the Jordanian capital aboard a U.S.-chartered Iraqi Airways jet, would probably be flown to Charleston, S.C., today. It was the first U.S.-arranged flight from Kuwait, which was overrun by Iraq on Aug. 2. Most aboard were women and children, but there were some Arab-American husbands and a few other men. Elena Reyes of Los Angeles described the last five weeks in Kuwait as ``terrifying.'' ``I didn't know night and day when they would come and knock down my door,'' she said. Reyes said she felt ``relieved but still worried. You left part of your life back there.'' Another American woman, Patricia Hammer, originally from Denver, described her foiled desert escape, a frantic house-to-house search for safety, and the pain of leaving her children behind. And Mary Willett, 35, of Chicago, said of the situation in Kuwait: ``It's a disaster.'' The flight stopped over in Baghdad, where passengers obtained exit permits from Iraqi authorities before leaving for Amman. On arrival, the Americans were taken to the airport hotel to wait for the flight home. State Department spokesman Mark Dillen put the number of Americans on the flight at 165 and said there were a few other foreigners on board. Many in the group seemed overwhelmed by their experience, eager to talk even if they did not give their full names. Maureen Aldakheel of St. Louis, asked what advice she would give President Bush, replied: ``Go for it. Do something. People are tired of waiting for something to happen.'' ``People are very tired of waiting every day, hoping for news of some military strike,'' said Mrs. Aldakheel, who lived in Kuwait for 11 years and left her husband behind. ``I don't want war, but it's inevitable,'' said Sandra Williams, who said she was from Ohio but gave no city. ``You're dealing with a madman.'' The Americans in the group were among the first airlifted from Kuwait. A handful of U.S. citizens in Kuwait were flown on an Iraqi Airways flight to Baghdad last week, escorted by civil rights leader Jesse Jackson. Most other foreign evacuees have had to cross the desert to Baghdad to catch flights out. Mrs. Hammer described the fear-filled days that followed the invasion. At first, Iraqi jets streaked over rooftops to frighten the population, she said. Later, patrols and roadblocks had people cowering behind locked doors. ``People are now terrified, hiding, and they don't know what to do next,'' she said. After the invasion, she joined a jeep caravan to try a run for it across open desert to Saudi Arabia. ``Iraqis shot at us, and then our escorts abandoned us in the desert,'' Mrs. Hammer said. ``Then some Bedouins saved our lives and got us back to Kuwait.'' Her Kuwaiti landlord brought food until word went out that Arabs would be executed for helping foreigners. She found another place to hide with other Americans. Finally, the flight was arranged. ``This morning, I dressed up in a black veil like an Iranian Shiite woman and made my way to the pickup point,'' she said. Mrs. Hammer, who spent eight years in Kuwait, had to leave behind her two children, Alia, 14, and Issa, 9. She said she just divorced her Kuwaiti husband, and he refused to let them go. ``Now that it's over, I don't know what I will do. I left everything. I left my children, my money.'' She stopped. ``How can I put those two in the same sentence?'' Her strength faded, and tears softened her eye makeup. ``I have nothing left, nothing at all.''

DOC.HEAD: Typhoon Dot Kills Three in Taiwan, Four in Philippines
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to add dead in the Philippines, Dot downgraded to tropical storm; No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Typhoon Dot was downgraded to a tropical storm today after battering Taiwan and the Philippines and leaving at least seven people dead in the two nations, authorities said. Four people were missing in northern and eastern Taiwan, police said. One man was swept out to sea when fishing, while a woman and two men were washed away by flooded creeks, they said. On Friday, police said that in Taipei two 9-year-old girls drowned while playing in flooded ponds, and a man died after being struck by falling objects. In the Philippines, the National Red Cross said today four people drowned in flooding caused by Typhoon Dot. The Central Weather Bureau said Dot's maximum winds of 105 mph had weakened overnight to 60 mph. A typhoon's winds are at least 74 mph. This afternoon, the storm was located 72 miles west of Taiwan, moving northwest at 12 mph. It was expected to leave Taiwan by this evening for China's southern Fujian province. Police in Hualien, 110 miles southeast of Taipei, said huge waves smashed through a dike protecting a seaside village, but 50 people were rescued unharmed. There were no immediate reports of injuries. Landslides disrupted train and highway traffic in eastern Taiwan, and wide power outages affected 850,000 households in the northern and eastern areas of the island, officials said. Most domestic flights were canceled and several international flights were delayed, officials said. In the Philippines, the Red Cross said three of the drownings occurred in Luzon's Abra province and the other in Pangasinan province. More than 15,000 fled their homes in Manila and other cities on Luzon island because of flooding caused by Dot, the group said. Dot hit the Philippines late Thursday before swinging toward Taiwan.

DOC.HEAD: Two-Thirds of Donated Blood Found AIDS Positive
DOC.TEXT: Two-thirds of all donations to Uganda's main blood bank have been rejected after testing positive to the AIDS virus, a government newspaper reported today. New Vision quoted Dr. John Watson Williams, the blood bank's manager, as saying about 11,700 pints of the 17,800 pints of blood donated since the facility opened in May carried the virus that causes the deadly acquired immune deficiency syndrome. In a recent report, Uganda's AIDS Control Program said nearly 1 million people in the East African nation of 15 million carry the AIDS virus.

DOC.HEAD: Persian Gulf Crisis At-A-Glance
DOC.TEXT:
Here, at a glance, are the latest developments in the Persian Gulf crisis:
President Bush arrived in Helsinki, Finland, today for a day-long meeting on Sunday with Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev to discuss the Mideast crisis and other issues. On Friday, Soviet Foreign Ministry spokesman Gennady Gerasimov said his country would be willing to send military forces to the Middle East under a committee that included officers from the five permanent members of the U.N. Security Council.

More Americans were scheduled to leave Kuwait today, a day after the government of Iraqi President Saddam Hussein allowed 165 others to leave. Iraq has freed few male hostages, many of whom are placed at key installations as human shields to guard against potential attack by U.S.-led forces.

U.S. forces gained more momentum today when five amphibious landing craft passed through Egypt's Suez Canal toward the gulf region, bringing the total number since Monday to 12. About 100,000 U.S. troops are dug into the Saudi desert south of the Kuwaiti border.

Kuwait's government-in-exile told Secretary of State James A. Baker III on Friday it would help bankroll the U.S. military effort. A day earlier, Saudi Arabia had pledged several billion dollars toward defraying the cost of the U.S. deployment, which is centered in the oil-rich kingdom.

A few foreign embassies _ including the U.S. mission _ were still defying a 2-week-old Iraqi order to shut their doors in Kuwait. But without power, water, telephone service or food, the diplomats were being forced to retreat. Norway said it planned to evacuate its embassy today.

James N. Purcell, director of the U.N. International Organization for Migration, appealed urgently for ships and aircraft to repatriate Asians refugees in hot and dirty camps in Jordan. The United States said it will dispatch 27,000 tons of rice, vegetable oil and wheat flour worth $12 million.

DOC.HEAD: Neighbors, Congregation Rally Around Family of Slain Tourist
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Funeral scheduled for 1 p.m. EDT.
DOC.TEXT: When word reached Provo that one of their own, Brian Watkins, was stabbed to death in a New York subway station trying to defend his mother, the family's Mormon neighbors pitched in to ease the grief. Women of the church's Relief Society prepared casseroles, lasagna, shepherd's pie, rolls and chicken soup. They cleaned the family's house, helped pick out funeral-going clothes and did other chores. ``The first thing I do is cry a little,'' neighbor and society president Margie Holmes said Friday, the day eight young men were indicted in New York on murder and robbery charges in the case. ``And then I remind myself that somehow we'll get through it all,'' she said. Watkins was to be buried today in Provo. He was 22, a tennis buff. He went to New York with his parents, Karen and Sherman Watkins, and other relatives for the U.S. Open as they had for many years. The eight men were accused of killing Watkins last Sunday after robbing his father of $200 and credit cards. Police said the gang wanted the money to pay the cover fee to a dance hall. They were ordered jailed pending a Sept. 24 bond hearing. Manhattan District Attorney Robert Morgenthau said he promised Watkins' father that the eight defendants would not be offered plea bargains. Seven of the defendants made incriminating videotaped statements after their arrests, Morgenthau said. Two others were still being sought in Watkins' slaying, he said. The Watkins family returned to Provo on Wednesday after testifying in New York before a grand jury. For the 100 or so families that live in the Watkins' neighborhood, the congregation is a nucleus of worship and friendship in a faith that prizes industrious self-reliance. The Watkins' pain is all too familiar to Mrs. Holmes. Four years ago she lost her 18-year-old son, also named Brian, to a drug overdose. ``People were doing this for me. I can't tell you how much it helped me make it through that time,'' Mrs. Holmes said. ``There was such an outpouring of love for our family.'' Karen Watkins said the family will visit New York again. ``Probably not for a while, but the people in New York, the majority of the people in New York, responded very well to us, very compassionately, and just opened their arms to us with anything they could give us,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: On-The-Lam Trotter Temporarily Halts Military Aircraft
DOC.TEXT: A trotter horse that escaped from a keeper galloped through a National Guard training base, where he took on military aircraft and won _ at least temporarily. Shayne Gregory was out with the horse, Star O Cathy, for a workout Friday at Los Alamitos race track when the animal threw her and shook off the training cart, track spokesman Don Escalante said. The horse trotted over to an adjacent golf course, then took off down a street and later a busy boulevard. After running through traffic, Star O Cathy sped through the guard gate at Los Alamitos Armed Forces Reserve Center and onto the base's main aircraft runway. Star O Cathy's presence on the runway temporarily halted air operations at the base, where air traffic has been heavy since the U.S. deployment of troops to the Middle East began last month. First, the horse stood in the way of a C-5 transport plane awaiting takeoff. Then he delayed the landings of two helicopters. Finally, track officials, with a horse van in tow, caught up with the spirited steed and base operations returned to normal, Escalante said. Base officials could not be reached for comment late Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Says He's Not Seeking Soviet Troops for Saudi Arabia
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Subs graf 3, bgng 'Bush arriving, to CORRECT Tuesday to Sunday
DOC.TEXT: President Bush arrived in this Finnish capital today with words of warm praise for Finland's stand ``with the forces of peace'' arrayed against Saddam Hussein's Iraq. Bush and his wife Barbara received a red-carpet welcome from Finnish President Mauno Koivisto and his wife Tellervo after arriving at Helsinki International Airport on the first overseas flight aboard the new Air Force One, a gleaming jumbo jet. Bush, arriving several hours ahead of Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev in advance of their summit together Sunday, praised Helsinki's past role as a meeting-place for peace-seekers. At a time of crisis in the Persian Gulf, Bush said, ``Much is at stake and there is much the world stands to gain if we succeed.'' ``The city of Helsinki has often been a meeting place for nations seeking to advance the cause of peace. My thanks to the people of Finland first for hosting this meeting and for setting an example for all the world in your resolute commitment to liberty and independence,'' Bush said. He thanked Finland for ``its staunch support'' in the United Nations Security Council for the economic straitjacket imposed upon Iraq for its occupation of Kuwait. ``Today at this time of challenge, Finland once again stands with the forces of peace,'' said the president. Earlier, Bush said he had no plans to ask Gorbachev to send ground forces to Saudi Arabia but expects talks on ``a wide array of cooperative arrangements'' when they meet Sunday. Speaking to reporters accompanying him aboard Air Force One, Bush said he was interested in trading U.S. oil technology for oil from the Soviet Union and that an oil deal ``could well come up at these meetings.'' ``I think it's something that we can work closely with the Soviet Union,'' he said. The president also said he wants to visit U.S. troops deployed in Saudi Arabia, but ``Not now.'' ``Eventually I want very much to do it, but I may wait for a while until all our forces are there and things calm down and (the troops) get settled in,'' Bush said. ``I very much want to do it, but I have no schedule or plans, no set plans.'' Bush also said he has no plans to ask for Soviet ground forces to serve with U.S. troops deployed in Saudi Arabia. ``I have no plans to do that, but I will be talking about a wide array of cooperative arrangements,'' the president replied. Soviet Foreign Ministry spokesman Gennady Gerasimov said earlier in the day that the Soviet Union would be willing to send military forces to the Middle East under a military staff committee that included officers from the five permanent members of the U.N. Security Council. Asked about trading technology for oil with the Soviets, Bush said: ``I'm all for that. I've already told Mr. Gorbachev that. That came up when he was here. '' The president said he would ``welcome the best in American ... drilling, production and seismic work going to the Soviet Union.'' He noted that some U.S. companies, including Chevron and Texaco Corp., have reached preliminary agreements on joint oil exploratory ventures with the Soviets. A group of U.S. oil executives were traveling to the Soviet Union this weekend at the behest of Bush and planned to share new technology that might immediately boost Soviet oil production. Just before leaving, Bush signed an order releasing $10 million from U.S. emergency funds to aid refugees in Jordan and other Middle East countries, spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said. Administration officials said that the summit was designed as an informal session for consultation and was unlikely to produce any major announcements or new initiatives. The new Air Force One, a modified Boeing 747 jetliner, took a little more than eight hours to complete the transatlantic trip. Bush first flew in the plane Thursday. After arriving, Bush and his wife drove to Finland's presidential palace for lunch with President and Mrs. Koivisto. Then, Bush was to make a short stop at the U.S. Embassy to speak with American diplomats before checking into government guest quarters at the Kalastajatorppa Hotel. Bush will return to Washington Sunday evening after his sessions with Gorbachev. He will address a joint session of Congress Tuesday night on the Middle East situation and on the summit.

DOC.HEAD: Finnish President Opposes Increases Military Strength in Gulf
DOC.TEXT: Finnish President Mauno Koivisto says the United Nations economic sanctions against Iraq are ``extremely effective'' and the West should refrain from any further military build-up in the Persian Gulf. The Finnish host of the U.S.-Soviet summit made the remarks in an interview published today in Finland's leading daily newspaper, Helsingin Sanomat. ``In my view it seems that the sanctions are extremely effective,'' Koivisto said. ``Those who like to believe that they aren't working are yearning in the direction of taking other quick action,'' said Koivisto, referring to military action. He said he objected to sending more military forces to the region. ``It's possible that they could cause more confusion and mix-up than usefulness ... when small ships sail to and fro over there,'' Koivisto said. Koivisto was interviewed before he greeted Bush, the first to arrive for Sunday's sudden summit. Bush warmly praised Finland for standing ``with the forces of peace'' in backing the U.N. sanctions against Iraq. Finland, a Security Council member, heads the U.N. committee on sanctions against Iraq. Koivisto said there should be no deal with Iraq to secure the hostages' release or anything else. He reiterated Finland's support for the U.N. position that Iraq must release all the hostages and withdraw from Kuwait unconditionally. ``One cannot always reconcile, and one shouldn't always (try to) do so. There is a time and place for reconciliation,'' said Koivisto, who in the past week has taken an unusual step for a Finnish president by speaking out strongly against Iraq's policies.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Clears Way for Chemical Weapons Shipment to Johnston Atoll
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge has rejected a challenge from Greenpeace USA and cleared the way for the Army to ship chemical weapons from West Germany for destruction at a remote outpost in the Pacific. Greenpeace sought a temporary restraining order, contending the move and incineration at Johnston Atoll posed an environmental and human threat. The Army already has begun moving the weapons from a storage site at Clausen, West Germany, to Johnston Atoll, 800 miles southwest of Honolulu. Government attorneys had said Johnston Atoll is the safest location for the weapons. They said every precaution has been taken to ensure the safety of the shipment to the new Johnston Atoll Chemical Agent Disposal System, or JACADS. Greenpeace attorney Skip Spaulding contended the Army violated the National Environmental Policy Act by not filing an environmental impact statement covering the movement of the weapons within West Germany. The Army said it prepared such a statement on the ocean portion of the weapons' journey to Johnston. That report was classified. President Bush had assured the West German government the weapons would be removed by the end of the year. Congress required all U.S. chemical weapons be destroyed by 1997. The disposal facility at Johnston resembles a factory or power plant. It covers several acres on the coral atoll that is barely large enough to accommodate its airport.

DOC.HEAD: Pageant Contestants Get Respite for Bert Parks' Return
LaserPhoto XACC5 of Sept. 7
DOC.TEXT: The 50 contestants in the Miss America Pageant got a brief respite from hours of rehearsals while attention focused on the return of Bert Parks. Parks, who looked tanned and fit, was restored to grace Friday. ``I feel that this could be a vindication,'' the 75-year-old Parks told reporters. Pageant officials axed Parks in 1980, saying he was too old to keep up with the pageant's new image. The firing set off a nationwide letter-writing campaign and Parks said it catapulted his career. Tonight, Parks was to serenade former Miss Americas with his trademark ``There She Is.'' Co-host Gary Collins was to sing the song to the newly crowned Miss America. At a news conference, Parks sang the first few words of ``There She Is,'' but said America would have to wait until the finals to hear the rest. To commemorate the crooner's return, Parks was named grand marshal of Friday night's Miss America parade on the Boardwalk. The city renamed Park Place to ``Bert Parks Place'' for the weekend. Fans of Parks attracted by a throng of reporters came to watch the unveiling of the green and white street sign one block off the Boardwalk. ``If you're not singing, I'm not watching,'' one woman shouted. Parks blew kisses and mugged for photographers as he led the waving contestants, floats, cars and marching bands down the four-mile parade route. In a pageant tradition, the contestants, perched atop convertibles, revealed their legs to cheering spectators who screamed: ``Show us your shoes.'' Miss Hawaii Cheryl Akemi Toma didn't raise her legs, but held up a beach thong to the cheering crowd. Fans shouted ``Welcome back'' and ``Glad to have you back'' as Parks passed by. Only a group of Vietnam veterans carrying American flags drew more applause. The 50 Miss America hopefuls are divided into three groups, competing in talent, swimsuit and evening gown divisions on three successive nights to qualify for the finals. Thursday was the last of three preliminary competitions in the events. The winner of the evening gown competition is kept secret to heighten the suspense for the finals. Miss Texas Suzanne Lawrence won the first talent competition and Miss Colorado Karrie Mitchell the first swimsuit competition in the Tuesday night preliminary. Miss North Carolina Scarlet Morgan won the second talent competition and Miss Florida Dana Rinehart Dalton won the second swimsuit competition in the Wednesday night preliminary. Miss Illinois Marjorie Judith Vincent won the last talent competition and Miss Mississippi Beth Howell the last swimsuit competitions in the Thursday night preliminaries.

DOC.HEAD: Cloudy in the Midwest, Haze and Fog in the East and South
DOC.TEXT: Clouds dotted the Midwest early today and rain fell in Iowa. Most of the East and South had haze and fog. The summer heat was expected to break in the Northeast, with a high pressure system bringing sunny skies, low humidity and temperatures in the 70s and 80s. A thin band of showers and thundershowers formed from Oklahoma to North Carolina. Hot weather was forecast for the South, with highs in the 90s. Thunderstorms were possible in Florida. The Plains and much of the West were in store for sunny skies and sizzling temperatures, with the highs mostly in the 90s but in the 100s in Texas, Southern California and Arizona. The nation's high Friday in the Lower 48 states was 113 degrees in Borrego Springs, Calif., and Palm Springs, Calif. DOC.HEAD: Newspaper: Slaying Suspect Names Killer
DOC.TEXT: A suspect in the slaying of five college students told police he knew who killed two of the victims and provided a name believed to be one of his multiple personalities, a newspaper reported today. The Florida Times-Union in Jacksonville cited sources it did not identify in today's story about Edward Lewis Humphrey. According to another newspaper report, Humphrey's statements to police may be challenged because prosecutors stretched the law to keep defense attorneys away from him after he was arrested Aug. 30 in an attack on his grandmother. Humphrey, 18, has not been charged in the slayings. Humphrey is one of eight suspects in the killings by a man police said preyed on petite brunettes. One of four women slain was decapitated and three of the bodies were mutilated. The victims included one man. Humphrey said he knew who killed the first two, Christina Powell, 17, and Sonja Larson, 18, the Jackonsville newspaper said. The Times-Union did not print the name Humphrey used, but during a bond hearing Thursday, a jail guard testified Humphrey referred to himself as ``John'' and exhibited bizarre behavior. Humphrey's lawyer, public defender J.R. Russo, said he was unaware of any such statements by his client. ``It's news to me,'' he told The Associated Press. But Russo noted that police had grilled his client without attorneys present. ``They also questioned him before we were appointed to the case,'' he said. Authorities have refused to discuss publicly what Humphrey has said. Russo said he believes investigators and prosecutors manipulated the system to deny Humphrey the benefit of a lawyer soon after his arrest. A judge could rule inadmissible any evidence gathered that afternoon, which could include vital statements about Humphrey's last week in Gainesville, he said. Despite an intense focus on Humphrey, a University of Florida freshman, investigators elsewhere in the Southeast checked unsolved stabbing deaths of other young women for similarities. Police cautioned Friday that they don't expect immediate results. Investigators provided no details about what they gathered in searches of Humphrey's Gainesville apartment, car and his grandmother's home in Indialantic, a coastal city about 180 miles southeast of Gainesville. ``We did not leave empty-handed,'' Darnell said. Agents also obtained a personal search warrant for Humphrey that could yield evidence on bodily fluids, fingerprints and hair. The Times-Union reported investigators found pubic hairs resembling Humphrey's, but said the hairs were not conclusive evidence. New charges of aggravated assault were filed against Humphrey as a result of a confrontation the night before the first two bodies were discovered. Students Greg Herskowitz and Rob Lipvak, both 18, claim Humphrey threatened them with a knife at the Pi Lambda Phi fraternity house Aug. 25. Humphrey also faces charges in Indian River County of armed burglary and attempted sexual battery two years ago. Police disclosed for the first time Friday that Manuel Taboada, the only man killed by the serial slayer, was asleep in bed when he was slain. ``He was apparently surprised by his attacker,'' Ms. Darnell said.

DOC.HEAD: Woman Apparently Infected With AIDS During Tooth Extraction Plans Lawsuit
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf, `The national...', to CORRECT month of CDC report to July sted last month.
DOC.TEXT: A woman who apparently contracted AIDS during a tooth extraction says her dentist's death from the disease will not stop her plans to file a lawsuit. Kimberly Bergalis spoke out Friday for the first time and pleaded for tighter controls on the health care industry. The national Centers for Disease Control in Atlanta reported in July that the case marked the first time a health professional had passed AIDS to a patient. ``I had a lot of crazy thoughts, like maybe I was at the beach and I stepped on a hypodermic needle,'' Ms. Bergalis said. ``You just go insane with thought.'' The 22-year-old woman from Fort Pierce said she plans to sue the estate of the dentist, David J. Acer of Stuart, and her insurance company. ``If I can protect other people from what happened to me, then I have to do it,'' Ms. Bergalis said. Documents filed in state court in Palm Beach described her as being in the advanced stages of acquired immune deficiency syndrome. Her wisdom teeth were pulled by Acer in 1987. Acer died Monday, but his death was not made public by his family until Friday. Investigators from the Centers for Disease Control interviewed Ms. Bergalis three times to determine where she contracted the disease. ``When I was visited by the CDC we kept going over certain things,'' she said. ``I said, `What about the dentist?' because there was a rumor at the time that he had AIDS. They said they were not investigating that. I never heard from them again.'' CDC officials in Atlanta refused to comment, citing confidentiality rules. The family of Acer, 40, decided not to immediately disclose his death so relatives could ``privately grieve,'' said lawyer Deborah Sawyer. On Tuesday, the state Health Department released a letter dated Aug. 31 that Acer wrote to former patients urging them to be tested for AIDS. Acer said in the letter that he had followed CDC safety guidelines, including consulting his doctor before continuing his practice and wearing gloves and a mask while treating patients. He said he doubted he was the source of Ms. Bergalis' infection. ``I am a gentle man, and I would never intentionally expose anyone to this disease,'' he wrote. The letter did not say how long Acer practiced after being diagnosed with AIDS. Ms. Bergalis' lawyer, Robert Montgomery, said he planned to sue Acer's estate and CIGNA Dental Health of Florida on Ms. Bergalis' behalf. He did not say when the lawsuit would be filed. CIGNA referred Ms. Bergalis to Acer, who treated about 370 patients belonging to the dental plan. Ms. Bergalis said she was stunned when she was told in December 1989 that she was HIV positive, which meant she had been exposed to the virus. The illness forced her to withdraw at the time from the University of Florida. Her legal consultant, cardiologist Dr. Sanford Kuvin, said she had no known risk factors. ``There weren't any other areas of my life that could have exposed me to this as far as dating and friends,'' Ms. Bergalis said. ``I was in shock. I was in deep shock.''

DOC.HEAD: Mother Teresa Gives up Retirement Plans After Nuns Re-Elect Her
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS to UPDATE thruout with approval by Vatican; EDITS to conform. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Mother Teresa, the frail and aging Nobel Peace Prize winner, gave up her retirement plans today when nuns from around the world re-elected her to head their order, a church official said. ``If this is God's will, I will serve in the capacity in the best way possible,'' the 80-year-old nun was quoted by Monsignor Francis Gomes as saying. He supervised the election. The Vatican gave its blessing and approval today to keeping Mother Teresa as head of the order she founded in the late 1940s. In March, Pope John Paul II bowed to Mother Teresa's wish to retire and accepted her resignation. He had rejected her earlier requests to step aside, even though she pleaded old age and ill health. The ballots were cast by 103 delegates representing the Missionaries of Charity around the world. The vote came after eight days of religious instruction, reflection and devotions conducted behind the walls of the Kennedy Center, a home for retarded women and children near Calcutta's Dum Dum Airport. The nun, known as the ``saint of the gutters'' for her work with the destitute and dying, suffered a nearly fatal heart attack a year ago. Sister Priscilla Lewis, spokeswoman for the order, said Mother Teresa's agreement to stay on was ``greeted with great joy and clapping.'' Gomes, who announced the result after a three-hour meeting, said the nuns felt that ``with so much opening up in the Western world and in the Eastern Europe they need someone who can face the challenges.'' Until the balloting outcome was announced, Mother Teresa had not changed her mind about stepping down, Gomes said. After the result was announced, Gomes walked to the center's front gate to give the news to a small group of reporters. Mother Teresa's re-election settles, for the moment, one of the biggest questions facing the Missionaries of Charity: who besides Mother Teresa has the worldwide recognition, coupled with the indefatigable determination and charisma, to open the political and financial doors needed to accomplish their work? At the height of the Israeli siege of West Beirut in 1982, she walked between the guns of the Israeli army and the Palestine Liberation Organization to rescue children trapped without food and medicine in a front-line hospital. The shooting stopped until her rescue mission was completed. Pulling herself from her sickbed only a few months after suffering a heart attack in September 1989, Mother Teresa headed for Moscow and Eastern Europe to open new missions. Her ministry to the poor and helpless began in earnest 43 years ago in the gutters of Calcutta. She gave up a comfortable teaching job at a Roman Catholic school to succor those whom no one else would touch. Rescuing dying people from the streets of the teeming metropolis, Mother Teresa went on to found a series of homes in Calcutta and eventually throughout the world for society's castaways. Today, the Missionaries of Charity operate 430 homes in 95 countries for lepers, cripples, abandoned babies and others with no place to turn. The order has about 3,000 nuns. She was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize in 1979. Mother Teresa was born in Skopje, Yugoslavia, daughter of an Albanian contractor.

DOC.HEAD: Clark Candy Line to Go Up for Sale
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS lead to CORRECT billion to million.
DOC.TEXT: An Illinois company is putting the Clark candy line up for sale and shutting down a plant it opened five years ago with help from $4.9 million in low-interest loans. Leaf Inc. made Clark and Zagnut candy bars at the plant. Production of the Zagnut will be moved to a Centralia, Ill., factory, company officials said Friday. The plant closing in suburban Pittsburgh by late 1991 will idle 170 workers. Clark is going up for sale after marketing efforts and capital investment failed to make the candy ``a national brand,'' said Jim Grubiak, Leaf's senior vice president. ``Unfortunately, Clark just didn't make the cut,'' he said. Five years ago, Allegheny County and its Industrial Development Authority persuaded Leaf to open the plant to replace an old one and arranged for the low-interest loans. The old plant, in Pittsburgh, was shut down.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Captivates Finnish Crowd at Marketplace
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout with color from Bush arrival
DOC.TEXT: President Bush created a friendly frenzy with an impromptu stop today in a Finnish marketplace where he strolled out of his armored limousine and shook hands with the crowd. Bush, the first to arrive for Sunday's superpower summit with Mikhail Gorbachev, said he just wanted to say ``hello'' to a few people and ``then I've got to get to work.'' As helicopters whirled above his motorcade, the friendly Finns shoved to get a better view of the 6-foot-2 American president. Some clambered atop chairs and stall tables. The scene unfolded in a vegetable and fish market in front of the Presidential Palace, where Sunday's summit with the Soviet leader will unfold. ``It's great they've come here,'' said a teenage girl named Sari, balancing against her two school friends on a market bench. Preparations in the Finnish capital have been frantic since last weekend when Bush and Gorbachev announced their snap summit to discuss the gulf crisis and other issues. A Royal Danish Orchestra concert got bumped from Finlandia Hall, commandeered as an international press center for the 3,000 journalists covering the summit. Gorbachev and Bush planned to hold a joint news conference there Sunday evening. Streets were barricaded, tram stops were shifted and shopkeepers moved in to cash in on the foreigners pouring in for the weekend, including 750 American and Soviet officials. Shops, usually closed on Sundays, were given special special permission to open on the sabbath. More than 20 large blue buses were parked across city streets to block traffic around the palace ``and act as cover,'' said a security policeman. Paramilitary snipers perched on the rooftop across from the palace and scanned the waterfront with binoculars. Police blocked off the entire Katajanokka peninsula, a residential area where a prison and harbor facilities are located. Ferries to Sweden were delayed because passengers would have to drive past the Presidential Palace while Gorbachev was having dinner with President Mauno Koivisto. T-shirts with pictures of Bush and Gorbachev above the face of Iraqi President Saddam Hussein were fetching $20. Above Saddam's picture were the words: ``I love babies and cemicals'' (sic). Underneath the two superpower leaders were the words, ``Peace of world in Helsinki.'' ``Of course, it's great that the presidents are coming,'' said Merja, a schoolgirl out watching the city get ready. ``After all, we here in the north are so cut off from the rest of the world that it will be good that we can be at the center of world attention for a short while.'' Businesses expect the journalists alone to spend about 2 million marks every day _ about $270 each _ during their speedy stay. But Matti Kohva from the Finnfacts Institute said Finns could make more than money. ``Above all, Finnish businessmen will benefit from the fact that Helsinki's name will be seen abroad,'' Kohva said. ``The (summit) participants will pay for their own expenses,'' said Foreign Ministry spokesman Petri Tuomi-Nikula. ``All we have to do is to cover the cost of the extra arrangements.'' That, he said, could come to about $1 million. The foreign ministry hired all-black limousines and all-black taxis to ferry visitors and police were called off vacation and weekend leave.

DOC.HEAD: Hard, Hungry Days Face Those Stranded in Jordan
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS thruout to UPDATE with Indian, Sri Lankan repatriation efforts; MINOR EDITING. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: India and Sri Lanka today intensified efforts to bring their citizens home from Jordan, but tens of thousands of Asian and Arab refugees from Iraq and Kuwait remained stranded. A Jordanian border official said 225,000 Egyptians were stranded in a huge camp just inside the Iraqi border. He said Jordan was withholding permission for them to cross because of the overcrowding at refugees camps. Jordan's meager resources are inadequate to provide food, shelter and transportation for the 100,000 refugees stranded in camps along its desert border. The flood of evacuees began five weeks ago following Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. An airlift operation for the Indians got under way today as a planeload of refugees from Amman, Jordan, landed in Dubai. They were to be flown back to India aboard Indian Air Force Ilyushin 76 transports. Indian Air Force planes have not been given permission to fly directly to Amman, but Dubai is allowing them to use its international airport as a transit point to Bombay. The new operation will allow India to take refugees from Amman at a much faster pace than over the past week. In Sri Lanka, officials are appealing for food donations for Sri Lankan refugees in Jordan. The food will be flown to Amman on passenger jets that are now returning home empty after refugee airlifts, a Royal Jordanian Airline official in Colombo said. The 185-seat Airbus jets, chartered by the International Organization for Migration, have been arriving at a rate of one or two a day for the past week, the airline official said, speaking on condition of anonymity. Relief officials have warned of unsanitary conditions at the makeshift desert camps, and on Friday one said the refugee problem could turn into a disaster. The government and aid workers have appealed for international help to feed and transport home the evacuees from Iraq and Kuwait _ many of whom left all their possessions and money behind. They fled after Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion and subsequent annexation of its oil-rich neighbor. But on Friday, a shipment of four tons of canned beef from the Netherlands was sent to laboratories for testing after tons of cookies, powdered milk and dates sent to hungry refugees were deemed unfit for human consumption. The worthless food was only the latest problem confronting international aid workers trying to ease the misery of 45,000 Asian refugees packed into the Shaalan I camp near the Ruweishid border post. The Jordanian border official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the stranded Egyptians ``are waiting under terrible conditions for permission to cross into Jordan to continue their journey home.'' ``But we cannot cope with such huge numbers before the Asian evacuees already inside Jordan waiting for transportation to their homes are shifted,'' he said. He said 18,325 evacuees crossed through the border post on Friday. James N. Purcell, director of the International Organization for Migration, appealed for ships and aircraft to repatriate Asians in hot and dirty camps ``before human suffering becomes a human tragedy.'' Fights have broken out at the Shaalan I camp, where refugees scramble and jostle under hot sun for a meager daily ration of a piece of bread, a tomato and a cucumber provided by the government. Little outside aid has reached them. Red Cross officials and others say some refugees have gone for up to three days with little water, food or shelter. Most of the refugees at the Shaalan I camp are Bangladeshi, Pakistani, Indian and Sri Lankan men. Many of the women and children are being sent to refugee camps in Amman. At a tent hospital set up by the Red Cross-Red Crescent, Dr. Khaled Issa said 2,000 people a day come in for treatment. Most suffer dehydration, colds and other minor illnesses. But in the harsh camp conditions, minor ailments can rapidly become life-threatening. Issa said those who are sick should drink five gallons of water a day, much more than is available. A five-member delegation from the European Parliament toured Jordan's camps and members said Friday they were appalled by the conditions. One said European nations should provide military transport planes to airlift the refugees home. Official estimates say more than 250,000 foreigners, mostly Asians, have crossed the desert border post at Reweishid since the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait.

DOC.HEAD: Economic Task Unable to Resolve Yeltsin, Gorbachev Differences
DOC.TEXT: A legislative task force has failed to reconcile fully the economic plans of President Mikhail Gorbachev with the more radical proposals of rival Boris Yeltsin, a top official said today. The task force on economic reform, which was under orders to come up with an economic blueprint before Monday's opening session of the national parliament, agreed Friday night on what it called a ``unified plan.'' However, Anatoly Lukyanov, chairman of the national Supreme Soviet legislature, said at a news conference that the task force's plan would leave some major points of disagreement for national and republic parliaments to tackle. Lukyanov did not specify the areas of disagreement. But on Tuesday, Gorbachev spokesman Vitaly N. Ignatenko said they centered on the speed and sequence of the reforms and on price-setting machinery. Yeltsin, president of the Russian Federation, had threatened that the Russian republic would go ahead with radical economic reform on its own if Gorbachev and national authorities continued to delay. Since Russia is the largest Soviet republic, with half the country's people and three-quarters of its land, the Kremlin could hardly ignore Yeltsin's warning. Lukyanov said the national legislature will not act on the economic plans until it has been discussed in each of the 15 republican parliaments. Russia's Supreme Soviet is to debate its radical version starting Monday and may adopt it Tuesday. The plan calls for transformation of the Soviet Union to an economic union with a single currency and one customs code, but no central authority to levy taxes. The Russian republic would immediately legalize private ownership of land. Lukyanov also said 13 bills on economic reform have already been sent to parliamentary committees for review. He said they including draft laws on protection of individual property and inventions, pricing, entrepreneurship, banking, use of foreign currency, employment, customs, social security, insurance, foreign investment and support for invalids and other disadvantaged groups. Other bills on the Supreme Soviet agenda for the upcoming session include one guaranteeing freedom to emigrate and travel. The United States has refused to grant the Soviet Union preferential trade treatment until this law is approved. Freedom of religion and a law on creation of public organizations and political parties also will be considered, Lukyanov said.

DOC.HEAD: Swedish, Norwegian Embassies In Kuwait Plan Evacuation
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to UPDATE with comment from Norwegian foreign ministry. Pick up 5th graf pvs, `Iraq invaded...'
DOC.TEXT: Sweden and Norway evacuated their embassies in Kuwait today but officially left them open in defiance of Iraqi authorities, Swedish and Norwegian officials said. Surrounded by Iraqi troops, Norway's embassy has been without water, electricity and communications for nearly two weeks. Similar conditions prevail at the Swedish mission. Norwegian Foreign Ministry spokesman Bjoern Blokhus said three Norwegian diplomats, two Swedes and and local employees were en route to Baghdad and expected to arrive Sunday. ``We received word through the Danish Foreign Ministry that they had left,'' Blokhus said. ``We feel reasonably certain that the trip will go well.'' He said Norway still does not accept the Iraqi order to permanently close its mission. Sweden took the same position. ``Principally, we maintain our right to keep our embassy in Kuwait,'' Swedish Foreign Ministry spokesman Ulf Heineback told the Stockholm newspaper Dagens Nyheter. The diplomats were guaranteed safe passage to Baghdad, but their eventual departure from Iraq would ``be the subject of future negotiations,'' Blokhus said. He said the Iraqis no longer consider the Kuwait embassy staff as diplomats. Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2 and then annexed the oil-rich emirate, claiming it as part of Iraqi territory. Baghdad on Aug. 24 ordered all missions in Kuwait closed, turning off utilities and surrounding embassies with troops. The U.S. Embassy is among about 30 missions in Kuwait that refused to close, although the staff was reduced. Several nations _ including the Soviet Union, Japan and Hungary _ withdrew their staffs earlier but maintained the embassies are not officially closed. Iraq has told diplomats accredited to Kuwait that they have lost their diplomatic immunity. Baghdad has blocked personnel who left the U.S. Embassy in Kuwait from returning home until the mission is closed. There were about 21,000 Westerners in Iraq and Kuwait at the time of Iraq's invasion, including 3,000 Americans. Iraqi President Saddam Hussein has allowed some Western women and children to leave over the last week. Western men, however, have been prevented from leaving. Many were placed at strategic Iraqi installations to deter any attack by U.S.-led multinational forces.

DOC.HEAD: Insurgent Lt. Gov. Grabs Control in Dukakis' Absence
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4-5th grafs, bgng `Acting under...', with 4 grafs to ADD comment from Dukakis spokesman. Picks up 6th graf pvs, `Murphy, who...'. SUBS 12-14th grafs pvs, bgng `Murphy, who...', with 2 grafs to DELETE redundant material. Picks up 15th graf pvs, `Included in...'.
DOC.TEXT: Lt. Gov. Evelyn Murphy issued executive orders to slash the state work force and cut state salaries as she defied Gov. Michael S. Dukakis while he was out of town. With Dukakis leading a trade mission in Germany, Murphy lived up to her promise to take command and try to balance the state deficit. ``What I have put in motion today is what I have been talking about for some time _ nothing radical, nothing irresponsible,'' Murphy said Friday. ``I'm an economist and a public servant, not a revolutionary.'' Acting under provisions making her acting governor in Dukakis' absence, Murphy issued executive orders that would cut the state work force by an estimated 1,000 jobs and cut salaries for some employees. She acknowledged, however, that Dukakis can undo her work when he returns Friday. Dukakis had said he might cut his trip short if any action Murphy took threatened to hurt the state's stability. But after Murphy issued her orders, Dukakis spokesman Stephen Crawford said he saw no reason for the governor to return early. He noted that executive orders requiring payroll cuts would not take effect before Dukakis comes back, since such actions take 10 days to implement. In her announcement Friday, Murphy also requested state agencies to cut their 1992 budgets 10 percent below spending levels for the current fiscal year, and unveiled plans to set up a commission to investigate inaccurate revenue estimates, which have been blamed for exacerbating the budget problems. Murphy, who is running for governor in the Sept. 18 Democratic primary, touched off a power struggle in the Statehouse after she said Wednesday that she was waiting for Dukakis to leave so she could enact her plans to deal with the state's fiscal crunch. Learning about the revolt, Dukakis postponed his travel plans, bitterly attacking Murphy's maneuver as a ``charade.'' But he eventually left for Germany on Thursday night. Critics called Murphy's efforts a political stunt that ultimately would have about as much chance of success as her flagging campaign for governor. Opinion polls put her behind two other candidates for governor in the primary race. ``I don't take coffee house coup d'etats very seriously,'' said one of her Democratic primary rivals, Boston University President John Silber. L. Edward Lashman, the governor's secretary of administration and finance, said that the projected savings in Murphy's plan were highly inflated, though he called the proposal a ``serious effort.'' Along with many Democrats, Murphy was an avid Dukakis supporter during his 1988 bid for the presidency. But the state's fiscal woes have made Dukakis the source of public disdain, including snipes from Murphy. Murphy insisted she was trying to save the state from sinking further in its fiscal mess. ``As I look back, maybe I should have acted in the past,'' she said. ``I don't deny that.'' Included in Murphy's executive orders: _Cut the management positions under each Cabinet secretary by 25 percent by Dec. 31. _Restructure the state Department of Administration and Finance, setting a goal of a 10 percent payroll reduction. _Temporarily cut payrolls for state employees in the Executive Branch whose salaries exceed $40,000. The salaries would be restored when the budget is balanced.

DOC.HEAD: European Finance Ministers Discuss Union, Gulf Crisis
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4 grafs for 9-13 bgng `While there ...' to ADD Spanish economic proposal; no pickup
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Finance ministers of the 12-member European Community today discussed plans for economic and monetary union and assessed the impact of the Persian Gulf crisis on Europe's economy. On Friday, EC foreign ministers agreed to give $2 billion in economic aid to Turkey, Jordan and Egypt to compensate them for lost trade with Iraq. The United Nations has imposed an economic embargo on Iraq for its Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. Officials said the finance ministers would discuss how the aid will be financed. Italy holds the rotating presidency of the European Community. The EC hopes the oil-rich Persian Gulf nations _ notably Saudi Arabia which benefits from higher oil prices _ will pay $6 billion of the estimated $9 billion Turkey, Jordan and Egypt will lose through 1991. EC Economic and Monetary Affairs Commissioner Henning Christophersen will give the finance ministers an initial assessment of the impact of the gulf crisis on the EC economy. He will not offer precise figures, officials said, but present several scenarios, including one foreseeing oil prices hovering at around $30 a barrel. At that price, the Community's economic growth could drop to 2.1 percent from a forecast rate of 3.1 percent, and there would be a reversal in the trend toward declining unemployment, according to EC figures. Another key topic of today's meeting was plans to turn the European Community into an economic and monetary union _ an issue that has pitted Britain against its EC partners. In December, the 12 EC nations will hold a conference to amend the Community's constitution, creating a European central bank and a single currency. While there is agreement on the need to turn the EC into a more effective trade bloc, there are disagreements on the need for a single currency and central bank, both of which Britain opposes. The finance ministers today discussed a blueprint for economic and monetary union that proposes a European central banking system, called Eurofed, as early as Jan. 1, 1993, and a European currency unit, the ecu, to become a single EC currency. Spain today proposed the EC not create a single currency until at least 2000, but use the currency along with the 12 national currencies for several years before the switch. Spanish Finance Minister Carlos Solchaga also recommended the EC not establish Eurofed until after Jan. 1, 1994. The European Community members are: France, West Germany, Italy, Luxembourg, Belgium, the Netherlands, Denmark, Greece, Ireland, Portugal, Spain and the United Kingdom.

DOC.HEAD: Arizonans Wed in Tahiti Hospital Despite Bride's Broken Leg
DOC.TEXT: An Arizona couple fulfilled a dream of marrying in Tahiti, even though the bride lay immobilized in a hospital bed during the ceremony because of a broken leg. Elizabeth Talbot fell off a terrace at a rented house three days before the planned wedding, breaking her leg in two places. She and her fiance, Douglas Michelson, applied for and finally received permission to be married at the hospital. The mayor of Papeete, capital of the French territory, dispatched a government official to conduct the ceremony Thursday and later presented a commemorative plaque to the two Phoenix residents. The event was front-page news Friday in local newspapers.

DOC.HEAD: 10 Die in Landslides and Floods
DOC.TEXT: Ten people were killed when their houses were buried under landslides or swept away by floods during torrential rains in western Nepal, the Home Ministry said Saturday. The deaths occurred Tuesday, but reports from the remote regions were slow to reach the capital. Eight people were killed and four were injured when their homes were swept away by floods in the Jajarkot district, 200 miles west of Katmandu, the ministry's announcement said. The bodies of two children were found under a heap of rubble after a landslide hit their house in the Rolpa district, 175 miles west of the capital, the ministry said. In late August, 32 people died in floods that struck several parts of this Himalayan nation.

DOC.HEAD: Gunmen Tie Up Italian Tourists, Blow Up Bungalows
DOC.TEXT: Masked gunmen tied up 29 Italian vacationers and workers, then set off explosives that damaged two bungalows at a tourist complex being built in southern Corsica, police said Saturday. There was no claim of responsibility, but the attack was similar to others claimed by guerrillas who seek Corsica's independence from France and oppose continuing tourist development on the Mediterranean island. Police said six or seven men entered the partially completed complex at about 9:30 p.m. Friday, took 15 tourists and 14 workers prisoner, and tied them up in a villa before setting off homemade bombs made from gas bottles. Two bungalows and a construction crane were badly damaged by the blasts, but no one was injured, police said. One of the attackers left a spray-painted message, ``No Mafia,'' and the group then fled in a stolen car, according to police. The seaside complex is being developed by an Italian company.

DOC.HEAD: Seoul to Propose Exchange Visits of Separated Family Members
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Kang Young-hoon said Saturday South Korea will propose that families separated on the divided Korean peninsula be allowed to have temporary reunions. Kang said the exchanges could begin around Chusok, the Korean thanksgiving day, which falls on Oct. 3. The holiday is widely observed in both countries. It would be the second time that the hostile nations have allowed separated families to visit with each other. The first exchange took place in 1985 and involved only 50 people from each side. There are about 10 million members of families separated by the division of the peninsula in 1945. The border of North and South Korea is sealed and there is no mail or other form of communication between the nations. Kang said he was optimistic about the prospect of the exchanges, citing an upbeat mood that prevailed at the just-concluded talks between him and North Korean Prime Minister Yon Hyong Muk. The prime ministers' talks were the highest-level meetings between the rival nations. They failed to produce any tangible agreements but officials of both sides were upbeat and said they will meet again in North Korea's capital in mid-October. The prime ministers' talks in Seoul could thaw the Cold War relations between the two nations, Kang said. He said the manner in which the North Korean officials spoke and acted bolstered belief that the communist regime may change its policy and recognize South Korea as a legitimate entity. He cited the North Korean prime minister's meeting with South Korean President Roh Tae-woo and his repeated reference to Roh as ``your excellency president.'' During the Seoul talks, Kang said he proposed that South Korea import iron ore and other raw materials from North Korea. Communist officials did not respond directly.

DOC.HEAD: Renegade Officer Surrenders, Urges Others to Do Same
DOC.TEXT: A renegade army captain surrendered to authorities and urged fellow mutineers to give themselves up to help the government overcome economic and political problems, officials said Saturday. Capt. Edmundo Malabanjot, a former officer of the Philippine Army's elite 1st Scout Regiment, surrendered Tuesday in central Capiz province to Brig. Gen. Raymundo Jarque, army regional commander. Malabanjot in a signed statement released to reporters said he was involved in the Aug. 28, 1987 coup attempt and another one that lasted from Dec. 1-9, 1989. ``I am calling on our countrymen who continue to rebel against the government to stop the violence to stop this senseless bloodshed and work together for the welfare of the country,'' the statement said. A report from armed forces headquarters said Malabanjot was among the renegade soldiers who attacked the army's detention center in suburban Fort Bonifacio at the start of the December coup attempt in an attempt to free jailed comrades.

DOC.HEAD: Albania's Communist Leader Outlines New Election Law
DOC.TEXT: Voters in Albania will be given some freedom of choice, but the ruling Communists will maintain tight control over the election process, that country's leader said. In comments made available today, Communist Party leader Ramiz Alia also hinted that wide-ranging changes may be necessary to accelerate new economic programs. ``Without combatting red tape, without being freed from the old management complexes ... the hindrances we are coming across cannot be eliminated,'' said Alia in a speech Thursday to legislators and senior officials of organizations supervised by the ruling Communist Party. The state ATA news agency distributed Alia's comments today. Albania in recent months has sought to usher in modest reforms and shed its image as a hermit country and Europe's last bastion of hard-line Stalinism. Diplomatic ties with the Soviet Union were re-established. Albania is also seeking to resume full relations with the United States while moving closer to other European nations. The Albanian leadership has announced economic reforms calculated to nudge the country away from rigid central planning and give private farmers and tradesmen greater freedoms. Last month, it liberalized travel regulations, allowing all citizens to own a passport and abolishing the death penalty for those trying to flee the country. Authorities later allowed the departure of about 5,000 asylum-seekers who had poured into foreign embassies in the capital city of Tirana. Alia, however, has said he will not allow sweeping democratic change and full multiparty elections. Outlining the planned election legislation, Alia said it would give all citizens the right to stand for office except those ``expressly deprived of this right by law.'' He did not elaborate on who would be prohibited. Balloting would be secret and there would be two nominees for each precinct. The right to nominate candidates would be granted to the party, trade trade unions and other groups, Alia said. But the party controls all public organizations in Albania, and it is unlikely the elections could pose a political threat to the current rulers. Alia said broadening the nominating base ``will represent and express better the will and convictions of all categories of the population.''

DOC.HEAD: NASA Budget Threatened By Summer of Trouble
DOC.TEXT: NASA was counting on a successful shuttle flight this month to help shake a tarnished image and prove to Congress that it is, indeed, the can-do agency of years past. But the glory days seem further away than ever now that Columbia still leaks hydrogen and remains earthbound for another week, possibly longer. It's one more embarrassment for NASA as lawmakers head into the final weeks of budget talks. President Bush has proposed spending $15.1 billion for NASA for fiscal 1991, which begins Oct. 1. That's 24 percent more than this year's $12.3 billion budget. The space agency's administrator, former astronaut Richard Truly, said he hopes _ and trusts _ Congress will support the National Aeronautics and Space Administration as it has before. ``I'm going to continue to tell them what I've been telling them, that is to remind them that we're executing the program that we put into place after the Challenger accident,'' Truly said. ``We said that when we ran into safety problems like hydrogen leaks, which can be extremely dangerous, we were going to stop and fix them.'' ``We've been sticking to our guns and doing what we agreed with their oversight to do,'' Truly said last week. NASA's third attempt to send Columbia on an astronomy mission ended abruptly Thursday when hydrogen leaked during fueling. A fuel leak also occurred during Columbia's first launch attempt in May. Shuttle Atlantis also was found to have hydrogen leaks. That discovery prompted NASA in late June to temporarily ground the three-shuttle fleet. Forrest S. McCartney, director of Kennedy Space Center, said there is no reason for NASA to be ``hanging its head'' over the leak-related launch delays. ``Hey, this isn't easy work. This is not the routine, everyday work,'' McCartney said. ``The thing we want to do is make sure every time we fly, we fly safely. Hopefully, America will understand that.'' One of the chief criticisms leveled against NASA after the 1986 Challenger disaster was that it was taking risks to meet an overambitious schedule. That year, NASA had scheduled 15 shuttle flights. In the two years since flights have resumed, 10 shuttles have been launched. Nine missions had been scheduled for 1990; three have flown. Discovery was the last shuttle to fly. The April mission successfully placed the Hubble Space Telescope in orbit _ but then a flaw in the instrument's mirror was discovered in June. Nothing, it seems, has gone right for NASA since spring. In addition to leaky shuttles and Hubble's trouble, the space agency has encountered mounting criticism of its space station plans and communications problems with the Magellan spacecraft orbiting Venus. A Senate appropriations committee will be taking all of NASA's problems into account when it sets the 1991 budget. Deep cuts are expected. The House already has slashed more than $800 million. The House's $14.3 billion plan still is 17 percent more than the current budget. About $195 million was cut from the $2.45 billion sought for the proposed space station Freedom. The House also cut more than $300 million in work to begin on Bush's plan to send astronauts back to the moon and on to Mars. ``NASA has more than enough on its plate at the moment and ought not to be starting new programs,'' said Rep. William Green, R-N.Y., vice chairman of the House appropriations subcommittee that funds NASA. Green said no one faults NASA for scrubbing launches because of leaking hydrogen, a highly combustible fuel. But, he said, the problem demonstrates ``how fragile the shuttle is and raises the question whether space station is way oversized in terms of the capability of the shuttle to get it built and serviced.'' Engineers suspect a bad fuel pump is the source of Columbia's latest leaks. Workers planned Sunday to replace all three recirculation pumps, one for each main engine. NASA is aiming for a Columbia launch for early the week of Sept. 17, which would provide enough time before Discovery's top-priority mission in October. Discovery's cargo is a satellite named Ulysses that will be sent on a five-year journey to study the sun's unexplored polar regions. NASA must launch Discovery between Oct. 5 and Oct. 23, or it will have to wait until the planets are properly aligned again in late 1991.

DOC.HEAD: Gulf Crisis Brings Social Change In Long-Resistant Kingdom
DOC.TEXT: The ban on women serving as nurses will be lifted Monday, which would have been unthinkable in this strict Moslem kingdom before Saddam Hussein's army invaded neighboring Kuwait a month ago. The announcement last week was an indication of the social and political change that began after King Fahd drastically altered Saudi policy and invited hundreds of thousands of foreign soldiers, mostly Americans, to defend his throne.
