Saudi, diplomatic and other sources said the crisis will accelerate a discreet move toward liberalization that has been creeping through the kingdom for a decade. Some of the changes wrought by the U.S. intervention may not last, but Saudi society appears on the threshold of modernization. ``The crisis will have a lot of impact,'' said Prince Abdallah bin Faisal, head of one of the country's major industrial developments and a nephew of the king. ``It will speed up certain ideas that the government has been thinking about for years.'' Expected changes include a more professional, broadly based military, more freedom for women, greater press freedom, more public say in local matters and a foreign policy of cementing alliances. Fear of a backlash from the conservative Islamic faithful will temper the pace. ``There's a feeling that society is still raw,'' said Omar S. Bagour, an economics professor at King Abdul Aziz University. ``New ideas should be delivered in specific doses so as not to offend the religious people.'' American servicemen and women pouring into Saudi Arabia are not expected to have much direct influence on Saudi society because most are stationed at desert bases. It is the first time foreigners have been called in to defend the kingdom. In addition, a call for army volunteers represents a major change in a force that had been reserved for princes and members of the Bedouin tribes loyal to the ruling al-Saud family since the country was united in the 1920s. ``They used to look for what was referred to as a `friendship of arms,'' Bagour said. ``Now the door's been thrown wide open.'' Billions of dollars in oil money engendered a false sense of security in Saudi Arabia, and the spartan, desert warrior tradition gave way to limousines and air conditioning. ``The Saudi government has pampered its citizens for years, given them everything for free,'' said Khaled A. Al-Maeena, editor of Arab News, the kingdom's leading English-language daily. ``It's time for people to start doing things for themselves.'' A few weeks ago, newspapers rarely carried anything that could rock the boat. Now, they are becoming more open about Arab issues. In foreign policy, the kingdom is moving conspicuously away from Yasser Arafat, leader of the Palestine Liberation Organization, but diplomats said it was unlikely to abandon the Palestinian cause. Saudi Arabia and the other oil-rich Persian Gulf states have paid Arafat's bills for years. The Saudis also have sought to balance their ties with America and the Islamic world. With the Arab world turned upside down by Saddam, diplomats said, the Saudis are expected to foster ties with Syria and Egypt to rebuild a semblance of Arab unity. No one wanted to be quoted as speaking against the royal family, a network of more than 4,000 princes, but businessmen are privately critical of the growing number of princes who use their influence to win government contracts. King Fahd is an absolute monarch. Like the neighboring emirates and sheikdoms, Saudi Arabia has little democratic structure, but that could be changing. One option is a consultative council. The government built a headquarters for it in the 1980s, but did not name a council or hold elections. Because of the small population, somewhere between 7 and 11 million in an area the size of Western Europe, policy changes could increase opportunities for women. ``Conscription for men has historically opened a place for women in jobs,'' said Faiza S. Ambah, a journalist. Women have been banned from nursing, for example, because it involves mingling with male strangers, a violation of Islamic tenets. ``Most of the nurses are Britons or Filipinos,'' said Samar Fatany, a radio broadcaster. ``What happens if there's a war and they all decide to go home?'' In a recent interview, the civil defense director said women probably would be asked to help ambulance and fire-fighting units. ``Before the crisis, this would have been blasphemy,'' one Arab said. Many women hope for an end to laws against their driving, or traveling without being escorted by a male relative. The sight of American servicewomen driving trucks or working with their male colleagues in high-tech jobs may bolster their argument. ``To rely on a 22-year-old girl to help defend the country could break a barrier in their minds,'' said an ambassador from a Moslem country. Saudis travel and study abroad, have access to foreign television and radio and are host to 4 million expatriate workers, among them 25,000 Americans, but none of that has changed the kingdom's traditions or strict Islamic principles. Most Americans and Europeans live in their own complexes so their customs, considered decadent by many Arabs, do not infect the Saudis. Conservative Moslems, who distrust the United States because of its close ties with Israel, supported the use of American troops to defend the country. Bin Baz, a spokesman for the religious groups, issued a statement saying it was permissible to have Christian soldiers defend the center of Islam against an enemy like Saddam. Even moderate believers say this support would evaporate if U.S. forces attack Moslem civilians in Kuwait or Iraq. ``The United States will have our support as long as they act under moral rules,'' said Nezar Zahed, a lay preacher. Diplomats said the same rule applies to the Saudi government, which is keenly aware that change must be synchronized with the kingdom's Islamic past. ``Just because we buy neon light doesn't mean we have to have a striptease with it as well,'' Prince Abdullah said.

DOC.HEAD: Oregon Proposal Would Provide Tax Break for Private School Parents
DOC.TEXT: A petition drive has put a proposed constitutional amendment on Oregon's Nov. 6 ballot that supporters and foes alike call the most far-reaching school choice measure in the nation. Backers of the Educational Choice Initiative, or Measure 11, say it would greatly broaden educational opportunity by giving parents the means to send their children to schools of their choice _ public or private. Opponents say it would severely weaken the public school system and violate constitutionally required separation of church and state. The proposal would allow parents to send their children across district lines to any public school. State school aid would follow the students. More controversially, it also would grant state income tax credits of up to $2,500 a year for pupils at private schools, including church-supported schools, and for children taught at home. A poll of 600 registered voters conducted in late August for The Oregonian newspaper of Portland found 48 percent in favor of the proposal, 47 percent opposed and 5 percent undecided. The margin of error was plus or minus 4 percentage points. Minnesota is the only state with statewide open enrollment for public schools. It also is the only one that gives tax breaks to parents of students who attend private schools, but the breaks aren't so generous as in the Oregon measure. Minnesota permits taxpayers to deduct from taxable income up to $1,000 in private school expenses. The Oregon measure would allow tax credits _ a direct subtraction from taxes owed _ of up to $2,500 a year. The Office of Legislative Counsel said Measure 11 is similar in most respects to the Minnesota law, which was upheld by the U.S. Supreme Court in 1984. If the Oregon measure is passed, it will take effect in the 1991-92 school year. The proposal ``is certainly the most extensive'' one of its kind, said Sister Catherine McNamee, president of the National Catholic Education Association in Washington. The association, which represents 200,000 Roman Catholic educators, strongly backs the proposal. The idea for Measure 11, however, largely came from Libertarian Party adherents. ``What we're most concerned about is quality education for our children,'' said Steve Buckstein, a Portland stockbroker. ``Where it's performed is not as important as getting a good education.'' Buckstein, an unsuccessful Libertarian candidate for state treasurer in 1988, is a spokesman for Oregonians for Educational Choice, which put the measure on the ballot with 127,000 petition signatures. Opponents say one of their major arguments against passage will be that the measure would result in using taxes to aid religion. ``I have a basic disagreement with public funds for private schools,'' said Norma Paulus, the state school superintendent-elect. ``Their arguments for allowing choice inside the public school system are very valid,'' she said. ``But if you lay the initiative on top of the existing funding mechanism, it will hasten the disintegration of the public school system.'' The Oregon Education Association, the state's largest teachers union, opposes the whole idea. ``We believe every school should be excellent,'' said the union's president, Karen Famous. ``Competition implies winners and losers, and none of our young children can be classified as losers.'' The union also would focus its attack on the church-state issue, she said. Buckstein and other supporters say the church-state argument is invalid. ``The state will never write a check to a religious school under our measure,'' Buckstein said. ``And there is no entanglement between the state and religion.'' Supporters compare the tax credits to federal college-aid benefits that can be used at public or private schools. A recurrent argument of the proposal's supporters is that it would give low- and middle-income parents who now have no options the opportunity to choose their children's schooling. ``Only the wealthy now have a choice in Oregon,'' Buckstein said. ``Right now, geography is destiny. Where you can afford to live determines where your child can go to school.'' A study of the Minnesota system, which until this year applied only to districts with more than 1,000 students, found less than half of 1 percent of students transferred under open enrollment last school year. Convenience was cited twice as often as academic opportunity by those who volunteered reasons on their applications.

DOC.HEAD: Arabs Vow Wave Of Terror If U.S. Humbles Saddam
DOC.TEXT: In the cozy arabesque precincts of the Wahdat Club, a Palestinian social center, a dapper clerk spoke matter-of-factly of the terrorism he expects to run rampant if America humiliates Saddam Hussein. ``If these colonial troops remain in our region, we will use any means to get them out; kidnapping, terrorism _ any means,'' Jamal Abu Saud said of the U.S. forces in Saudi Arabia. From former Cabinet ministers and millionaires to teen-agers who sweep up at the outdoor markets, a majority of Jordanians support the Iraqi leader and his demand for a tie between Kuwait's fate and a homeland for the Palestinians. If he fails, a wide range of Palestinians and other Jordanians agree, the United States will face deep-seated anger, radicalized political and religious feelings and possibly violence. Of Jordan's 3 million people, 65 percent are Palestinians. Already, some Arabs in Jordan refer to the United States as ``the head of the snake,'' in the way Iranians began calling it the ``Great Satan,'' because it is seen as Israel's protector. Many Palestinians say opinion crystallizing around Saddam seems to have unified their community to a degree rarely seen. ``I will explain,'' said John Hanna, a retired banker sipping coffee under a rack of Arabic lutes, called rouds, at the Studio Petra music shop. His friend, the shop owner, nodded gravely. ``As Arabs and Palestinians, we lost our land,'' Hanna said. ``We find this man who will give it back. If he gives us back our rights, we will worship him. What else he does, we don't care.'' With a low chuckle, he added that if King Fahd of Saudi Arabia ``put everything behind a Palestinian homeland, we would worship him.'' At his daughter's plush residence, Palestinian business mogul Issa Masri parked his deluxe BMW beside his two other cars and took his guests upstairs. There, a roomful of intellectuals chimed in. ``It's time American presidents understood that they must make friends with people, not with kings and sheiks,'' said Wadid Masri, an aging activist from Nablus in the Israeli-occupied West Bank. ``Saddam fought for eight years to keep Iran out of Arabia,'' said Wahid Salah, a Palestinian lawyer and former Jordanian foreign minister. ``The streets of Jordan are with Saddam.'' King Hussein of Jordan shows sympathy for Saddam because his people demand it, Salah said, just as Palestinians insist Yasser Arafat orient the Palestine Liberation Organization toward Iraq. Salah stabbed a finger and added, ``If Saddam is defeated, this whole area will be a zone of terrorism and anarchy. Every American in the Arab world will be in danger.'' Dr. Wiin Munib, a medical professor who has lectured at Johns Hopkins University in Baltimore and Iowa University, criticized Washington for not hearing out King Hussein. ``I feel bitter about America, maybe for the first time,'' he said, adding that his own feelings were more moderate than most. On a less fashionable hill of Amman, among the winding alleys of the old souk, or market, the mood is easy to read. At a butcher's stall, the familiar grinning portrait of Saddam is taped up behind a hanging lamb carcass. Vegetable sellers and keymakers display posters of the king and Saddam side by side. ``He's right,'' declared Ahmed Atthir, 18, leaning on a counter of sunglasses and watches. ``I'll go fight if they need me.'' Wealthier merchants are in accord. ``Saddam is a great man,'' said Emile Haddad, the Christian owner of a menswear shop. In little towns the length of Jordan, at truck stops, in the port city of Aqaba on the Red Sea, the word is the same. Complex feelings on the issue are not easy to judge. Salem Fouad, a cabbie, keeps a photo of Saddam on his windshield and, in the glove compartment, an invitation to his brother's wedding in Nashville, Tenn. Opinion in Jordan is shifting against the United States. This is most evident in the 11 camps where Palestinian refugees have waited since 1948 to go home. The refugee camp of Wahdat blends almost imperceptibly into the sprawl of downtown Amman, but its 120,000 residents know every inch of its boundaries. Many refuse to leave, even when they earn the means to move elsewhere, for fear of losing their Palestinian identity or their right to demand a homeland. Abdul Aziz Attar, 70, was uprooted from Ramallah in the 1948 Israeli-Arab war. In 1967, when the Israelis captured the West Bank of the Jordan River, he fled to Amman. He sits among balls of yarn and sequins in his shop and dreams of a message like Saddam's. ``You have to know the enemy is America because it gives everything to Israel,'' he said. ``We live like beggars so they can have our wealth.'' He drew a parallel with Kuwait, where he said a small group, the now-deposed ruling al-Sabah family, squandered vast riches. As he spoke, a Jordanian policeman leaned close to listen. At the mention of the Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait, he burst out: ``That was Saddam's right. It is his.'' Down the street a few blocks, a mother bringing her five children home from shopping was asked about Saddam. ``We love him,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: So Many Stores, So Little Time
DOC.TEXT: To Soviets and foreign residents of Moscow, Helsinki seems like one giant shopping mall. It's filled with all the goods, from canned tomatoes to fine clothes to videocassettes, that are unavailable at home. Children at Moscow's Anglo-American School, asked once for the name of Finland's capital, answered, ``Stockmann's'' _ the name of Helsinki's biggest department store. Catering to this image, the Finnish government said it would allow retailers to remain open Sunday to accommodate the thousands of free-spending foreigners in town for the summit between President Bush and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. Helsinki has long been a popular destination for shoppers from the East, many of them expatriates living and working but finding little to buy in Moscow. For diplomats, journalists, businessmen and students in Moscow, Helsinki has the closest hospital they would feel comfortable using, the closest English-language movie theaters, the closest orthodontist, and until this year, the closest McDonald's. A cat owner in Moscow says she is considering sending her pet to Helsinki to be spayed. Finnair's half-fare prices for three-day trips make the Finnish capital a popular weekend destination for foreign families in Moscow. To get by other times, they order lettuce, cheese, milk, car parts, furniture, even all the fixings for a party, from Stockmann's. The department store sends a goods train from Helsinki to Moscow every Thursday. For clothes, some Muscovites travel to Helsinki to get the sizes right, and a better choice of style and quality. But Stockmann's export service manager, Henry Blomqvist, said, ``One gentleman came in here once to order bras for his wife. His wife was in Moscow and he was here, so he took a look at one of our (sales) ladies and said, `You are the right size.''' Many Western residents of Moscow are asked to pick up a few items for their Soviet friends. The most frequent requests are for electronics goods, car parts and videocassettes. Anything with Western brand names or symbols _ beer brand T-shirts, sandals with foreign flag designs _ is gratefully received. For Soviet citizens who are able to save up precious foreign currency and lucky enough to be sent to Helsinki on a business trip, shopping in the West is an adventure. A Soviet sports team was buying ``ghetto-blasters'' _ powerful portable radios _ at Helsinki's trendy ``Clockwork Orange'' electronics store during the past week. A Soviet employee of an American firm in Moscow was sent to Helsinki to pick up a new company car. The driver was astounded that different stores had different prices for the same items. He had never heard of comparison shopping. Still, casual Soviet shoppers are uncommon in Helsinki, as reflected by sales signs _ in Finnish, Swedish, and English, but not Russian. Stockmann's glossy, multicolored catalogues are sold in the Soviet Union, even though the items shown are available there only in foreign currency stores. The magazine is a widely read ``dreambook.'' Some Soviets occasionally fulfill their dream and make their way to Stockmann's export department in Helsinki. ``They are short of money,'' Blomqvist says. ``That's the problem. So they just buy the simplest things for normal use, cheap clothes, usually. Soviets were not previously big customers for us. We have only one salesperson who knows Russian well. ``But more of them are coming every week,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Summit Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here are President Bush's remarks Saturday upon arriving for his summit meeting with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev: The city of Helsinki has often been a meeting place for nations seeking to advance the cause of peace. My thanks to the people of Finland first for hosting this meeting and for setting an example for all the world in your resolute commitment to liberty and independence. When President Gorbachev and I met in Washington, we discussed the possibility of meetings such as the ones we'll hold here tomorrow. We agreed that the United States and the Soviet Union had reached a stage in our relations where meetings should occur more frequently, less fanfare, working meetings, held as circumstances might dictate. And our aim was that these meetings be unstructured and informal, with an open agenda and a maximum opportunity to exchange views on issues of mutual importance. In keeping with that aim, here in Helsinki President Gorbachev and I will focus on a full range of issues. We seek continued movement towards the new Europe whole and free. We seek to advance the pace of arms control, strategic and conventional. And I want to hear about the progress of the Soviet reform and explore other issues of interest to our two countries. And of course I expect that we will devote a large part of our time together to the situation in the Persian Gulf. I've said many times this past year that we have entered a new era in world affairs. This meeting comes at a critical time, at a moment when the actions we take can shape this new world for years to come. In the past many regional conflicts have played themselves out against the background of the larger conflict of the Cold War. Renegade regimes and unpredictable rulers resorted to force, counting on superpower stalemate to frustrate a united response. International law and international organizations were often paralyzed, powerless to prevent conflict or restore the peace. But the international response to Iraq's invasion proves how much has changed. Here in Helsinki President Gorbachev and I meet, hopefully to strengthen our common approach to this unjustifiable act of aggression. Much is at stake and there is much the world stands to gain if we succeed. If the nations of the world acting together continue, as they have been, to isolate Iraq and deny Saddam the fruits of aggression, we will set in place the cornerstone of an international order more peaceful, stable and secure than any that we have known. To our Finnish hosts, let met simply say that I intent to take full advantage of this very brief but welcome opportunity to renew America's warm friendship with Finland. I meet today with President Koivisto whose counsel I have valued over the years. Barbara and I often talk about our visit here in the early 80s, 1983. It was then that I first met your president, President Koivisto. We've stayed in very close touch since then, and I look forward to hearing his views on the many issues that I've just mentioned and others as well. Finland has long been a voice of peace and stability between nations _ in the councils of the CSCE; as a member of the United Nations peace-keeping forces; and today, at this time of challenge, Finland once again stands with the forces of peace. I thank the government of Finland for its staunch support as a member of the United Nations Security Council upholding international law in the face of Iraq's unwarranted aggression. Together with the nations of the world I am confident that we can reverse the dangerous course of events brought on by the actions of Saddam Hussein and restore peace, stability and respect for the rule of law. Thank you, Mr. President, and may God bless the people of Finland.

DOC.HEAD: Helsinki Seen as Slim Chance for Speeding up Arms Talks
DOC.TEXT: The superpower summit in Helsinki comes at a critical juncture in U.S.-Soviet nuclear arms control negotiations, described by some analysts as stalled and possibly in danger of falling apart. Sunday's session between President Bush and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev is not expected to provide more than a symbolic push for arms control. The more immediate Persian Gulf crisis is at the top of the summit agenda. The result may be a delay in the target date for completing a long-range nuclear weapons treaty. At their Washington summit in June, Bush and Gorbachev pledged to finish the Strategic Arms Reduction Talks treaty _ already eight years in the making _ by the end of the year. Doubt also is growing that the superpowers will complete a separate treaty reducing conventional, or non-nuclear, arms in Europe in time for a planned 35-nation summit in Paris in November. Bush has said he will not attend the summit unless a Conventional Forces in Europe, or CFE, treaty is finished beforehand. The Europeans are particularly anxious to see a CFE treaty because it is closely linked to German reunification. Marlin Fitzwater, the White House press secretary, said Tuesday that Bush and Gorbachev will discuss CFE issues in Helsinki but will not negotiate on the complex details. ``They will be attempting to add the impetus that would ensure that agreement is ready to sign and that the summit can be held'' as planned in November, he said. The Persian Gulf crisis triggered by Iraq's invasion and occupation of Kuwait is more than a distraction for the arms control bureaucracies in Moscow and Washington. It also has raised a new Soviet security concern: the sudden emergence of a huge U.S. military force in the gulf area. Soviet Gen. Vladimir Lobov, the military chief of the Warsaw Pact alliance, was quoted by the Soviet news agency Tass as saying the American buildup in the gulf ``drastically changes the strategic balance in the region.'' Gorbachev is likely to seek reassurance from Bush in Helsinki that the U.S. buildup will be reversed once the Iraq crisis ends, said Steve Lilly-Weber, a defense specialist at the Institute for Defense and Disarmament Studies in Brookline, Mass. Fitzwater insisted that START negotiations are on track, but when asked whether Bush still expects to sign a completed treaty this year he said only, ``Well, we're hopeful.'' The START treaty would reduce each side's arsenal of long-range nuclear missiles by about 30 percent. It would be the first-ever negotiated cut in this category of arms. ``I think it eventually will be finished, but the timetable will slip maybe into next year,'' said Stan Norris, an arms control expert at the Natural Resources Defense Council, a private research organization. Others say the treaty negotiations could unravel completely if Bush and Gorbachev allow the relatively few remaining disagreements to fester much longer. Spurgeon M. Keeny Jr., president of the private Arms Control Association and an advocate of a START treaty, said the rapid pace of developments in the Middle East, plus fear of other post-Cold War upheavals could kill support for the treaty. ``A treaty is a little bit like a shark; it has to keep moving forward or it dies,'' he said. Three main issues are holding up completion of a START deal. One is how far the Soviets should be allowed to go in modernizing their SS-18 intercontinental ballistic missiles, which form the backbone of the Soviet nuclear arsenal. The other unresolved matters are limits on the Soviet Backfire bomber and Soviet efforts to set limits on U.S. transfers of strategic nuclear systems to third countries.

DOC.HEAD: Rhode Island River Flows Red _ With Dye
DOC.TEXT: The Pawtuxet River flowed red through Coventry and West Warwick last week. No, it wasn't blood red. About 3,000 pounds of a red powder dye was dumped accidentally into a chemical manufacturer's sewage treatment plant Wednesday. Friday, that powder found its way into the Pawtuxet River and turned the water bright red. Department of Environmental Management authorities said the Hoechst Celanese Corp. dye was water-soluble and non-toxic, so it did not threaten the river or aquatic life. ``Although I understand it looks pretty horrible, it's essentially an innocuous spill,'' said Fran Segerson, a department spokeswoman. The department has recommended that Hoechst be fined for violating its discharge permit, she said. The size of the fine had not been determined. The dye got into the river because workers failed to bleach waste water properly before it was released, said Carmen A. Avon, environmental safety manager at the plant. She said the company considered adding bleach to the river to clear up the color, but state environmental officials decided said it would be better simply to let the dye dissipate on its own.

DOC.HEAD: Precede BAGHDAD
Iraq Stopping Charter Flights to Amman; U.S. Says Evacuation Continuing
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS thruout to UPDATE with Jordanian official saying airport congestion not a problem, moving up reference to profitability of Amman charters. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Iraq said today it will halt charter flights of foreigners to Jordan because of congestion, but a U.S. official said the evacuation of foreigners would continue. Jordan denied crowding at its international airport was a problem. Iraqi government spokesman Naji al-Hadithi said the order, effective Sunday, would not stop any chartered flights today, which were expected to include a planeload of Americans from Kuwait. He also said regular Iraqi Airways flights to Amman would not be affected, and that charters to other destinations would be allowed. State Department officials said the latest group of Americans was to be flown on today's chartered plane from Kuwait to Amman. A U.S. Embassy spokesman in Amman said about 150 people were aboard. A similar flight Friday carried 165 Americans and a few other foreigners. Al-Hadithi, speaking to reporters, said the decision to stop charter flights to Jordan was made after Jordanian officials complained they could not handle the increased air traffic. But a spokesman for the Amman airport denied there was a problem with congestion at the capital's international airport. ``Everything is fine, the airport is not crowded,'' said Mashhour El-Kurashi. The foreigners arriving in the past week on Iraqi Airways charters to Amman usually transfer immediately to other planes for the journey to their home countries. Al-Hadithi himself suggested another motivation for the cutoff when he noted that the short-haul charters to Amman, paid for by the passengers' governments, were not particularly profitable. ``We are ready to take them (the planes) to any other capital or city, even to the farthest point,'' the Iraqi official said. A State Department spokesman, told of the Iraqi announcement on suspending charter flights to Amman, said: ``The evacuation will continue.'' The spokesman, speaking on condition of anonymity, said a chartered flight will leave Baghdad on Sunday for London. ``We hope this will be the new model,'' the spokesman said. He gave no further details on that flight. The Iraqi announcement came just as the air highway out of Iraq via Jordan appeared to be running more smoothly. Exit visas were being issued more quickly than at the start of the week, and Iraq has allowed at least two direct charter flights from Kuwait City to the Jordanian capital of Amman, with stopovers for visa formalities in Baghdad. About a thousand stranded foreigners poured into Amman by air from Kuwait and Iraq in the past week. Iraq had been allowing up to three charter flights a day from Baghdad to Jordan. Al-Hadithi, the director-general of the Iraqi Information Ministry, said airport officials in Jordan had complained that they could not handle the hundreds of foreigners that have been pouring into Amman for the past week. Since the exodus of foreign women and children from Iraq and Kuwait began Sept. 1, the Amman airport has been the primary transit point. Hundreds of women and children were in Baghdad awaiting exit visas or flights. Thousands more foreigners remain trapped in Iraq and Iraqi-occupied Kuwait, stranded since the Aug. 2 invasion. Most of those in Kuwait are in hiding. On Thursday, Iraq imposed a law mandating prison terms up to life for foreigners caught trying to leave the country without exit visas. The law also requires foreigners to report any change of address within 48 hours or face jail. On Aug. 24, Iraq announced that anyone caught harboring a foreigner would face charges of espionage, punishable by death.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Souter Hearings Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here, at a glance, is information on the Senate confirmation hearings for Supreme Court nominee David H. Souter. _The Senate Judiciary Committee hearings will start 10 a.m. Thursday, Sept. 13. Although there is no official word on how long the hearings will last, they could run three days and conclude the following Monday. _Presiding will be Sen. Joseph Biden, D-Del., the committee chairman. _Souter is scheduled to be the committee's first witness. _The committee, which comprises eight Democrats and six Republicans, will vote on Souter's nomination sometime after concluding the hearings. The nomination then will go to the full Senate. _For the first time in the history of Supreme Court confirmation proceedings, the hearings will be conducted in the Hart Senate Office Building.

DOC.HEAD: Federal Judge Rejects Killer's Latest Bid To Block Execution
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge has rejected as ``frivolous'' the latest bid to block the execution of William Andrews, the nation's longest standing death row inmate, for the torture-murders of three people. In a three-page opinion released Friday, U.S. District Judge David Sam said Andrews had been given ``every conceivable opportunity'' for judicial review in more than 15 years of appeals. Andrews, 35, of Jonesboro, La., was convicted of the slayings in 1975. Pierre Dale Selby, who was convicted along with Andrews, was executed by lethal injection in 1987. Both were enlisted men at Hill Air Force Base at the time of the murders, in which five people were tied up, forced to drink liquid drain cleaner and shot in the head. Two of the victims survived. Andrews' lawyers had filed a motion Aug. 13 asking Sam to reconsider his earlier rejection of their motion for a new trial. The petition by Andrews, who is black, was based on claims that the prosecution's rejection of a black potential juror violated his constitutional right to equal protection under the law. The defense also questioned whether Sam had seen certain files from earlier court proceedings. The judge said the arguments regarding the juror and other evidence purportedly uncovered from the sentencing phase of the trial ``appear frivolous.'' And he said the records cited were pertinent only to earlier proceedings. Selby eventually confessed to firing the shots. Andrews' lawyers have claimed he should have been convicted only of second-degree murder because he did not fire the fatal bullets. Andrews' principal lawyer, Robert M. Anderson, was out of town Friday and unavailable for comment. He has indicated that the case would be appealed next to the 10th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals.

DOC.HEAD: Mother Teresa Puts Retirement Plans Aside After Re-election
LaserPHoto NY17
DOC.TEXT: Mother Teresa, saying she was bowing to God's will, accepted re-election Saturday as head of her worldwide mission for the poor after nuns ignored her wish to retire and voted for her to remain. The vote was intended to choose a successor to Mother Teresa, but after the results were announced the 80-year-old Nobel laureate withdrew her decision to step down as superior general of the Missionaries of Charity. ``She hasn't changed her mind, but she was elected,'' said Monsignor Francis Gomes, who presided over the secret balloting. ``She hoped that someone else would be elected.'' Gomes said Mother Teresa had little choice but to accept the unanimous vote. ``In religious life, there is no personal desire. You have to accept God's will,'' said Gomes, the vicar general of the Calcutta diocese. The Vatican said in a statement that it approved and gave its blessing to the decision. Mother Teresa declined to meet reporters, pleading fatigue. After the vote she told the nuns, ``If this is God's will, I will serve in the capacity in the best possible way,'' said Gomes. Last March, Pope John Paul II bowed to Mother Teresa's desire to retire and accepted her resignation as head of the order she founded. He had rejected her earlier requests to step down. The Yugoslavia-born Roman Catholic nun, known as the ``saint of the gutters'' for her work with the destitute and dying, suffered a nearly fatal heart attack a year ago. She returned to work but asked for retirement within a few months. Mother Teresa was elected to a six-year term. The constitution of her order calls for a maximum two terms, but the pope has waived this clause in the past so Mother Teresa could remain in the post. Ballots were cast by 103 delegates summoned from missions around the globe. The election was held a year ahead of schedule because Mother Teresa wanted to step down. Gomes indicated that the sisters were swayed by the new democratization of Eastern Europe and the opportunities to open new missions. ``The feeling was that with so much opening up in the Western world and in Eastern Europe, they need someone who can face the challenge,'' he said. He spoke to reporters in the garden of an institution for retarded women and children where the assembly was held. Mother Teresa's decision to retire had raised questions about the future of the Missionaries of Charity. Church officials have said nuns on her six-member administrative council were capable but did not have her worldwide recognition, determination and charisma, which opened many of the financial and political doors needed to accomplish the work of the mission. Mother Teresa's ministry to the poor and helpless began in earnest 43 years ago in the gutters of Calcutta. She gave up a comfortable teaching job at a Roman Catholic school to care for those whom no one else would touch. Literally plucking dying people from the streets of the teeming metropolis, Mother Teresa went on to found a series of homes in Calcutta and eventually throughout the world for society's castaways. At the height of the Israeli siege of West Beirut in 1982, she walked between the guns of the Israeli army and the Palestine Liberation Organization to rescue children trapped without food and medicine in a front-line hospital. The shooting stopped until her rescue mission was completed. Today, the Missionaries of Charity operates 430 homes in 95 countries for lepers, cripples, destitute consumptives, abandoned babies and others with no place to turn. She was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize in 1979. After she was released from a hospital a few months after the heart attack, Mother Teresa opened new houses in Poland, the Soviet Union, Czechoslovakia and Yugoslavia, where she was born. The only East Europe state without one of Mother Teresa's houses is Albania, the homeland of her parents.

DOC.HEAD: Budget Negotiators At Odds Over Revenues, Defense Cuts
DOC.NOTE: EDS: UPDATES to show caucus meetings rather than negotiations under way; no further top expected; picks up 3rd graf pvs, ``I think ...
DOC.TEXT: Administration officials and congressional leaders are voicing optimism about their revived budget talks, but the two sides still must overcome their differences on taxes and military spending. Before heading into the second straight day of negotiations today at Andrew Air Force Base, 10 miles outside Washington in suburban Maryland, each side held meetings to review the other side's position. The negotiators hope to craft a deal by Monday chopping about $50 billion out of next year's federal deficit and $500 billion out of the shortfall over the next five years. ``I think there is a new spirit of optimism that we can get an agreement,'' President Bush told reporters Friday as he arrived at Andrews for a 30-minute visit with bargainers. ``We feel positive and optimistic,'' the Democrat's chief negotiator, House Majority Leader Richard Gephardt of Missouri, said as the talks picked up after a five-week summer break. The two sides, meeting in the main bar and restaurant of the Andrews' officers club, swapped offers Friday for the first time since the talks began in May. Officials speaking on condition they not be identified described them. Republicans submitted a $52.5 billion plan for next year, which starts Oct. 1. It contains $20.4 billion in new taxes, $5.6 billion in new federal fees, and $4 billion in defense cuts. GOP taxes included levies on alcohol, a limit on state and local income tax deductions, and a cut in the capital gains tax rate. Bush says the lower rate would raise money by encouraging people to sell real estate and other property. The Democratic plan called for $50 billion in savings next year and $500 billion over five years. It relies on $26.9 billion in taxes and fees and $14.9 billion in defense reductions. Its taxes include levies on energy and gasoline. Details were not available. Unless deficit cuts are enacted by Oct. 1, the Gramm-Rudman law will slice $100 billion from federal spending next year, an amount officials consider intolerably harsh. The bargainers hope to reach a compromise by Monday to give Congress time to write the measure into law.

DOC.HEAD: Man Convicted in Gang Robbery, Torture of Vietnamese Family
DOC.TEXT: A Vietnamese man faces sentencing for his part in the gang attack on a countryman's home in which an 8-year-old boy was strung up with wire and his father made the target in a game of Russian roulette. After three hours of deliberation, a jury in this Washington, D.C., suburb found Bao Quoc Doan guilty of 10 charges, including burglary, robbery, abduction and use of a firearm. Doan, 21, was the second person convicted in the attack, and he faces a second trial in October stemming from another incident. The Fairfax County Circuit Court jury recommended that Doan, of no fixed address, be sentenced to life in prison plus 56 years. Doan was one of at least five men, three of whom wore masks, who stormed the home of a Vietnamese-born restaurateur in Falls Church on Feb. 24, Assistant Commonwealth's Attorney Mark Simmons said. The attack was one of eight in the county this year in which homes of Asian families have been invaded by groups, often made up of Vietnamese men. The attacks target business people in Vietnamese communities who are then threatened or beaten until they reveal where valuables are hidden. According to testimony, the assailants ran a meat cleaver against the neck of a 10-year-old boy in the household in addition to the attacks on his 8-year-old brother and the gun threat against their father.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Hopes to Strengthen `Common Approach' to Gulf With Gorbachev
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines pvs, subs 2 grafs for 3rd graf pvs with Gorbachev quotes
DOC.TEXT: President Bush and Mikhail Gorbachev arrived today for their third summit, a meeting Bush said he hoped would ``strengthen our common approach'' to fighting Iraqi aggression in the Persian Gulf. ``If the nations of the world, acting together, continue as they have been to isolate Iraq and deny Saddam the fruits of aggression, we will set in place the cornerstone of an international order more stable and secure than any we have known,'' Bush said at a red carpet arrival ceremony. Gorbachev arrived Saturday night, nearly eight hours after Bush, and declared the two leaders were meeting at ``a crucial moment in history,'' to make sure positive trends in world relations ``are not thwarted by any developments.'' The Soviet leader said they would focus on ``the acute crisis in the Persian Gulf and a number of other issues.'' In addition to the Persian Gulf crisis, Bush said he and Gorbachev would discuss superpower arms control, changes in Europe and the Soviet leader's economic reforms. In brief remarks at the U.S. Embassy, Bush spoke of how fortunate it was ``to have the Soviet Union very much in accord with what we're trying to do'' to stop Iraq's aggression. ``Tomorrow we'll be speaking not to some adversary but to a leader of a country with whom I think we are going to have increasingly productive relations,'' said Bush. The sun peeked through overcast skies as the president's spanking new Boeing 747 Air Force One touched down after an overnight flight from Washington. In town, the signs of summitry were everywhere _ from the American, Soviet and Finnish flags flying together to the extended hours that stores were staying open to cash in on the invasion of thousands of potential customers. Several thousand people were in the streets around the presidential palace waiting for a glimpse of the American president's motorcade. The usual tight security was in place _ vehicles blocking intersections and police sharpshooters overlooking the scene. A helicopter hovered overhead. ``This meeting comes at a critical time, at a moment when the actions we take can shape this new world for years to come,'' Bush said. ``In the past many regional conflicts have played themselves out against the background of the larger conflict of the Cold War. Renegade regimes and unpredictable rulers resorted to force, counting on superpower stalemate to frustrate a united response,'' he said. ``But the international response to Iraq's invasion proves how much has changed.'' Even before the first handshake, a Soviet official raised the possibility the two leaders might decide to extend their talks into Monday. ``It's unpredictable. It's up to them,'' said the official, who insisted on anonymity. Gorbachev has been supportive of Bush's efforts to isolate Iraq in response to Saddam Hussein's August invasion of Kuwait. And even a joint summit statement reiterating a demand for an Iraqi withdrawal would be a remarkable event, marking the first time the one-time rivals have spoken jointly on a major international issue other than arms control in more than four decades. Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze, speaking Friday on his way back to Moscow from Tokyo, said he is ``ready if necessary'' to go to Iraq to seek a peaceful resolution of the gulf crisis. Bush raised his hopes for a united U.S.-Soviet front against Iraq out of the Sunday summit. ``Here in Helsinki, President Gorbachev and I meet, hopefully to strengthen our common approach to this unjustifiable act of aggression,'' Bush said. Iraq's aggression in the Middle East overshadowed even the stubborn disagreements blocking completion of treaties to slash nuclear stockpiles and reduce troop and conventional arms in Europe in the post-Cold War era. Officials said Bush and Gorbachev would devote part of their five hours of summit talks to those issues, as well as to regional concerns such as Afghanistan. Speaking to reporters accompanying him here aboard Air Force One, Bush said he would not ask Gorbachev to contribute troops to the multinational force defending Saudi Arabia. ``I have no plans to do that, but I will be talking about a wide array of cooperative arrangements,'' Bush said. Bush said he was interested in trading U.S. oil technology for oil from the Soviet Union, the world's largest producer, and an oil deal ``could well come up at these meetings.'' Soviet Foreign Ministry spokesman Gennady Gerasimov said earlier in the day that the Soviet Union would be willing to send military forces to the Middle East under a military staff committee that included officers from the five permanent members of the U.N. Security Council. The talks came as both presidents coped with economic difficulties at home. Gorbachev is expected to announce a series of radical economic reforms when he returns home to Moscow next week that could transfer power from the central government to authorities in the 15 Soviet republics. Bush left behind a weakening economy possibly sliding into recession. Administration officials said the summit would be an informal session for consultation and play down prospects for any major announcements or new initiatives. Bush proposed the meeting. After their overnight flight from Washington, Bush and his wife Barbara went to the Finnish presidential palace with Finland's President Mauno Koivisto and his wife. Later, en route to address American diplomats and their families at the U.S. Embassy in Helsinki, Bush briefly stopped his motorcade at a crowded marketplace and briefly waded into the excited crowd, shaking hands. After speaking at the embassy, Bush moved on to his government guest quarters at the Kalastajatorppa Hotel. Secretary of State James A. Baker III was arriving Saturday from his tour of European and Middle East capitals seeking financial support for the deployment of U.S. troops in Saudi Arabia. ``It is an unstructured agenda,'' Bush spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said of the summit, the third that Bush has held with Gorbachev as president. And despite the continued presence of Soviet military advisers in Iraq, Fitzwater went out of his way in a pre-summit briefing for reporters to praise the Soviets for their ``real and very helpful support in the Persian Gulf'' and to say that For their part, the Soviets have said they were looking forward to sessions devoid of the ``theatrics'' of other superpower summits, and reflecting the improved relationship in the post-Cold War era. While the Soviets have opposed Saddam's occupation of Kuwait, the summit gives Bush an opportunity to respond to Soviet misgivings about the U.S. military buildup in the region. Gorbachev has voiced concern about ``unpredictable consequences'' of military confrontation. Moscow has been Baghdad's primary arms supplier and still has advisers in Iraq. Gorbachev met with the Iraqi foreign minister earlier in the week, and Bush may sound out Gorbachev on the Iraqi position. The two leaders last met in Washington in early June. Their first summit was at Malta last December.

DOC.HEAD: PLO Battles Abu Nidal Forces in Lebanon, 46 More Dead
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to UPDATE with new casualty figures, calls for cease-fire. Pickup 5th graf pvs `Police said ...'
DOC.TEXT: PLO forces shelled guerrillas loyal to terrorist Abu Nidal and battled hand-to-hand today in alleys during widening clashes that killed at least 46 people, police said. The Palestine Liberation Organization offensive to oust Abu Nidal's Fatah-Revolutionary Council from south Lebanon spread to areas around Sidon, a coastal city about 25 miles south of Beirut. Police report at least 163 people have been wounded since the latest battles began Friday. Abu Nidal's spokesman, Walid Khaled, said in a statement from Beirut that the group was ``ready to accept a cease-fire.'' Prime Minister Salim Hoss and leaders of Moslem factions also urged for a halt to the fighting. But loyalists of PLO chairman Yasser Arafat ignored the pleas and raided houses where Abu Nidal's men were believed to be hiding. Mortar shells and rocket-propelled grenades exploded on other suspected Abu Nidal strongholds. Police said shells fell at the rate of 20 a minute during some periods. An estimated 100 Abu Nidal guerrillas were entrenched in their last bastion about five miles east of Sidon. Also, pockets of Abu Nidal gunmen were still holding out in several parts of the sprawling Ein el-Hilweh shantytown, where an estimated 32,000 refugees live. PLO officers with bullhorns called on the rivals to, ``Surrender or die. There's no way out. Surrender if you want to survive.'' The response was volleys of automatic weapons fire. ``Abu Nidal's men are putting up tough resistance in the few places they still hold in the camp,'' said a police spokesman, who cannot be identified under briefing regulations. Abu Nidal, whose real name is Sabri al-Banna, broke away from the PLO in 1973 and was sentenced to death in absentia by a PLO tribunal for killing Arafat aides. He has been based in Iraq, Syria and Libya. His current headquarters are near Tripoli, Libya's capital. Abu Nidal is sought by the United States and some Western European nations for terrorist attacks over the last 15 years, including massacres at Rome and Vienna airports in December 1985 that killed at total of 20 people. He is also wanted in connection with the hijacking of a Pan American World Airways jet in Karachi, Pakistan, in September 1986. In that operation, 20 passengers were killed and 120 wounded. Security sources say Abu Nidal's faction has increasingly been allied with the Syrians, which has about 40,000 troops in Lebanon. Arafat, with about 5,000 guerrillas in south Lebanon, is seeking undisputed control over the Sidon region and ordered his forces to eliminate Abu Nidal loyalists. In June, Arafat's guerrillas crushed a 200-man Abu Nidal force in the Rashadiyeh refugee camp near Tyre, about 50 miles south of Sidon.

DOC.HEAD: Pilot Hurt in 2nd Helicopter Crash in As Many Days
DOC.TEXT: A U.S. Army helicopter crashed during a night training mission, and the pilot was hospitalized, U.S. military spokesmen said Saturday. It was the second such crash in two days. The OH-58 Kiowa scout helicopter went down about 9 p.m. Friday. On Thursday, a Marine Corps AH-1 Cobra gunship tipped over after a hard landing. The pilots of both aircraft suffered slight injuries. Both helicopters were on training missions, and their pilots were believed to be using night-vision equipment. Officers said they did not know if the special goggles, which have been criticized as contributing to a number of mishaps in recent years, were involved. The Kiowa, belonging to the 101st airborne division, crashed in the southern Arabian peninsula, the Army said. It gave no other details.

DOC.HEAD: US Protests Arrest of American in Yugoslavia
DOC.TEXT: The United States has protested to Yugoslavia the arrest and alleged beating of an American citizen charged with participating in a demonstration, the State Department said Saturday. Shaban Kastrati, 19, of Plainfield, Ill., was arrested in Kosovo province and sentenced on Aug. 31 to 60 days in prison for joining a demonstration and throwing rocks, State Department spokesman Dave Denny said. Denny said a formal protest was lodged with the Yugoslavian Foreign Ministry after a U.S. consular officer visited Kastrati in prison. The protest was based on Kastrati's account of mistreatment and the consular officer's observations, Denny said. The Washington Post, in its Saturday editions, quoted the youth's father, Mike Kastrati, as saying the consular officer had reported that the young Kastrati had a cut chin and lip and ``bruises all over his body.'' The Post said Kastrati was arrested Aug. 29 in the provincial capital of Pristina as he was driving home after going to Belgrade to welcome a U.S. congressional delegation led by Sen. Robert Dole, R-Kan. The older Kastrati said his American-born son had been staying with his grandparents in Kosovo, which has been hit by unrest between the ruling ethnic Serbian minority and ethnic Albanians.

DOC.HEAD: Barbara Bush Visits Scenic Town, Looks Forward To Seeing Raisa
DOC.TEXT: Barbara Bush strolled the narrow streets of this picturesque town, an ancient Viking haunt, and said she was looking forward to seeing Raisa Gorbachev and chatting about their grandchildren. Mrs. Bush spent a chilly Saturday afternoon in Porvoo while her husband met with Finnish President Mauno Koivisto in advance of Sunday's summit with Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev. In a bright cherry red suit, Mrs. Bush trod carefully over the cobblestones outside the 13th Century Lutheran Cathedral where Russian Tsar Alexander I declared in 1809 the autonomy of the Grand Duchy of Finland, then part of Russia. The white granite cathedral with red brick ornamental gables has survived centuries of plundering and fires, first by the Danes and later by the Russians. A Soviet bomb fell on it during World War II, but caused little damage. Mrs. Bush shook hands with about half the 300 local residents gathered outside the churchyard, hugged their babies, and joked that she wanted to keep one of them. The first lady walked along one of Porvoo's medieval shopping streets, admiring the old wooden buildings painted in bright shades of mustard, red and blue, some displaying American flags in her honor. In the local museum, she examined antique needlepoints and lamented that needlework was a lost art among American children. A display of jewelry crafted from human hair also caught her eye. This city of 20,000 people, a historically important trading post 35 miles northeast of the capital Helsinki, has long attracted Finnish painters and poets for its beauty. It was also a favorite of the Swedes when they controlled Finland, and Swedish is still the mother tongue of nearly half its residents, who call it Borga. The Gorbachevs arrived late Saturday afternoon for the summit. Mrs. Gorbachev and Mrs. Bush are to have tea Sunday morning and then view rare maps and books at the University of Helsinki, which is marking its 350th anniversary. While relations between Mrs. Gorbachev and former first lady Nancy Reagan were cool and sometimes testy, Mrs. Bush insisted Saturday that she and her Soviet counterpart are friends who have many common interests. ``I think it helps the husbands' relations if the wives are friends. It softens the road a little bit,'' she told reporters. ``We're both interested in our countries, we're interested in world peace,'' she said. ``On a very personal basis, I'm interested in her grandchildren and she's interested in mine. We have a lot to talk about.'' The first lady urged support for world leaders trying to dislodge ``that dreadful man,'' Iraqi President Saddam Hussein, from Kuwait. The Persian Gulf crisis sparked by Iraq's invasion and annexation of Kuwait has ``affected the lives of everyone in the world,'' Mrs. Bush said. ``Twenty-four countries have troops there, but those who don't are (also) affected. So this is a very important time. We should be backing our leaders with every bit of strength we have,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Scenes of John Paul's Seventh African Trip
LaserPhoto KIG1
DOC.TEXT: Pope John Paul II has impressed people around the world with his knack for languages. Besides his native Polish, the pontiff speaks fluent Italian and French and excels in German, Spanish and English. Now he's getting rave reviews for his Swahili. During his swing through Tanzania, the first stop in a four-nation African tour ending Monday in Ivory Coast, John Paul spoke mostly in English. But he delighted the crowds by including long passages in Swahili, the lingua franca of East Africa. Tanzanians said the pope's accent, pronunciation and delivery were impeccable, even clearer than his English. It was no accident. Vatican spokesman Joaquin Navarro explained that the pope prepares for all his trips abroad by listing to tapes of the local languages. He began practicing Swahili a month before this trip, his seventh to the continent. In Burundi and Rwanda, former Belgian protectorates in central Africa, the pope has spoken in French but also laced his homilies with brief expressions in Kirundi and Kinyarwanda. Sometimes the pope finds it difficult to hold the attention of his African flock since many are uneducated, rural people who do not understand English or French. For example, during a ceremony in Tabora, Tanzania, the 50,000 stadium seats were filled when the pope arrived. But once he launched into an English-language homily, a few thousand people, mostly youths, headed for the exits or milled around on the grass infield.

The pope's foreign trips are planned to the last detail, allowing little room for changes in the schedule. But John Paul is beginning to make a habit of paying impromptu visits to African villagers. In January, during a tour of the Sahel region, he stopped along a dirt road in Guinea Bissau and wandered into a hut to greet a man and his family. The pope was so struck by the living conditions that he remarked, ``Freedom is compromised by poverty.'' On Thurdsday, after celebrating Mass in Gitega, Burundi, the pope visited with a family in a relatively comfortable house, asking questions about the five children. Next, in a much poorer area a mile away, he stepped into a dark, rudimentary hut and embraced a small child.

John Paul is not always the only show in town. In Dar es Salaam, Tanzania, about 100,000 people showed up for his first Mass and many others tuned in on radio. But shortly after the pope rode off after the ceremony, the city's attention and radio dials turned to another national religion: soccer. Tanzania was playing Gabon in a qualifying round match of the Africa Cup of Nations at the National Stadium. For the record, the game ended in a scoreless draw. John Paul, an avid sportsman who played goalkeeper as a youngster in Poland, is not one to ignore the popularity of soccer. In Kigali on Saturday, he presented the ``John Paul II Cup'' to the winners of a 12-team national tournament held before his visit.

The pope's pilgrimage has taken him across one of Africa's most famous wildlife zones _ from the plains of Serengeti in Tanzania to the hills of Rwanda, home of rare mountain gorillas. John Paul has not taken time to visit any game parks, but he received a stuffed lion as a gift from a Masai warrior in Moshi, Tanzanzia, at the foot of Mount Kilimanjaro. The pope does not want to offend local sensibilities by refusing gifts, so the lion, along with the wood sculptures, fly wisks, handicraft, paintings and other more conventional offerings, was taken to the airport for loading onto his plane. But in the end, the lion was left behind, apparently because of lack of room.

DOC.HEAD: Nunn Says Time To Slow Committment Of U.S. Forces, Begin Rotation
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee said Saturday it is time to slow the deployment of American forces to the Middle East and to implement a rotation policy for troops already there. At the same time, the number of soldiers from Arab nations helping defend Saudi Arabia should be increased, said Sen. Sam Nunn, D-Ga. There are already more than 100,000 Americans in Saudi Arabia, he noted. ``I think we've got deterrence there now, and I believe the prime psychological and political benefit will come from getting more Arab forces in there,'' he said. Nunn, talking with reporters at a convention of the Georgia Democratic Party, said he does not advocate a cap on the size of the American force, but thinks a rotation system should be implemented to bring soldiers home. ``I think it's important that we understand those young men and women are going to get awfully bored and tired and gritty and dirty and hot, and we're going to have to have a rotation policy; I think three to four months, maybe five months _ but some set period of time. ``They need to be told they're going to rotate out of there. ... It is important psychologically. It's important to keep the morale. It's also important if we're going to demonstrate patience and tenacity.'' Nunn said he expected President Bush and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, meeting over the weekend in Finland, to discuss possible alternative action in the Middle East in case the embargo of Iraq fails. ``There has got to be a discussion of options and how we act,'' Nunn said. ``I certainly think we should not in any way be surprising the Soviet Union. They have been enormously helpful here.'' He added: ``I think that Bush needs to have a frank discussion of what we do down the road. I also believe that if we do have to take military steps down the road, it ought to be done as much as possible ... with other countries participating. That's why I keep pushing for getting the Egyptians in there with heavy forces, getting the Syrians in there with heavy forces.''

Here is a transcript of Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's remarks Saturday as he arrived for his summit with President Bush: Mr. President and Mrs. Koivisto let me very warmly thank you and through you the friendly people of Finland for your hospitality, for receiving us, and for once again agreeing to participate in a very important event. It is very symbolic that this important meeting between the president of the Soviet Union and the president of the United States will be taking place in Helsinki, which saw the birth of some very important trends, very important developments which are evolving today and which are gaining, acquiring further prospects. President George Bush expressed a wish for us to meet here at this crucial moment in history when it is very important to compare our political approaches and to cooperate in order to protect the positive trends evolving in the world today, to make sure that they are not thwarted by any development. And I was pleased to accept that invitation, and given the rapid agreement of the government of Finland, we are now here. And I hope that this meeting will be successful. It is important for us to meet personally, although we have been in touch in various ways through our personal representatives and in various other ways. But it is necessary to meet in order to discuss the acute crisis in the Persian Gulf and a number of other issues. And I would like to conclude my brief remarks by expressing the very warm wishes to the people of Finland from all the peoples of the Soviet Union. I wish prosperity to your country. Thank you.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Troops Change Camp Name, Remove Crosses to Accommodate Saudis
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: All-American Base Camp, home to members of the Army's 82nd airborne, disappeared from the map last week. From now on it's Champion City, the desert base camp for soldiers from Fort Bragg, N.C. Military officials said the Saudi government, which is trying to keep a wide distance between American troops and Saudi citizens, asked for the name change. Other U.S. military outposts in the eastern desert have similiar nicknames. Dragon City is the Army's 18th Airborne Corps headquarters. The dragon is the corps' emblem. Falcon Forward Base Camp and Eagle Forward Base Camp are home to the 101st Airborne air assault units. They are also known as the Screaming Eagles. The Defense Department has barred reporters from pinpointing locations of troops so the desert camps are always ``Somewhere in Saudi Arabia.''

Dragon City's medical clinic has been stripped of red crosses, the emblem of the international relief organization. Saudi officials insisted the Americans remove the crosses, also a symbol in Christian religions. Saudi Arabia's version of the Red Cross relief organization is the Red Crescent society, marked by a red sliver of the moon. All religions except for Islam are barred in Saudi Arabia; two of Islam's holiest mosques are in Medina and Mecca and draw pilgrims from around the world every year. Some medical units have not gotten the word on red crosses. The 28th combat support hospital still has them on its temporary structures.

When a congressional delegation passed through Saudi Arabia this week, Marines in the field took the opportunity to complain about a few things. Most griped about the time it takes to get a letter. One Marine said he couldn't get cigarettes. ``Here is a good time to kick it,'' Lt. Gen. Walter Boomer said of the habit.

When the going gets tough, the tough go shopping at Safeway. That's where members of the 82nd Airborne went last week to buy sponges and cleaning supplies for the barracks. Although Saudi Arabia is a traditional Islamic society, its large expatriate community has brought with it Western-style stores like Safeway and a mall with T-shirt shops and stores that sell other clothes.

DOC.HEAD: Home on the Range
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 17th graf, `You better...', to FIX you're to your. Also sent for PMs.
EDITORS NOTE
DOC.TEXT: The 265th Quartermaster Detachment of the South Carolina National Guard is one of the reserve units called up for possible duty in Saudi Arabia. National Writer Fred Bayles is following the 14 Guardsmen as they prepare for deployment overseas.

It looks like Christmas gone mad. Plastic soldier targets, lit like holiday lawn ornaments, are under assault. Orange tracers slice through them like death rays. Bullets ricochet and flare with brief rose-colored intensity. A bush catches fire, illuminating the night. The 265th Quartermaster Detachment, a water purification unit of the South Carolina National Guard, is practicing night fire, another skill they needed for duty in the Mideast. Some of the 14 men, all from the environs of Allendale, S.C., are exhilarated by the sound and light show they have staged. ``We are ready! We are ready!'' shouted Don Graham, a construction supervisor, as they drove back to the barracks through the sultry night. Some of the other men had already fallen asleep. There was little enthusiasm earlier in the day as the 265th, a collection of civilians that includes construction workers, prison guards, a truck driver and a college student, spent a long, hot and dusty afternoon on the range, sweating, swearing and firing at pop-up targets that sometimes failed to pop-up. The day begins with an almost picnic quality. The air is filled with dragonflies and vibrant orange and yellow butterflies that flitter and land on the flat black muzzles of the M-16s. There is even a picnic lunch of MRE's _ Meals, Ready-to-Eat _ book-sized foil packages that come in a variety of flavors. One of the many delicacies is tuna with noodles, a lukewarm glop of casserole that comes with separate packages of: _Fortified cheese spread (knead package before opening) _Crackers _Chocolate nut cake _Beverage base powder, grape. As the name implies, you open the packages and eat. But there are table manners to be learned. You can heat the meal by placing the package in the sun. And you might want to think twice about putting the grape mix in your canteen. ``You better be sure you like it cause your water's going to taste like that forever,'' warns Sgt. Earnest Deloach. But haute cuisine only goes so far. The bucolic scene becomes oppressive as the day grows long and the temperature soars into the 90s. Worst of all, the unit must don hellishly hot chemical protective overclothes and the ever-present gas mask and try to knock down targets. Bullets fly wide and heads ache from the Kevlar helmets. You feel like the helmet has melted through your softened skull and imbedded itself in your brain. ``My head hurts, I'm covered with dirt, I'm sweated through. The only way I'm going to make it is if the good Lord lets me,'' said Spec. Ulysses Calhoun as he struggled out of his chemical warfare suit. ``The targets just aren't falling,'' says Spec. Mark Rooker. Rooker, 20, is the youngest and newest member of the unit. When the other men stop to check out female personnel, Rooker wanders over to check out the tanks and armored personnel carriers. He carries a large survival knife on his web gear and asks hopefully about getting an M-203 grenade launcher for his rifle. Rooker wanted to join a National Guard firefighters unit, but his training school would have interfered with college. So he took a less exciting option, the 265th water purification unit. It has turned out to be anything but boring. ``I could be home right now, working in an air conditioned bank,'' he said. ``I guess I made a mistake.''

DOC.HEAD: Egypt Pledges More Troops To Aid Saudis, Sound Impatient Note
DOC.TEXT: Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak pledged more troops Saturday to defend Saudi Arabia against an Iraqi attack and registered doubt President Saddam Hussein could be stripped of his most dangerous weapons through diplomacy. Speaking to reporters after a 90-minute private session with Secretary of State James A. Baker III at the opulent Ras-El-Tin Palace on the Mediterranean, the Egyptian leader recommitted the largest Arab nation to the U.S.-engineered drive to pressure Saddam to reverse his Aug. 2 takeover of Kuwait. ``We are supporting the Saudis as much as we can,'' Mubarak said, referring to the 2,000 Egyptian troops now in Saudi Arabia and his drive to rally Arab opposition to the Iraqi leader. Having held further discussions with the Saudis, Mubarak said, ``we will send them the forces needed, which is agreed upon. We sent some forces now. We are intending to send other forces in the very near future.'' Baker flew from Egypt to Helsinki to join President Bush in talks Sunday with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. The main topic is the Gulf crisis. Mubarak urged the two leaders to stand firm on the sanctions voted by the U.N. Security Council. ``I hope that Gorbachev and Bush have one line for dealing with this problem,'' Mubarak said. ``This would be a hell of problem in this area if there are differences.'' Saddan's invasion has swept away traditional Egyptian and Saudi reluctance to line up overtly with the United States. Their strong stand against Iraq, reinforced by a multi-billion dollar Saudi contribution, has encouraged such Arab states as Morocco, Syria and the Persian Gulf emirates to participate in an anti-Iraqi coalition. Mubarak was rewarded this week by the Bush administration with a promise to forgive $7 billion in debts to the United States for arms purchases. ``Let me simply state for the record how very appreciative and pleased the United States is with the outstanding and courageous leadership that you have demonstrated from the very beginning of this crisis in the Persian Gulf,'' Baker said. Asked by a reporter if there could be peace in the Persian Gulf so long as Saddam had nuclear and chemical war-making potential, Mubarak replied: ``You know we are against chemical weapons, against the presence of missiles because this is a very destructive means. I think peace will never go with the presence of all these forms of weapons in the area.'' The United States and its supporters, in trying to harness Saddam, are relying primarily on an economic boycott. The goal is to weaken the Iraqi economy to the point Saddam will withdraw his troops from Kuwait and restore the monarchy. But Mubarak showed impatience. Asked how long sanctions should be employed before resorting to military action, Mubarak said: ``It is a matter of estimation _ one, or two or three months. It may last only one month, maybe two months. But I'm telling you that doesn't mean it's going to stay for one year.'' Baker's meeting with Mubarak concluded a three-day trip to the Middle East in which the secretary of state raised several billion dollars. At the same time, Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady was asking for money in visits to world leaders in Paris, London, Seoul, South Korea and Tokyo. The United States is trying to raise more than $25 billion to defray the costs of the American military buildup in the Persian Gulf and provide emergency assistance to Egypt, Jordan and Turkey, three countries which have been hard hit by the trade embargo against Iraq. Officials traveling with Brady said the United States hopes to get $3.5 billion to the three ``front-line'' countries before the end of 1990, with some funds arriving before the end of September to meet urgent needs such as refugee resettlement. Another $7 billion would be disbursed to those countries through the 12 months of 1991. The remaining $15 billion or so would go to reimburse the United States for the $1 billion-a-month cost of the Persian Gulf military buildup, the officials said.

DOC.HEAD: Stasi, Jobless, Revolutionaries, Failing Companies Share One Stage
DOC.TEXT: For two years, a small army of East German secret police kept an intimidating vigil outside the home of Katja Havemann, a revolutionary long before there was a revolution. Ms. Havemann ultimately helped lead the protests that toppled the old government. On Saturday, she kept her own vigil inside the former headquarters of the dreaded secret police, demanding to see the records they kept on her. She was among 22 people who on Tuesday began occupying the building that houses the secret files that the Stasi, as the force was called, maintained on 6 million Germans. The activists have vowed to remain until both German governments promise that the records will not be turned over to West Germany's secret service when the two nations unite. But the protest wasn't the only thing going on Saturday at the giant complex of buildings where the Communist regime's brutal security service kept the population in check. On a cool, cloudy day, the headquarters of the feared Stasi was a montage reflecting 40 years of oppression and one year of chaos, a microcosm of the vanishing nation's dark past, troubled present and uncertain future. A West Berlin property speculator prowled the grounds, looking at some of the vacant buildings he hoped to buy now and sell later. ``I consider myself quite ethical,'' said the developer, who spoke on the condition he not be identified. ``There is money to be made here, but these people don't know how to do it.'' As he drove away in a red Mercedes-Benz, workers hauled building materials into one of the 30 buildings on the sprawling grounds. The building has been used as an unemployment office for the last two months, and workers were dropping off materials to renovate some of the rooms to accommodate the growing crush of job seekers. More than 2 million of the nation's 8 million workers are either unemployed or working shortened hours. ``We probably see 1,000 people a day now,'' said Horst Nitsche, who works as a receptionist and was overseeing the delivery Saturday of the building materials. In a parking lot across the street, a small bazaar was set up by merchants hawking everything from smoked eel to sweat socks. Textile companies offered their unsold clothing, farmers peddled wares that have been nudged off grocery store shelves by West German products, and Christian Geissler displayed shoes made by his struggling company in the southern city of Rosswein. Geissler, who runs the factory of 450 workers, said he and a small staff made the three-hour drive to remind East Berliners that the factory is still pumping out loafers and wingtips. East Germans have been buying goods from West German firms, and Geissler said his company's survival is in doubt. ``Next year will tell,'' he said. ``We've been lucky so far. But survival, now, is the main thing.'' Nearby, Olaf Ulaemst sold Chinese-made radios, jewelry and toys. He bought the goods from an East German importer who can no longer get them into East German stores, which now stock Japanese- and Western-made products. In front of another building, members of the New Forum civic group that led the revolution passed out leaflets. The group is not only demanding public access to the secret police files, but the dismissal of the hundreds of former intelligence agents still working for the government. Ms. Havemann, one of the people occupying the file archives, came out briefly. She was a prominent dissident for more than a decade before the peaceful revolt last autumn. She said hundreds of police and Stasi agents surrounded her and her husband's home during a 2{-year period when they were under house arrest. ``We have to resolve this in a good way,'' she said of the Stasi files. ``If we don't do it in a good way, the old way will come back into the new Germany.''

DOC.HEAD: Refugees, Hostages, Diplomats Face Hardship; U.S. Flight Scheduled
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS one graf after 13th `Arriving today...' to UPDATE with Gorbachev arrival statement; pickup 14th pvs `Moscow said...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos NY11,12,13
DOC.TEXT: Hunger and hardship grew today for stranded refugees in Jordan as well as among diplomats and other foreigners holed up in Kuwait, whose Iraqi occupiers faced further pressure from a U.S.-Soviet summit this weekend. Iraqi President Saddam Hussein told President Bush and Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev to remember when they meet that ``Iraq did not invade with its armies either of your countries.'' ``I am not saying to you...what your decision should be,'' Saddam said in a statement read by an announcer on Iraqi television. The comments were billed as an open message to the two leaders before they meet in Helsinki, Finland. Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak also looked ahead to the Sunday summit. He said after meeting with Secretary of State James A. Baker III today that he hoped the United States and the Soviet Union could take a unified approach to the gulf crisis. ``I hope that Gorbachev and Bush have one line for dealing with this problem,'' Mubarak said in English. Mubarak, who has been reluctant to discuss the size of the Egyptian force deployed in the gulf region, said ``we intend to send other forces in the very near future.'' He gave no details. Another freedom flight of Americans was expected out of Kuwait today, a day after Saddam's government allowed 165 Americans and some other foreigners to leave, the latest flights in the week-old airlift.
