Iraq said today it would halt chartered flights to Amman, Jordan, beginning Sunday because of Jordanian complaints they are overwhelmed by the influx. But a spokesman for Amman's airport, Mashhour El-Kurashi, said crowding at the airport was not a problem. Another possible motivation for the cutoff emerged when the Iraqi spokesman, Naji al-Hadithi, suggested that the short-haul charters to Amman were relatively unprofitable for Iraqi Airways. The Iraqi spokesman said regularly scheduled flights would continue to leave normally, and the State Department said charters to evacuate foreigners would continue as well, with destinations other than Amman. Five weeks after Iraq invaded Kuwait, thousands of Americans and other Westerners remain trapped in the two countries. Many are held as human shields if war breaks out. Swedish and Norwegian diplomats today evacuated their embassies in Kuwait but said they defied Saddam's order to officially close them. Iraqi troops have surrounded the U.S. and other compounds, where diplomats running low on supplies have been drinking boiled swimming pool water and using furniture for firewood. Arriving today in Helsinki, Bush told reporters he hoped the summit will ``strengthen our common approach to this unjustifiable act of aggression.'' In his arrival statement today, Gorbachev said the summit was necessary to ensure that international actions against Iraq ``are not thwarted by any developments.'' Moscow said Friday that it would be willing to provide troops for a U.N. peacekeeping force in the Persian Gulf _ if they were under a joint command that included Soviet generals. Financial support for the effort to counter Saddam's Aug. 2 invasion of oil-rich Kuwait grew by the billions Friday. Pledges came from Japan, South Korea and Kuwait, whose exiled leaders promised $5 billion. Saudi Arabia pledged several billion Thursday. In Dhahran, Saudi Arabia, a U.S. military spokesman said one pilot was hospitalized and a second escaped unhurt when a U.S. Army helicopter crashed during a night training mission. The crash of the OH-58 Kiowa Scout helicopter Friday evening was the second in two days. A Marine Corps AH-1 Cobra gunship tipped over after a hard landing 24 hours earlier, slightly injuring both pilots. About 100,000 U.S. troops are dug into the Saudi desert south of the Kuwaiti border at an estimated cost of $1 billion a month, facing an estimated 260,000 Iraqi soldiers in and around Kuwait. Scores of U.S. and other warships in the Persian Gulf region are enforcing a U.N.-sanctioned embargo against the Baghdad government. U.S. forces gained more momentum today when five amphibious landing craft passed through Egypt's Suez Canal toward the gulf region, bringing the total number since Monday to 12. Saddam, who seized Kuwait in a dispute over oil, land and money, has called on Moslems to wage a holy war against the United States and its allies in the gulf crisis. A Jordanian border official said 225,000 Egyptian refugees were waiting to cross from Iraq but that Jordan was holding them back because it was overwhelmed by the 100,000 refugees already stranded in its desert. ``They are waiting under terrible conditions for permission to cross into Jordan to continue their journey home,'' the official said, who cannot be identified under regulations. ``But we cannot cope with such huge numbers before the Asian evacuees already inside Jordan waiting for transportation to their homes are shifted,'' he added. James N. Purcell, director of the International Organization for Migration, appealed urgently in Jordan for ships and aircraft to repatriate the Asians squatting in hot and dirty camps ``before human suffering becomes a human tragedy.'' The United States said Friday that it will dispatch 27,000 tons of rice, vegetable oil and wheat flour worth $12 million to the camps, Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter said in Washington. The food is to be shipped from ports by Sept. 30, a statement issued by the department said. Other countries have pledged millions of dollars in relief, but distribution has been slow. In Kuwait, a few foreign embassies _ including the U.S. mission _ were still defying a 2-week-old Iraqi order to shut their doors. But without power, water, telephone service or food, the diplomats were being forced to retreat. The embassies have tried to stay open in part to avoid the appearance of having accepted Iraq's annexation of the emirate, in part to try to provide protection to their citizens. About 2,200 Americans remain in Iraq and Kuwait, U.S. officials estimate. But there was less and less they could do to help. Americans arriving in the Jordanian capital of Amman on Friday aboard a U.S.-chartered Iraqi Airways jet described desperate conditions. ``Until I felt my feet on freedom, it was just terrifying,'' said Elena Reyes of Los Angeles. ``I didn't know night and day when they would come and knock down my door.'' ``It's terrible there,'' said Patricia Hammer of Denver. ``People are frightened, they're in hiding, running out of food.'' State Department spokesman Mark Dillen said U.S. officials hoped another group of Americans would leave Kuwait for Amman today, and fly to Charleston, S.C., later during the weekend, along with Friday's 165 arrivals. Of the Iraqi order to halt charter flights to Amman starting Sunday, a State Department spokesman said today: ``The evacuation flights will continue.'' The spokesman said a charter flight on Sunday was to fly from Baghdad to London, which might be a new destination for the freedom flights. Dillen said Iraqi authorities continued to round up American men and have nearly 90 in detention. He said the latest addition to the list was an American man picked up Thursday in Kuwait with his non-American wife. He was subsequently taken to Baghdad. Kuwait's government-in-exile told Baker in Saudi Arabia on Friday that it would help bankroll the military effort. A day earlier, Saudi Arabia had pledged several billion dollars toward defraying the cost of the U.S. deployment. Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady, wrapping up a mission that took him to Paris, London, Seoul and Tokyo, said Friday that Japan and South Korea gave new assurances of support for the campaign against Iraq. European Community ministers in Rome Friday offered no money for the military effort, though individual West European nations have committed ships to the gulf flotilla. The ministers agreed to give $2 billion in economic aid to Turkey, Jordan and Egypt to compensate them for trade lost as a result of the U.N. sanctions against Iraq. They also granted more food and other emergency aid for refugees.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Suggests Possible U.S.-Soviet Oil Swap to Help Both Superpowers
DOC.TEXT: President Bush on Saturday raised the possibility of a unique superpower swap: American state-of-the-art oil technology for some of the Soviet Union's vast, untapped crude resources. ``I have no problem with that at all,'' Bush said en route to the Finnish capital for his summit Sunday with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the third high-powered meeting between the two leaders. ``I would welcome the best in American know-how on oil production, drilling and seismic work going to the Soviet Union,'' he told reporters aboard Air Force One. ``I think it is something we can work closely (on) with the Soviet Union.'' Bush said he had mentioned the idea to the Soviet leader and that they might discuss it further at their one-day summit, which is expected to focus mostly on the Persian Gulf crisis. Such an exchange could serve the needs of both countries. The United States, with ample supplies of sophisticated petroleum technology, is thirsty for oil, even more so since the Persian Gulf crisis has shut off millions of barrels of crude to consuming nations. But unlike West Germany, it doesn't have the cash to funnel into development projects badly needed by the Kremlin to shore up its sagging economy. The Soviet Union, the world's largest oil producer, is desperate for the revenues, which would flow from an upgraded petroleum industry. ``It's a good trade,'' said Allen Sinai, chief economist at the Boston Co. ``They have the resources, and we have the know-how.'' John Lichtblau, chairman of the Petroleum Industry Research Foundation in New York, said, ``It's definitely a good idea. There's nothing negative about it.'' He also noted that ``any increase in oil production in the world would lower dependence on the Middle East.'' The suggestion comes at a time of a world oil crunch caused by the international embargo on 4 million barrels a day of Iraqi and Kuwaiti crude. The economic sanctions were imposed by the United Nations after Iraq invaded and occupied its tiny, oil-rich neighbor on Aug. 2. Saudi Arabia, the world's No. 1 crude exporter, and other members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries have agreed to pump as much as they can to make up the shortfall. But analysts predict there still will be a gap on the market that could widen with colder weather in the coming months in the United States and other consuming nations. However, analysts said, any deal worked out with the Soviet Union to bring more oil into the United States was unlikely to do much to alleviate possible shortages this year. The Soviet Union produced 12.1 million barrels of oil a day last year, which amounted to a sixth of the world's total and more than the combined output of Saudi Arabia, Iraq and Kuwait. But analysts expect Soviet output, crimped by an outmoded system, to tumble by about a half million barrels a day this year. It exported 3.7 million barrels a day _ second only to Saudi Arabia _ with about half going to Western buyers. With oil prices soaring because of the gulf crisis, Moscow will likely earn a windfall this year of hundreds of millions of dollars. Every $1 a barrel increase could mean $1 billion a year in additional hard currency for the Soviet economy, according to analysts' estimates. In 1989, oil exports brought some $20 billion in hard currency into the Soviet Union, accounting for about 40 percent of the country's hard currency earnings. Even before Bush's suggestion, the Kremlin had begun eyeing Western oil companies to help expand the country's oil exploration and improve production facilities, deteriorating from years of neglect. ``The Soviet Union doesn't know how to bring oil out of the ground, to refine it and ship it,'' said Sinai. Both Chevron Corp. and Texaco Corp. have reached preliminary agreement with the Soviets on joint oil exploratory ventures. American service companies also are participating in oil exploration with the Soviets, as is the French oil company Elf Aquitaine.

DOC.HEAD: Eight Killed in Fighting Among Blacks
DOC.TEXT: Eight black men were shot, stabbed or burned to death in a series of attacks around the country, police said Saturday. Police said four men were killed in Soweto and two died in Tokoza, two townships outside Johannesburg that have been hit hard by the black factional fighting that has claimed almost 600 lives since it began Aug. 12. Two men were killed in separate attacks in the eastern province of Natal, police said in the daily unrest report, which covers incidents from the previous 24 hours. Most of the fighting in the Johannesburg area has pitted Zulu backers of the conservative Inkatha movement against Xhosas and other blacks loyal to the African National Congress. However, there also apparently have been random attacks in recent days with no clear link to the factional fighting. The ANC and Inkatha blame each other for the fighting. The ANC alleges police have sided with Inkatha, further fueling the violence. Government and police leaders have said individual officers may have acted improperly but that the police force as a whole has remained impartial. Both black groups oppose apartheid, but they differ over tactics and plans for a future South Africa. The more militant ANC waged a guerrilla campaign for 29 years before suspending operations last month. The organization still supports sanctions, strikes, boycotts and other confrontational measures that Inkatha does not endorse. Inkatha, led by Mangosuthu Buthelezi and made up almost entirely of Zulus, favors capitalism in contrast to the socialist-oriented ANC. The two sides have been fighting for supremacy since 1986 in the eastern province of Natal, and about 5,000 people have been killed in the violence. The ANC has been leading the fight for an end to apartheid and President F.W. de Klerk's government has been holding preliminary talks with the group to clear the way for negotiations on ending white-minority rule. The anti-apartheid Democratic Party said Saturday it wants to join the government and the ANC in future negotiations. De Klerk has said all opposition groups would be welcome for formal constitutional talks, which he hopes to begin soon. The Democrats hold 33 of the 166 elected seats in the white chamber of Parliament. De Klerk's National Party has 94 seats and the pro-apartheid Conservative Party has 39 seats. The Democrats are not expected to play a central role in any political settlement, but the party is seen as a barometer of liberal, white opinion and could form an alliance with another organization. De Klerk says he wants to replace the apartheid system of racial segregation with a constitution that would allow the 5 million whites and 30 million blacks to share power. But he wants guarantees for whites under any further black-majority government. Blacks now have no voice in national affairs.

DOC.HEAD: People In The News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: Singer Luther Vandross wants to make sure he has a hot show this week in Detroit. Vandross likes to keep the air conditioning turned down because the cold air affects his voice, Brass Ring Productions spokesman Jeff Elwood said. ``He likes to sing in warm buildings,'' Elwood said. ``He believes he does a better show when it's off.'' At the time of his last show in Detroit, two weeks ago, the temperature outside was in the 80s. Fans may be a little more comfortable the end of this week when Vandross returns to Detroit for three days _ the temperature will be only in the middle 70s.

Pop singer Madonna, artist David Hockney, Rep. Henry Waxman and British actor Ian McKellen were honored for their efforts to combat AIDS during a fund-raiser organizers said generated more than $1 million. Among the performers at Friday night's show were Madonna, violinist Joshua Bell, and singers Rod Stewart, Sarah Brightman and Toni Childs. ``AIDS is about living people, not just cases,'' said Waxman, D-Calif., chairman of the House Subcommittee on Health and the Environment. David Wexler, chairman of AIDS Project Los Angeles, said the event raised more than $1,150,000 for the 8-year-old nonprofit organization. Others attending included Henry Winkler, Susan Blakely, Marlee Matlin, Bette Midler, Angela Lansbury, Gregory Harrison and Lynn and Vanessa Redgrave. ``Someone asked me why we're all doing this tonight. Slowly but surely, everyone will be touched by this,'' Winkler said.

Rising country music star Garth Brooks says he met his wife, Sandy, when he broke up a fight she was involved in at a nightclub in Stillwater, Okla. Brooks, a finalist for five Country Music Association awards this year, said in an interview that he was a bouncer at the nightspot in 1983 when he was summoned to halt a dispute in the women's restroom. ``These two gals had her cornered ...,'' Brooks recalled. ``She took a swing at this one ol' gal and missed her. But her fist went through the pressed-wood stall and she couldn't get it back out. ``She was just madder than a hornet.'' Brooks removed her fist and threw her out of the club. But he later began telephoning her and they were married in 1986. Brooks' hit records include ``If Tomorrow Never Comes'' and ``The Dance.'' He is a finalist for the CMA's male vocalist of the year, single of the year, song of the year, Horizon Award and video of the year.
DOC.NOTE: Eds: A version moved on the sports wire.
DOC.TEXT: Oakland A's outfielder Jose Canseco almost didn't make it to the outfield at all, thanks to one of those notorious New York cab drivers. Canseco left the team's hotel about 4:45 p.m. Friday in order to arrive at Yankee Stadium in the Bronx for a 7:30 game. The trip north out of Manhattan would take about 30 minutes by subway. It took Canseco more than two hours. ``The cab driver thought I said Shea Stadium,'' Canseco said after the A's beat the Yankees 7-1. Shea is in the borough of Queens. ``We were about 10 minutes from Shea when I realized the mistake. I said: `Take me to Yankee Stadium.' ``The fare was $60, but he told me to make it half. He was lucky to get that. You know the way New York is. There was massive traffic. Everyone beeps their horn. And the language, it was atrocious.''

Entertainer Tony Orlando feels something special for those yellow ribbons, the ubiquitous symbol of hope for loved ones held captive. The singer known for ``Tie a Yellow Ribbon Round the Old Oak Tree'' said in a telephone interview Friday that he discovered the song's deep emotional effect shortly after it was released. It was in 1973, and the group Dawn, featuring Orlando as lead singer, was the opening act at a Bob Hope show at the Cotton Bowl in Dallas. About 400 or 500 former prisoners of war were seated in front of the stage. The song is based on a Civil War story about the homecoming of a Union soldier from a Confederate prison. In the song, the man is welcomed by yellow ribbons as he comes home from a stint in prison. The message moved the former POWs. ``I'm on stage and I'm singing this song and all of a sudden it was the most spine-chilling moment ...,'' he said. ``Up they got, off their chairs, and they're coming toward the stage and they come on stage and they begin to sing the song.'' Orlando said Friday's interview with The Sun Herald of Biloxi, Miss., was the first he'd ever done about the song, and said the Iraq-Kuwait crisis was the reason. ``Normally, I duck it,'' he said. ``This is a different situation. I just feel that we're in a posture of war. They've got like 2,000 people there still, who are hostages.''

DOC.HEAD: Youth Charged With Raping, Murdering His Mother
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Note contents.
DOC.TEXT: A 19-year-old man is accused of raping his mother and beating her to death with a baseball bat after she tried to stop him from sexually assaulting a 4-year-old child, police said. Andy Leon Vigil is charged with first-degree murder, aggravated sexual assault and rape of a child in a complaint filed in court Friday. Vigil was arrested after his mother, Juanita Vigil Madragil, 40, was found unconscious in her central city apartment last Sunday. She later died of head injuries at LDS Hospital. Detectives believe the mother found Vigil in a bedroom of her home, molesting a 4-year-old girl for whom she was baby-sitting, and confronted him, said police Lt. Norm Thompson. Thompson said the man turned on his mother, clubbed her with a baseball bat, raped her, then beat her with the bat. Vigil is being held in the Salt Lake County Jail in lieu of $500,000 bail.

DOC.HEAD: Economic Task Force Heads off Confrontation Between Yeltsin and Gorbachev
DOC.TEXT: A task force on economic reform will let the national legislature resolve policy differences between political rivals Mikhail S. Gorbachev and Boris Yeltsin, a top official said Saturday. The Soviet president and Yeltsin, president of the republic of Russia, had ordered the task force to come up with a single plan for the economy before Monday's opening session of the national parliament. Their representatives decided late Friday to leave key points of disagreement for the national and republic parliaments to resolve, said Anatoly Lukyanov, chairman of the national Supreme Soviet legislature. Lukyanov said the task force ``will present a unified plan with alternatives on several issues.'' He refused to discuss the points of disagreement. The news agency Tass quoted Russian Prime Minister Ivan Silaev as saying the national plan called for price increases and maintaining centralized control over the economy, while the Russian plan did not. Yeltsin has said that Russia will go ahead with radical economic reform on its own if Gorbachev and national authorities continue to delay. Since Russia is the largest Soviet republic _ with half the country's people and three-quarters of its land _ the Kremlin had to take Yeltsin's warning seriously. Russia's Supreme Soviet legislature is to debate its radical plan starting Monday and may adopt it Tuesday. It calls for eliminating the Kremlin's authority to levy taxes, among other changes. Russia would immediately legalize private ownership of land under the plan. Lukyanov, speaking at a news conference Saturday, said the national legislature would not act on the task force proposal until it has been discussed in each of the 15 republics' parliaments. Lukyanov also said 13 bills on economic reform have already been sent to parliamentary committees for review. He said they include draft laws on protection of individual property and inventions, pricing, entrepreneurship, banking, use of foreign currency, employment, customs, social security, insurance, foreign investment and support for invalids and other disadvantaged groups. Other bills on the Supreme Soviet agenda for the coming session include one that would guarantee freedom to emigrate and to travel. The United States has refused to grant the Soviet Union preferential trade treatment until it enacts such a law. Legislation on freedom of religion and creation of public organizations and political parties also will be considered, Lukyanov said.

DOC.HEAD: National Police Press Spokesman Murdered in Bogota
DOC.TEXT: Assailants shot to death the chief spokesman for Colombia's national police Saturday when he resisted an attempt to steal his car, police said. Col. Alfonso Obispo, chief press officer at the national police, was shot to death in northern Bogota, a police spokesman told The Associated Press by telephone. The spokesman asked not to be identified, a standard practice at police headquarters. He said the three suspects escaped. Two police officers were killed Friday during a guerrilla ambush in a rural region of eastern Colombia, the spokesman said. About 60 leftist guerrillas ambushed a police convoy with gunfire, killing two officers and wounding another two, he said. The spokesman said the guerrillas likely belonged to the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, the country's largest rebel outfit.

DOC.HEAD: Budget Bargainers Get Seclusion, Private Rooms at Maryland Airfield
DOC.TEXT: Just 10 miles from the U.S. Capitol but light years from its distractions and temptations, bargainers at this year's down-to-the-wire budget talks have found a nice, quiet home. Quiet, that is, if you don't mind the roar of an occasional Air Force F-4D fighter or a squadron of helicopters taking off and landing. The 6,840-acre base has 129 aircraft, 28,010 personnel and is home to Air Force One, the president's jet. Budget bargaining began Friday at the base, which was built in 1943 and until now was best known for all those shots of presidents or other world leaders waving from the doorways of airplanes. White House Budget Director Richard Darman and the chief Democratic negotiator, House Majority Leader Richard Gephardt, D-Mo., selected Andrews because reporters and lobbyists could be kept away from the bargainers. In addition, lawmakers in the bargaining room would not be tempted to leave because of a meeting with a constituent, lunch with a lobbyist or the lure of a bank of television cameras. Because the negotiators want to fashion a budget deal by Monday, Andrews offered another attraction: free room and board, so the talks could start early and go late. Rep. Silvio Conte, R-Mass., one of the bargainers, said each private dorm room had a kitchenette and, he said with a smile, was ``like a first-class hotel.'' But apparently not all of his colleagues saw the same luxury Conte did. Of the 21 lawmakers and the two or three administration officials involved in the bargaining, only seven of them stayed overnight Friday, an aide said.

The negotiations are being held in what is normally the main bar and restaurant of the Andrews officers' club, a sprawling, single-story brick and glass building reminiscent of a suburban high school. Next door are two single-story bungalows done in tan stucco. Republicans are using the Essex House as their conference area; Democrats have been assigned Shelton Manor. In appearance, neither one recalls the English countryside. The officers' club bar has large, potted plants around its perimeter, large speakers and a large-screen television, and an orange-brown rug that one participant says give it the feel of a billiards room. There is no built-in bar table.

Before the talks began Friday morning, reporters had their equipment inspected by the Secret Service and were then herded onto buses to be taken from the press center to the officers' club, about two miles away. When they got there, they were herded again into a roped-off portion of the parking lot in front of the officers' club. Gradually, cars bearing House and Senate members and their aides began pulling up, and reporters beckoned to them to come to the microphones. At one point, Sens. Pete Domenici, R-N.M., and Phil Gramm, R-Texas, obliged and answered questions. One Andrews public relations officer shook his head at the sight of reporters shouting one question after another at the lawmakers. ``If these were generals, I'd say, `Thank you, sirs,''' he told a congressional aide, referring to the remark press secretaries often make to end news conferences. The congressional staff worker responded, ``You don't do that to politicians.''

Several minutes later, Gephardt answered some questions and disappeared into the officers' club to await the arrival of President Bush. The president was not scheduled to speak, and White House officials told congressional aides to disconnect and remove the microphones before his arrival. The aides only had time to remove the public address system when the presidential motorcade pulled up. Unexpectedly, Bush bounded out of his limousine and marched right up to the microphones, where he spoke briefly before entering the building. With the public address system no longer working, most of the reporters in the crowd had to compare notes with their colleagues who had been close enough to the president to hear what he actually said. Or, presumably, they had to read his lips.

The budget talks began in May and got virtually nowhere by the time they broke off in early August for Congress' summer recess. At the time, jokes were heard about how the negotiators had discussed everything but the shape of the bargaining table, a reference to a stumbling block during the Paris peace talks on the Vietnam War. Well, the budget bargainers now have discussed the shape of the table _ and done something about it. The bargaining table originally was laid out in a U-shaped configuration. But it didn't take long for people to realize that the acoustics in the large room made hearing difficult. The solution: the table was reconfigured into a square.

DOC.HEAD: Foundation to Review Decision to Stop Funding Planned Parenthood
DOC.TEXT: A retailer's charitable foundation will review the decision to end 22 years of donations to Planned Parenthood, a decision that prompted some customers to destroy their credit cards in protest. In August, the Dayton Hudson Foundation turned down Planned Parenthood's request for $20,000 for family-planning programs, saying it hoped to distance itself from the abortion issue. Now that decision is being reviewed, Cynthia Mayeda, the foundation's head, said in a statement Friday. The move angered many Dayton Hudson Corp. customers who support abortion rights. They cut up their credit cards and returned them to the company. The company operates stores known as Dayton's or Hudson's in seven Midwestern states, as well as Target discount stores. It also owns California-based Mervyn's department stores, and last spring announced the purchase of the Chicago-based Marshall Field chain. The foundation is a separate entity set up by the company to manage its charitable contributions. Ms. Mayeda said meetings with Planned Parenthood officials will be held in coming months. ``We are confident that as we work together we will arrive at commonly sought, mutually agreed-upon solutions,'' she said. Thomas Webber, executive director of Planned Parenthood of Minnesota, said he was delighted by the foundation's decision to reconsider. ``It is something we had hoped for, but if you asked me a week ago to predict when, I wouldn't have said today,'' Webber said. ``It is swifter than we thought.'' The foundation's announcement came the same day that the Twin Cities chapter of the National Organization for Women rallied outside Dayton's Minneapolis flagship store to call for a boycott of all Dayton Hudson stores. The company has received letters and phone calls on both sides of the issue, Dayton's spokeswoman Ann Barkelew said, but she acknowledged that the larger number disagreed with the foundation's action. Peggy Lucas of the Women's Consortium of Minnesota said her group, which supports freedom of choice on abortion, would continue to press the company to restore funds to Planned Parenthood. But Nancy Koster, vice president of Minnesota Citizens Concerned for Life, said the foundation's review of its decision will ``make a lot of pro-life people unhappy and Dayton's will hear about it.''

DOC.HEAD: Pope Urges Help for Rural Poor; Government Announces Amnesty
DOC.NOTE: EDS: New thruout to update with government announcing amnesty to mark pope's visit, pope comments on AIDS. No pickup.
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Pope-Notebook
DOC.TEXT: Pope John Paul II on Saturday called for a narrowing of the gap between Africa's urban elite and rural poor and urged peasants in this infertile nation to redouble efforts to improve the quality of their lives. Later, the military government announced a general amnesty to mark John Paul's visit and said it will cover all prisoners except those sentenced for ``political crimes and corruption against the state.'' The announcement broadcast on state radio said prisoners facing the death penalty will have their sentences commuted to life imprisonment. Life sentences will be reduced to 20 years, and sentences of 10 to 20 years will be halved. Prisoners jailed for 10 years or less and all women and prisoners under the age of 18 will be freed, the announcement said. It was not immediately known how many prisoners will be affected. In his speech, John Paul said Rwandan peasants, who comprise more than 80 percent of the population of 7 million, have the right to demand the same health, social and administrative facilities, including credit banking, as their urban counterparts. ``It is necessary to avoid widening the inequalities between the town and the countryside,'' he said. The message in French was broadcast on state radio as John Paul's motorcade traveled to the small agricultural center of Kabgayi, 40 miles southwest of the capital, Kigali. Thousands of peasants gathered in shaded banana groves near villages along the route to see him. Many held small radios to their ears. John Paul told listeners he believed the international community was duty-bound ``to contribute to the development of the peasant world.'' ``Development projects must not deviate from their objectives or lose sight that they are for the peasants,'' John Paul said. He said industrialized nations should pay a just price for primary produce from poor nations, as well as provide humanitarian aid when conditions are worsened by famine, drought or man-made calamity. This year scores of people have died in a drought that hit remote southern Rwanda. On Sunday, John Paul leaves Kigali for the Ivory Coast, the last stop on a 10-day, four-nation African tour that has also taken him to Burundi and Tanzania. A senior Vatican official traveling with the pope welcomed the announcement of the amnesty. Maj. Gen. Juvenal Habyarimana seized power in a bloodless coup in 1973. His government has been praised for its moderate pro-Western policies but has cracked down on internal dissent. John Paul met with civil servants and academics Saturday and commended the government for maintaining civil harmony and good relations between church and state. Later, he repeated his warnings about the danger of AIDS in this nation at the heart of the so-called AIDS belt across central Africa. He blamed sexual permissiveness for the epidemic and urged self-control. ``Fidelity and chastity, which are part of Christian marriage, reinforce self-control,'' he told a gathering of 25,000 young people at the Amahoro stadium in Kigali. During his African visit, John Paul has visited AIDS sufferers but has reaffirmed the church's opposition to the use of condoms to prevent the disease. In Africa, AIDS is spread mainly through heterosexual contact. As many as 40 percent of young urban adults in some areas of central Africa may be infected with the AIDS virus, according to official estimates.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Conflicts of Interest Could Be Affecting Medical Research
DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUBS 16th graf pvs, The Republicans, to CORRECT that their objection is with restricting not disclosing financial interests
DOC.TEXT: Americans may be misled and endangered by scientists' misconduct and conflicts of interest in federally funded medical research, according to a congressional report to be released Monday. The report by the House Government Operations Committee charges that federal health officials have few safeguards to discourage scientists from manipulating research on products in which they have a financial interest. Based on a three-year investigation by the committee's human resources and intergovernmental relations subcommittee, the report reviews 10 cases of alleged scientific misconduct at universities that receive Public Health Service funds. The report, a copy of which was obtained by The Associated Press over the weekend, focuses on two parts of the Public Health Service: the National Institutes of Health; and the Alcohol, Drug Abuse and Mental Health Administration. It charges that the universities conducted inadequate investigations of possible misconduct and retaliated against whistleblowers. It also says NIH officials usually accepted the findings of the university and ignored financial conflicts of interest among scientists who receive federal grants. In one case, at least 13 researchers who were evaluating a heart drug owned stock or held stock options in the company that developed it. NIH was funding research trials of the drug. ``In all of these cases, the ownership of the stock or options could have created a conflict of interest for individuals who received federal funds to study'' whether the drug was safe and effective, the report said. ``The reporting of misleading research results poses an obvious danger to the public,'' the report said. ``In addition, the policy of some universities to make no announcements about their findings of misconduct is also a source of potential danger to the public'' because these scientists can resign quietly and move to another job where their work won't be monitored carefully. The Public Health Service, which is part of the Department of Health and Human Services, said in a statement that officials could not comment on the report because they had not seen it. However, the statement noted that officials have been drafting conflict-of-interest guidelines. It said officials ``wish to assure the public that any use of public funds for research will be done in a quality way.'' Currently, most universities do not limit the amount of money their faculty may accept for research, honoraria, travel, consulting fees or gifts from drug companies, the report said. Also NIH has no restrictions on conflicts of interest for outside researchers who get federal funds, though it requires grant recipients to list all sources of funding for research projects when they apply for NIH funds, the report said. NIH officials also must approve outside financial arrangements that could pose a conflict for NIH employees, it said. Rep. Ted Weiss, D-N.Y., subcommittee chairman, said in comments included in the report that current Public Health Service proposals to protect against conflict of interest would merely ``maintain the status quo.'' Lawmakers recommended adoption of regulations restricting honoraria, consulting fees, stocks, equity and other conflicts of interest for scientists receiving federal health research. They also recommend legislation to protect whistleblowers. Seven Republicans on the committee faulted the ``factual accuracy'' of the report and said that while most of the cases had come under subcommittee scrutiny in hearings, a few of the cases were investigated without the knowledge of Republicans on the panel. The Republicans also disagreed with one of the committee's recommendations, saying that restricting outside financial ties ``could force qualified, honest researchers to turn away from federally sponsored projects.'' A better way to reduce incentives for manipulating research is through ``stringent enforcement of existing disclosure requirements,'' they said.

DOC.HEAD: Saddam Lampoons Whitewashed Away Before Iraqi Minister Visits
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Huge cartoons lampooning Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein were removed from public view Saturday in preparation for a historic visit by an Iraq's foreign minister, who was expected to ask Iran to break the U.N. economic embargo. Officials declined to comment on the visit Sunday by Tariq Aziz. He will be the first high-ranking Iraqi visitor to Iran since 1980, when the Iran-Iraq war broke out. Iraq is increasingly feeling the pinch of U.N. economic sanctions imposed after it invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. Since the embargo, it has made concessions to Iran, including promising to withdraw from Iranian territory seized in the last days of the war. Iraq also agreed to Tehran's demand that the frontier between the two countries should run along the middle of the Shatt al-Arab waterway. Iraq had long demanded that it have full control of the waterway. Aziz will return to Iraq ``with his hands full'' if Iraq continues its policy toward Iran, said an editorial in Saturday's editions of Tehran's Jomhuri Islami. Foreign observers speculated that Aziz would bring ``concrete proposals'' for ending the territorial dispute that sparked the Iran-Iraq war. One Western diplomat, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said Aziz probably would present a way to enforce a 1975 treaty that split the Shatt-al-Arab waterway between Iran and Iraq. Such a plan ``would be vitally important because it would represent a de facto peace treaty between Baghdad and Tehran,'' the diplomat said. Walls along roads leading to Tehran's Mehrabad Airport have been covered with huge cartoons depicting Saddam Hussein as a war monger and a U.S. stooge throwing bombs at Iranian children. But they were being painted over Saturday. Where the walls could not be whitewashed, painters, who reportedly started work earlier in the week, settled for smudging up the caricatures. Another indication that Iran could be willing to negotiate with its former adversary was an editorial in Saturday's Keyhan International proclaiming that the ``American game plan (in the gulf is) at odds with world peace.'' ``Essentially, the present Iraq-Kuwait crisis is being exploited by Washington's regional ambitions in the name of the U.N.,'' it said. An Iranian newspaper close to President Hashemi Rafsanjani on Thursday raised the question of sending food and medicine to Iraq. ``Should the Islamic republic help the Iraqi Moslem people in these hard times when they are facing an economic blockade?'' asked the editorial in the English-language Tehran Times. ``Since food and medicine are not included in the sanctions so far imposed on Iraq, by choosing to help the Iraqi people Iran will not be breaching any international law,'' the editorial said.

DOC.HEAD: Spate of Palestinian Attacks on Accused Collaborators
DOC.TEXT: Masked Palestinian assailants gunned down an Arab man and hacked to death an Arab woman in weekend attacks on alleged collaborators in the occupied lands, Arab and Israeli sources said Saturday. The violence underscored the inward turn taken lately by the nearly 34-month-old Palestinian rebellion against Israeli rule. Most uprising victims since June have been Arabs slain by Arabs. Prior to that, most were Arabs killed by Israeli soldiers during stone-throwing protests. Palestinian sources who spoke on condition of anonymity said masked activists abducted the woman, identified as Etas Anims, 45, from her home in Rafah in the Gaza Strip on Friday night. Her body was found in a Rafah street on Saturday, riddled with dagger and ax wounds. An arm and leg had been hacked off, the Palestinian reports said. Graffiti scribbled on walls in Rafah accused Ms. Anims of collaborating with Israel. She had been beaten four times in the past by activists for similar accusations, the Palestinian reports said. In the Magazi refugee camp in Gaza, masked assailants ambushed Fahmi Mohammed Sayed Abu Libda, 34, on Friday night and fatally shot him in the head, the reports said. Abu Libda, also accused by uprising activists of collaborating with Israel, arrived dead at Shifa Hospital, hospital officials said. A military source confirmed Abu Libda's death and was checking the other report. The deaths raised to 258 the number of Palestinians killed by fellow Arabs during the uprising against Israeli rule of the West Bank and Gaza Strip. Most have been accused of helping Israel or of dealing in drugs or prostitution. Another 728 Palestinians have been killed by Israelis during the rebellion, which began on Dec. 8, 1987. Fifty-one Israelis and foreign tourists have been slain during the unrest. Palestinian violence against accused collaborators has risen dramatically in the last three months as activists have tried to eliminate informants suspected of sabotaging their rebellion. The attacks have persisted despite calls by PLO leaders to stop the slayings. Since June, 42 alleged collaborators have been killed, compared with 14 Palestinians killed by Israeli soldiers or civilians in the same period. The decline in shooting deaths by Israeli troops is largely a result of attempts to calm the atmosphere by pulling many soldiers out of trouble spots. The army also has turned to other punitive measures to curb stoning attacks, such as more curfews and closing more businesses. On Friday the military took the unusual step of closing eight stretches of West Bank highway from one to two miles in length, during the night, to prevent stoning and firebomb attacks, the national Itim news agency reported. Soldiers also shut down a marketplace in Gaza City on Saturday after activists blocked a road with boulders, and they closed a vegetable market in Bethlehem following a stoning assault, Arab reports said.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev: Superpowers Should Not Let Iraq Thwart Thaw
With AM-Summit Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Crises such as the one in the Persian Gulf should not be allowed to thwart better superpower ties, Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev said Saturday on arriving to meet President Bush. Gorbachev planned to assure Bush in their meetings on Sunday that he will continue efforts to force Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait and to conclude conventional and nuclear arms control pacts by yearend, said top U.S. and Soviet officials. He was also seeking assurances from Bush that the administration will press for Senate ratification of a new trade pact with Moscow, and for other assistance to help the Soviet Union through its own time of economic and political crisis at home. Gorbachev has backed U.S. initiatives in the U.N. Security Council to condemn the Iraqi invasion and approve military means to enforce sanctions against Iraq. But so far he has balked at sending Soviet ground or naval forces to support the U.N. effort in the gulf. Nor has he recalled 193 Soviet military experts on contract to train Iraqi forces. Soviet spokesmen say the experts did not take part in the invasion, but Bush is almost certain to seek further clarification from Gorbachev. It remained to be seen whether Gorbachev and Bush agreed to the hastily called one-day summit in Finland in order to announce some previously undisclosed deal concerning the Persian Gulf. One Soviet official said of Gorbachev, ``If the president has agreed to such an urgent meeting, he must have something in his pocket.'' The official, who spoke on condition he not be further identified, declined to indicate what sort of deal _ if any _ might be in the works. Gorbachev's presidential Ilyushin-62M touched down at the Helsinki airport Saturday night, nearly eight hours after Bush. In his arrival statement, he made clear the initiative for the meeting lay with the Americans. ``President George Bush expressed a wish for us to meet at this crucial moment in history, when it is important to compare political approaches, and to cooperate and protect the positive trends that are developing in the world today _ and to make sure that they are not thwarted by any development,'' he said. ``It is important for us to meet personally, although we have been in touch through various means,'' including telephone calls and letters, he said. ``It is necessary to meet in order to discuss the acute crisis in the Persian Gulf and other issues,'' he said in remarks that were translated at the arrival from Russian into English _ but not into Finnish. Gorbachev looked relaxed, despite a host of domestic troubles that threaten the economy and structure of the Soviet Union. As he flew toward Helsinki, Radio Moscow quoted parliamentary leaders saying that the nation might drop the word socialist from its formal name _ changing from the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics to the Union of Soviet Sovereign Republics. The change would reflect declarations of independence or sovereignty by more than half of the 15 Soviet republics, including Russia, the largest. A key Gorbachev ally in Moscow, Vice President Anatoly Lukyanov, also said Saturday that a prospective compromise on economic reform had fallen through with Russian President Boris Yeltsin, who advocates a more radical transition to a market economy. Faced with possible approval of Yeltsin's radical reform package by the parliament of the Russian Federation early next week, Gorbachev dropped plans to present his own version to the national parliament on Monday or Tuesday. Instead, Lukyanov told a news conference in Moscow, Gorbachev will circulate his plans to the Soviet republics before presenting it to the national legislature. The announcement indicated that Gorbachev was losing the domestic initiative to Yeltsin.

DOC.HEAD: Nordstrom Stores Announce Cutbacks, Layoffs
DOC.TEXT: The Nordstrom clothing store chain is cutting costs and laying off employees because of a drop in profits. The cutbacks will vary between 3 percent and 12 percent at each Nordstrom store depending on the stores' performance, spokesman Dave Marriott said Friday from the company's Seattle headquarters. Nordstrom, a chain known for its blue-chip customer service, employs about 30,000 people in 61 stores in seven states. The cuts will be determined by store managers and could include trimming staff, advertising budgets and inventory, Marriott said. Nordstrom profits have declined from the previous year for three consecutive quarters. For the three-month period that ended July 31, Nordstrom profits of $35.9 million were down 7 percent from the $38.5 million reported for the same quarter of 1989. Despite a slowdown in sales, Nordstrom is continuing its national expansion program. It opened a new store Friday in Paramus, N.J., and another in August in Santa Barbara, Calif. Nordstrom has been embroiled for about a year in a labor dispute with the union representing many of its workers, who charged they were pressured into working overtime without pay. The company recently signed an agreement with the National Labor Relations Board to resolve some of the issues. Marriott said the cost-cutting moves were unrelated to those problems.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Union May Get New Name
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union may drop the word ``Socialist'' from its formal name, according to a top official quoted by Radio Moscow on Saturday. The Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, or U.S.S.R., might become the Union of Sovereign Soviet Republics, the broadcast said, quoting parliamentary leader Rafik Nishanov. Proposals to drop ``Socialist'' indicate the depth of change in the country, where less than six months ago the Communist Party held a constitutionally guaranteed monopoly on power. The use addition of the word ``Sovereign'' would be aimed at placating republics seeking independence or more autonomy. A second variation on the U.S.S.R. initials calls for ``Sovereign'' to replace ``Soviet,'' a term disliked by nationalist movements in some republics. The full title of the nation could be ``Union of Sovereign Socialist States,'' the radio broadcast said. Nishanov said a name change might be approved as part of a new union treaty, which is expected to redefine the country as something between a federation and an economic alliance. Action on the union treaty is expected before the end of the year. Democratic reforms have led to official name changes in other countries. Last year, both Hungary and Poland dropped the word ``People's'' from their names to become the Republic of Hungary and Republic of Poland. In January, Czeckoslovakian President Vaclav Havel proposed dropping the word ``Socialist'' from the country's formal name.

DOC.HEAD: EC Sees Strict Monetary Policies As Best Reaction to Oil Price Surge
DOC.TEXT: Finance ministers of the 12 Economic Community nations agreed Saturday that restrictive budget and monetary policies are the best way to react to the recent surge in world oil prices. At a one-day meeting here, they also agreed that governments should react according to the conditions in their own countries, said Italian Treasury Minister Guido Carli. Carli, the meeting's chairman, said the EC countries should be able to prevent widespread inflation following the oil price surge by controlling consumer demand. Oil prices have soared nearly 50 percent _ to about $30 a barrel _ since Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2 and the subsequent U.N. trade embargo imposed on Iraq. The price rise occurred despite a decision by OPEC nations to raise production. ``Budget and monetary policies should be restrictive according to the conditions found in individual countries,'' Carli told reporters. He also said governments should seek to keep savings rates, and thus investment rates, high. He said investment, rather than consumption, should fuel EC economic growth in the face of rising energy costs.

DOC.HEAD: College Town Gets Respite From Slayings; Reports Of Multiple Personality
DOC.TEXT: This north Florida city regained the feel of a typical college town Saturday as attention shifted from the killings of five college students to the football stadium. Reports surfaced that an 18-year-old freshman who is a suspect in the case may have multiple personalities ranging from a knife-wielding Rambo type to a mixed-up college kid. An estimated 70,000 fans crowded into Ben Hill Griffin Stadium for the opener for the University of Florida Gators, who were playing the Oklahoma State Cowboys. Fear and tension were temporarily replaced by traditional tailgate parties, boisterous fans and gridiron competition. ``This football game was needed,'' said William Stebbins, a Florida alumnus from Jacksonville, who said he had missed only three home games since 1951. ``All the students need something to reduce the tension and stress.'' But the search for a killer continued. Sources close to the investigation have told The Florida Times-Union that suspect Edward Lewis Humphrey, an 18-year-old University of Florida freshman, has admitted having knowledge of the first two killings, discovered two weeks ago. Humphrey, in an interview with investigators last week, named someone he said had killed Christina Powell, 17, and Sonja Larson, 18. Their bodies were discovered Aug. 26 in their Gainesville townhouse. Investigators believe the person Humphrey named is one of his multiple personalities, the newspaper reported. Both his lawyer and police had no comment on the report. A source familiar with the case said Humphrey's personality sometimes resembles that of a knife-wielding killer, and at other times a emotionally troubled college student. Humphrey takes the anti-depressant drug lithium to control mood swings. Police have repeatedly said that Humphrey, being held in the Brevard County Jail in lieu of $1 million bond for allegedly beating his grandmother, is one of eight suspects and they have refused to characterize him as the prime suspect. At a hearing Thursday in Sharpes, Emily Glaab, a Brevard County jail guard, said Humphrey sometimes referred to himself as ``John.'' The guard quoted Humphrey as saying: ``John doesn't take no prisoners.'' Humphrey's lawyer, public defender J.R. Russo, said he was unaware of any such statements by his client. ``It's news to me,'' Russo said. He noted, however, that police had grilled his client without attorneys present. So far, authorities have refused to discuss publicly what Humphrey has told them. ``We are not going to be able to speak to what information we have gained in interviews with suspects,'' Gainesville Police Lt. Sadie Darnell said Saturday. ``We are still working around the clock and following up leads, but as far was we can tell, there will be no new developments this weekend.'' Police said late last week they had found promising evidence during searches of Humphrey's Gainesville apartment, his car and his grandmother's home in Indialantic, a coastal city about 180 miles southeast of Gainesville. Police also have continued to pursue other leads, both in Florida and elsewhere. Besides the Brevard County charge, Humphrey has been charged in Indian River County with armed burglary and attempted sexual battery and with aggravated assault in Gainesville. Memories of the killings were likely to return after the game, said Joe Fincher, owner of the Gator Shop. ``It's just a football game,'' he said. ``The extra people who came into town will be gone tomorrow and nothing will have changed.''

DOC.HEAD: President Testifies in Jesuit Massacre Case
DOC.TEXT: President Alfredo Cristiani has testified before a court investigating the murders of six Jesuit priests, a case that has strained relations with the United States, a government official said Saturday. Information Minister Mauricio Sandoval said in a telephone interview that Cristiani testified Friday. Sandoval said he did not have further details, and that he did not know if Cristiani testified in his capacity as commander in chief of the armed forces. Nine members of the armed forces, including a colonel and three lesser officers, have been charged in the murder of the priests, their housekeeper and her daughter last Nov. 16. The massacre occurred during a period of tight army security imposed during a major rebel offensive. Some U.S. congressmen have threatened to seek cuts in aid to the Salvadoran military because of alleged army efforts to cover up the killings and to block the investigation. Local radio station YSU reported that Cristiani testified before criminal court Judge Ricardo Zamora for more than two hours. It quoted the president as saying he testified to ``give an example and so that other witnesses will appear to testify before the judge.'' The broadcast did not include Cristiani's voice, nor did it give details of his testimony. Other military officials have given only written testimony. According to court spokesman Mario Gonzalez, Cristiani was not on the list of those who had been called to testify.

DOC.HEAD: Subway Stabbing Victim Remembered For Helping Others
LaserPhoto PVX1
DOC.TEXT: A tourist slain in a New York City subway was remembered Saturday as a competitive and fun-loving young man who loved helping others. The funeral for Brian Watkins, 22, at the Mormon Church's Provo North Stake Center was attended by about 300 people. ``I suppose there could be no greater epitaph on a tombstone than `He was trying to help his mother.' Somewhere in the heart and breast and soul of Brian there was a giant,'' said Michael R. Hill, Watkins' former Mormon lay bishop. Watkins was fatally stabbed Sunday when he tried to defend his mother from a band of teen-agers who robbed his father in a Manhattan subway station. The family from Provo, Utah, had made their annual trip to New York to attend the U.S. Open tennis tournament. ``New York is shocked, Provo is shocked and so is the nation. We have witnessed a real live hero,'' Hill said at the funeral. Watkins was buried later at the Provo City Cemetery. After a graveside service, his mother, Karen, plucked two yellow roses from atop the casket, and gave one to her 10-year-old daughter, Emily. Watkins attended Idaho State University for three years on a tennis scholarship and was working as a seminar director for American Business Seminars. He aspired to be a prosecuting attorney. He planned to work as an intern to Sen. Steven D. Symms, R-Idaho, in Washington next January before returning to college and attending law school. Brian's 26-year-old brother, Todd, who was in the subway that night, said: ``Brian always had a competitive spirit inside him. . . . He did whatever was necessary so he could come out on top.'' And yet, he said, his brother had a tender side. ``Brian grew to become a very compassionate human being. He loved his family . . . Brian loved helping others and he died doing just that,'' Todd Watkins said. No mention was made of the eight young men accused in Watkin's slaying. They have been charged with second-degree murder and related robbery counts and are jailed pending a Sept. 24 bond hearing. Police said the gang wanted the money to pay for a night of drinking and dancing at a nightclub where several suspects were arrested. Manhattan District Attorney Robert Morgenthau promised Watkins' parents the defendants won't be offered a plea bargain. On Friday, Watkin's parents spoke about their son. ``If there was something he wanted, he worked for it,'' Sherwin Watkins told The Deseret News. ``I think that was one of Brian's strong points.'' Watkins and his family had traveled extensively in the United States, Europe and Israel. ``He wasn't intimidated by any place. He wasn't a typical 22-year-old who hadn't been somewhere,'' the father said. ``He didn't lead a sheltered life. We always traveled. He liked to travel _ the excitement of being in different places.''

DOC.HEAD: Thunderstorms In South, Cold In Northeast
DOC.TEXT: Rain was scattered from the southern Plains into the Ohio Valley on Saturday, and temperatures fell from the Great Lakes into New England. Showers and thunderstorms were widely scattered along a stationary front from northwestern Texas through Arkansas and Missouri to Kentucky during the afternoon. A few showers and thunderstorms also were scattered in southeastern Texas and southwestern Louisiana. Late Friday and early Saturday, severe thunderstorms developed along a stationary front from Nebraska and Kansas to North Carolina, Virginia and Maryland. Temperatures rose into the 90s across much of the southern tier of states, with some midday readings above 100 in the desert Southwest, and temperatures in the lower 90s were also reported over parts of the northern and central Plains. But cool air spread from the upper Mississippi Valley to New England, where where afternoon temperatures were only in the 50s and 60s. Overnight readings in that region dipped into the 40s and 50s, with lows in the 30s reported in Upper Michigan, northern Lower Michigan, upstate New York, and northern New England. Worcester, Mass., equalled its record low for the date at 43. Lows also were in the 40s in the Rockies and the Great Basin, which includes Nevada and western Utah. Saturday's low for the Lower 48 was 32 at Watertown, N.Y.

DOC.HEAD: Inmates Making Gospel Music Album
DOC.TEXT: The New Faith Singers, a promising group of gospel music singers, has won the go-ahead for a record album on a major label, but the group won't be taking its act on the road anytime soon. The New Faith Singers are serving life sentences at the Tennessee State Penitentiary. The group plans to complete its first LP for Warner Bros. Records this week. ``This really hasn't all sunk in, but it looks like this is God's little pet project,'' New Faith member Malika Haki said in an interview from prison. ``Because of their dedication, there's every reason to think there is a high potential for commercial success,'' said Jim Ed Norman, president of Warner's Nashville division. The New Faith Singers grew out of a Bible study group that Moses Dillard started during a prison ministry in 1987. Dillard, a musician, songwriter and minister, is the group's co-producer along with Jesse Boyce. ``I was so impressed with the first four tracks, I said let's go with the next step, which is finishing an album,'' Norman said. ``Then we'll have to evaluate just how to go about a marketing strategy.''

DOC.HEAD: Grenades From France Force Evacuation at Post Office
DOC.TEXT: Dirt-encrusted hand grenades spilled from a broken box in a U.S. Postal Service bulk mail center Saturday, forcing a three-hour evacuation, authorities said. ``They were live,'' said police bomb squad Sgt. Robert Garrison. ``They were very badly deteriorated. We considered them unsafe for storage.'' Bomb squad officers hand-carried the 19 grenades and an artillery shell, believed to be of World War I vintage, out of the building. The weapons were taken to a disposal site and detonated, Garrison said. The box also contained empty bottles, a mess kit, military-style leggings and two boxes of French cookies, Garrison said. The box had been mailed from France to an address in Chambersburg, police said. It fell off a conveyor belt and broke open shortly before 7 a.m. Employees were allowed to return about 10 a.m., police said. ``The package broke loose, and they saw that there were explosives and what looked like explosives, and they called the bomb squad,'' he said. Postal Inspection Service investigators were trying to locate the sender and the intended recipient, police said. Postal inspectors contacted by telephone refused to answer questions.

DOC.HEAD: Talks on Economic, Monetary Union Stall
DOC.TEXT: Efforts to achieve economic and monetary union within the European Community hit a snag Saturday in disagreements among the 12 member states over when and how union should be accomplished. At a one-day session, the EC finance ministers reached no accord on a timetable for moving toward a single currency and central bank patterned after the U.S. Federal Reserve. They met with only three months before the final negotiations on monetary union are to take place. The ministers agreed to meet again here in November. The final talks, due to open in December, must produce amendments to the EC's 1957 founding Treaty of Rome to bring about monetary union. The meeting was a boost for British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, who opposes a single EC currency and an EC central bank. Some EC nations have expressed support Britain's alternative proposals for monetary union. Supporters of a single currency and a central bank _ notably France, Belgium and Italy _ had hoped Saturday's meeting would put the final touches on preparatory work for the start of the December talks. The EC's drive for monetary union is a complex, three-stage journey. The first stage began July 1 and the EC nations now are more closely coordinating their economic and monetary policies. Also, all EC currencies, notably the British pound, will join the European Monetary System's exchange rate mechanism. The pound, the Greek drachma and the Portuguese escudo are not in the ERM now. On Saturday, several nations rejected a proposal by the EC executive Commission that the second stage _ during which the EC would create a central bank _ begin on Jan. 1, 1993. West Germany, Britain, the Netherlands, and Portugal argued that before the second stage begins, the EC nations must first narrow the gaps between their inflation, unemployment and interest rates. ``There was a long discussion about the moment at which you must go to phase two. There are difficulties there,'' said Dutch Finance Minister Wim Kok. Under the EC Commission's proposal, in the third and final stage of monetary union the nations would permanently fix exchange rates among their currencies. These eventually would be replaced by a single currency known as the ``European currency unit,'' or ECU. Spanish Finance Minister Carlos Solchaga Saturday proposed that a single currency not be created until the year 2000. He described his proposal as a compromise between Britain _ which prefers the retain the 12 EC currencies plus a ``hard ECU'' _ and the EC Commission's monetary package. But Solchaga's plan ran into opposition from West German Central Bank President Karl Otto Poehl, who said, ``I am very much against it. I cannot see many merits'' in a parallel currency.

DOC.HEAD: Dukakis Staff Assesses Insurgent's Plans
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis' staff will assess the budget-cutting proposals unveiled by his rebellious lieutenant governor, but some observers said Saturday her plan won't solve the state's fiscal troubles. Lt. Gov. Evelyn Murphy seized command as acting governor after Dukakis left the state on a European trade mission, and on Friday she issued her own program. But Dukakis' staff is still carrying out the orders he issued before he left Thursday. Murphy, needing some life in her lagging campaign for governor, had raised expectations about her proposals by refusing to disclose them as long as Dukakis was still in Massachusetts. She said she was waiting for the former Democratic presidential candidate to leave so she could assume authority. She will face two other opponents in the Sept. 18 Democratic primary, and public opinion polls put her well behind. Dukakis, whose popularity has dived, is not seeking re-election. Among Murphy's steps were cutting management positions in each cabinet secretariat by 25 percent, as well as slashing by 10 percent the payroll of the Department of Administration and Finance. Murphy said her proposals would save up to $150 million annually. Earlier in the week, Dukakis had ordered cabinet secretaries to find $150 million worth of cuts for the current fiscal year. Dukakis refused to comment on her proposals Saturday. ``I've got a very good team in place (at home) and I want to get on with this trip,'' he said in Bitterfeld, East Germany. Dukakis administration officials said Murphy's numbers were misleading, and that her plan would realistically save only about $17 million this fiscal year. ``In terms of real dollar savings, it doesn't match up to the $125 million to $150 million which she says it is,'' said Stephen Crawford, a Dukakis spokesman. ``For people looking to an end to this yearlong nightmare, I don't think we saw it yesterday,'' said James Braude, head of the Tax Equity Alliance for Massachusetts, a group that has supported higher taxes to help solve the state's fiscal woes. Crawford said the governor's staff would assess Murphy's plans over the next week. Dukakis is scheduled to return Friday. Dukakis had said he might cut his trip short if any action Murphy took threatened to hurt the state's stability. But after Murphy issued her orders, Crawford said he saw no reason for the governor to return early. He noted that executive orders requiring payroll cuts would not take effect before Dukakis comes back, since such actions take 10 days to implement. Once the governor returns, he can rescind Murphy's action, but Crawford could not predict what action Dukakis might take. Murphy's orders do not supersede the instructions Dukakis issued earlier in the week to make cuts, which means cabinet secretaries will still carry out those plans, Crawford said. A spokesman for the Executive Office of Human Services said his agency would proceed with the spending cuts ordered by Dukakis. ``The secretary's strong position is that he works for Mike Dukakis,'' said Kenneth Schwartz, chief of staff for Human Services Secretary Philip Johnston. Mark Longabaugh, a spokesman for the lieutenant governor, said Saturday that she stands behind her savings projections. One element of her plan did not receive as much as attention as the payroll cuts, he said, but was highly important. That order would require the department of Administration and Finance to submit monthly budget reports, documenting whether the state's books are in balance. Cabinet secretaries who fail to remedy their deficits could lose part of their salaries and possibly their jobs. While Murphy has downplayed the political aspects of her action, saying she was simply looking out for the state's well-being, Longabaugh acknowledged her supporters believe the campaign has gained ground from the episode. ``From a political standpoint, she looked like a leader, she looked like she was ready to act,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Pittsburgh Sniper Described As Troubled Bachelor
DOC.TEXT: A gunman who caused panic by firing shots from the top of a high-rise before shooting himself and falling to the ground, was a shy man discouraged because the Navy had rejected him, friends said. Paul Fisher was ``a real good guy who had a lot of personal problems,'' said Dennis Byrd, owner of Thirsty's Restaurant & Saloon, where Fisher was a regular. Fisher, 35, held police at bay for 5{ hours Friday from the rooftop of a 16-story apartment building in one of the city's busiest sections. He fired at least 11 shots in the air from a .22-caliber rifle. After pleading with police to kill him, Fisher shot himself with a .25-caliber handgun and plunged to the street. Police found a suicide note in Fisher's wallet, but said they had not immediately determined why he killed himself. Byrd said Fisher, a Navy reservist, was depressed because he wanted to join the regular Navy but failed to meet a weight requirement. Fisher spent the summer trying to lose weight, Byrd said. ``He got disgruntled with being a computer operator and wanted to try for a full-time job with the Navy,'' Byrd said. ``Then when he had to deal with that rejection from the Navy, I think that probably had something to do with what happened. That must have been working and working on him.'' ``He was really bummed out about it,'' said David Dietz, another acquaintance who said he talked with Fisher about seven hours before Fisher opened fire from the roof of the building near the University of Pittsburgh. Byrd described Fisher as a shy bachelor who spent most of his evenings and days off at the bar. ``He was never an extrovert on the bar scene _ he was just a joy to have around,'' Byrd said. ``We were his extended family, and he was quiet, pleasant and generous with us. If someone needed money for their rent, Paul would loan it to them. If he came into some money, he'd buy drinks for the house.'' The Navy permits people whose applications are rejected to file written objections, but Fisher did not do that, said Cmdr. John Wells, head of the Naval and Marine Corps Reserve Centers in Pittsburgh. ``When that situation came up, he didn't indicate a preference to stay,'' Wells said. ``He did not demonstrate a particularly gung-ho attitude.''

DOC.HEAD: White House, Congressional Leaders Continue Budget Talks ^EDS: INSERTS grafs 5-6, ``Another official xxx with Democrats proposing 10 percent surcharge on wealthy, energy taxes; SHOULD STAND FOR AMS
DOC.TEXT: Bush administration and congressional budget negotiators continued their stretch-drive search Saturday for about $50 billion in tax increases and spending cuts for next year, but there were no signs of major progress. The two sides swapped new offers Saturday, the second day of revived budget talks at Andrews Air Force Base just outside Washington. On Friday, each side proposed trimming about $50 billion from next year's deficit, but Republicans sought deeper cuts in domestic programs and Democrats wanted to rely more on defense reductions and revenue increases. Democrats offered Saturday to seek only about $13 billion in defense cuts instead of the $14.9 billion they had suggested Friday, one official said. But Republicans, who want to pare military spending by just $4 billion, dismissed the offer as inadequate, the official said. Another official, speaking on condition he not be identified, said Democrats proposed a 10 percent surcharge on income taxes of people earning more than $500,000 annually. They have also proposed a wide range of energy levies, including a 7-cent-a-gallon boost in the 9-cent federal gasoline tax. Half the increase would be to reduce the deficit and half to build new roads and bridges, the official said. One source close to the talks, speaking on condition of anonymity, said he believed the bargaining ``could be on the verge of breaking up'' because Democrats were making excessive demands for new taxes, defense slashes and for increases in some domestic programs. Other officials, however, said there were no indications of any problems beyond the usual disagreements between bargainers. As the negotiators met, about 25 federal employee union officials and government workers staged an hour-long demonstration outside the gates of the air base. They were protesting the furloughs of tens of thousands of federal workers that could occur should the negotiators fail to complete a budget deal by Oct. 1, the start of the new fiscal year. Should the deficit not be reduced by that day, the Gramm-Rudman law will automatically reduce the $1.2 trillion federal budget by about $100 billion. Agencies are threatening to give many of their workers up to 22 days of unpaid leave to make up the shortfall. ``We're tired of being jerked around as a political football,'' said John Sturdivant, president of the American Federation of Government Employees, the largest union for federal workers. Meanwhile, the negotiators further tightened the restrictions on reporters covering the budget talks. From the start, journalists have been restricted to a press center about two miles from the Andrews officers' club where the talks are under way. Beginning Saturday, they were permitted to enter the base or leave the press center only with an armed military escort. In either case, they were driven directly to their destinations with no detours permitted. ``Just want to make sure nobody's bothering anybody at the O.C.,'' or officers' club, one Air Force official said.

DOC.HEAD: American-Born Jordanian Queen Visits Desperate Refugees
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: American-born Queen Noor of Jordan visited a squalid camp housing tens of thousands of Asian refugees Saturday, offering them words of comfort and appealing for aid to get them home. Everywhere she stopped, Noor was surrounded by Bangladeshi, Pakistani and Indian men and women shouting at her: ``Please help us. We have no food, no water, you are our only hope.'' The queen shook hands and assured the refugees who were left penniless after fleeing Iraqi-occupied Kuwait: ``We are doing everything possible to get you home.'' At one point, a mother shoved her baby in front of the queen, sobbing: ``You are a mother, my child is dying, please help us.'' The queen, who was accompanied by Jordanian Health Minister Mohamed Azeben, immediately asked him to take the mother and child to the desert camp's medical tent. ``Don't worry, we are coming with you to the hospital,'' Noor told the mother, stretching out her manicured hand to wipe the tears from the bedraggled woman's cheeks. Noor, the former Lisa Halaby, the Lebanese-American daughter of an airline executive, has been married to Jordan's King Hussein since 1978. Official estimates say more than 250,000 foreigners, mostly Asians, have crossed the desert border post at Ruweishid since the Aug. 2 Iraqi invasion of Kuwait. Jordan's meager resources are inadequate to provide food, shelter and transportation for the more than 100,000 refugees stranded in camps along its desert border. The queen, who arrived by helicopter, flew twice low over the Shalaan I camp, housing more than 40,000 refugees in a square mile of arid desert near the Ruweishid border post, 200 miles northeast of the Jordanian capital, Amman. After viewing the hundreds of makeshift shelters set up to keep out the desert sun _ ranging from tents to colored women's saris tied to sticks _ Noor drove her four-wheel-drive Mercedes through the camp. She stopped more than a dozen times, getting out of the car to mingle with refugees and walk through the dusty, litter-strewn passages between the rows of tents. ``We understand how you feel, you are not forgotten,'' Noor kept saying to the crowds pressing around her. Dressed in a blue shirt and ankle-length khaki skirt over brown boots, the queen stood out amid the unkempt refugees. An elderly Indian woman who found herself next to the queen in the crush asked: ``Who are you?'' ``I've just come from Amman,'' Noor replied as the minister next to her informed the Indian she was the queen. ``God bless you!'' the woman blurted, overwhelmed by the realization she had spoken with the queen. One bearded man acting as spokesman for a large group said in broken English: ``Maximum people are suffering. No food, no water, day and night, terrible heat and terrible cold. We unable to sleep at night with thought what will happen to us.'' ``Be patient, be courageous, we will get you home,'' Noor responded. ``We have courage, but for God's sake, get bus home,'' countered the man. An airlift operation for Indians got under way Saturday, with Indians flying from Amman to Dubai, where Indian Air Force transports are carrying them home. In Amman, officials from the Middle East Council of Churches met with Noor and others involved in relief efforts. Gabriel Habib, the council's general secretary, called for governments to intensify efforts to airlift the refugees to their home countries, saying their situation was becoming desperate. Shortly before Noor's visit, thousands of refugees had been standing in parallel single-file lines stretching for more than a mile waiting their turn to receive their meager daily ration of a piece of bread, a tomato, a cucumber and a bottle of water. Scuffles broke out repeatedly as people at the back of the line grew impatient and tried to move ahead to get to the trailer truck where the food was being distributed. At the end of her visit, Noor appealed for international help to assist the refugees, asking for food, tents, blankets and medicine and, most importantly, ships and planes to take them home. ``I can't tell how long their repatriation will take, days or weeks, but God forbid it should take months,'' she said. ``We must impress on the world these people are living in even minimally unacceptable conditions.''

DOC.HEAD: Swedish Diplomat's Brother Hopes Bush, Gorbachev Will Discuss Him
