DOC.TEXT: An international team arrived Saturday in this summit city, hoping to persuade the American and Soviet presidents to discuss the fate of Swedish diplomat Raoul Wallenberg. The commission members, including Wallenberg's half-brother, Guy von Dardel, said they wanted to hand Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev a letter urging him to press the KGB to open its files on Wallenberg. The panel planned a news conference Sunday while the superpower leaders are talking about the Persian Gulf crisis, but they said they did not expect to obtain a meeting with President Bush. Wallenberg is credited with saving tens of thousands of Hungarian Jews from the Nazis during World War II. But he vanished after the Soviets arrested him in Budapest. The Soviet Union said in 1957 that prison documents showed the Swede had died of a heart attack in Moscow's Lubyanka Prison in 1947. The commission believes he may still be alive. ``We are closer to finding out the truth about Raoul Wallenberg than we've been for the past 45 years,'' said Marvin Markinen, an American professor and former inmate of Vladimir Prison, where Wallenberg reportedly was spotted. ``The Wallenberg case has never been on a summit agenda but it has also never been on the Soviet public agenda like it is now,'' said Canadian Irwin Cotler of the Soviet-International Joint Commission on the Fate and Whereabouts of Raoul Wallenberg. Soviet television last week showed a drawing of Wallenberg the way he might look if he were alive today at the age of 77. The report appealed to the public for help in tracing him, Cotler said. ``Two years ago, no one in the street would have known who Wallenberg was,'' he said. Swedish authorities presented Moscow with witness reports that Wallenberg was alive in the 1950s and '60s and had been seen by non-Soviets at Vladimir Prison, 12 miles outside Moscow. The commission said there had been less reliable reports of sightings in the 1970s and '80s. But the commission last week said it had found that Soviet authorities never looked into the records at the prison, although they said at the time they had done so. Therefore, the commission said, it found it hard to trust the death certificate produced in 1957. Cotler said the commission believed Wallenberg's name would be found only on classified lists of the KGB, the Soviet secret police and intelligence agency. Cotler said Soviet Minister of Internal Affairs Vadim Bakatin promised in a meeting Saturday he would bring up the matter with KGB head Vadim Kryuchkov. ``If the KGB is not cooperating, there are now parliamentary ways of holding them responsible,'' said Cotler. ``If Gorbachev wants to open up the blank pages of the Soviet history, here is an opportunity. Gorbachev has knowledge of the KGB and the capacity'' to open their files, Cotler said. The commission, which was formed two weeks ago, includes five Soviet experts who have been granted access to prison archives closed to foreigners. Von Dardel said he had worked for 10 years to get the Soviets included in an international investigation. He said the doors of Soviet ministries and prisons had opened up remarkably since that occurred.

DOC.HEAD: Local Banks Rebuff Philly Credit Plea
DOC.TEXT: Four local banks have rejected the city's request for a credit guarantee as the city seeks to borrow hundreds of millions of dollars to avoid running out of cash this month, according to published reports. Meridian Bankcorp Inc. confirmed Friday it would not help back the sale of temporary loan notes scheduled for this week. The Philadelphia Daily News quoted unidentified sources Saturday as saying CoreStates Financial Corp., Mellon Bank (East) and PNC Financial Corp. also had turned down the city's request. ``We cannot reconcile the associated risk with our bank's ongoing responsibilities to stockholders and other important constituencies,'' Meridian said in a statement. Representatives of the other three banks would not comment. Mayor W. Wilson Goode and other top city officials have refused to comment on the notes since the mayor delivered a televised address on the city's finances last month. The city initially planned to raise $450 million, but scaled that back to $400 million. The Philadelphia Inquirer reported Saturday it had obtained a document intended for would-be investors that said the city now is offering $375 million in notes. Goode has said the city will be out of money by the end of this month unless it receives a cash infusion. The notes would be repaid from property and business tax receipts expected early next year. Goode also has asked for an emergency tax increase of up to $150 million, the possible sale of Veterans Stadium and other steps to change a pattern of growing deficits in the city's budget. Even with the temporary notes, the city projects a $206.4 million deficit on this year's budget of $2.1 billion. The city's bond rating has been lowered to junk-bond status by Moody's Investors Service. Standard & Poor's Corp. has warned it is considering a similar rating. The city had asked each of the banks to issue letters of credit for $15 million in temporary loan notes as part of an arrangement in which a foreign bank would issue a letter of credit for as much as $225 million, the Daily News reported. The letters would allow the city to guarantee $285 million worth of notes and sell them at lower interest rates. The remaining $115 million in notes would not be guaranteed and would have to be issued at a higher interest rate. A source told the Daily News the city hoped to secure a letter of credit from Swiss Bank Corp. of Basel, Switzerland. Swiss Bank officials declined to comment. A Japanese bank that had offered a $225 million letter has pulled out, sources told the Daily News. The bank was not identified.

DOC.HEAD: Hemophiliac Boys' Suit Against Drug Companies Fails
DOC.TEXT: Three young hemophiliac brothers, who doctors say were infected with the AIDS virus through contaminated blood products, have lost their legal fight against two drug companies that made such products. A federal judge cleared the companies of any responsibility because Ricky, Robert and Randy Ray couldn't specify who made the products they took for their hemophilia that exposed them to acquired immune deficiency syndrome. U.S. District Judge Elizabeth Kovachevich granted the drug companies' request Friday and dismissed a 1988 case filed on behalf of Ricky, 13, Robert, 12, and Randy 10. Without showing a direct cause of the damages, the family cannot sue for negligence, the judge ruled. The Rays drew national attention in 1987 when they were shunned by the community of Arcadia and barred from school after their health problems became known. Parents Louise and Clifford Ray sued the DeSoto County School Board in federal court and won an order from Ms. Kovachevich that the boys be reinstated. Angry, frightened parents of classmates boycotted the elementary school. A week later the Rays' home was burned down in an unsolved arson. The family has since settled in Sarasota. In April, doctors said Robert has full-blown AIDS. The Rays sued Cutter Laboratories, a Berkeley, Calif., division of Miles Inc., and Armour Pharmaceutical Co. of Blue Bell, Pa., claiming they were negligent in the manufacture and distribution of blood coagulating agents needed by hemophiliacs. The suit alleged the companies failed to screen out high-risk blood donors, from whose plasma the clotting agents are obtained, failed to test the products for AIDS, and failed to warn users of the risks of contracting AIDS. Lawyers for the companies argued the Rays and their doctors could not specifically identify which clotting agent infected the boys. ``It was something we expected,'' said San Francisco lawyer Duncan Barr, who defended the case for Cutter. He said the boys were heavily treated with clotting agent produced by about five different companies. He said there was no way to tell which company's product caused the infection, if any, or if it may have been caused by whole blood they received. During the litigation, Cutter Laboratories mistakenly gave the Rays' attorneys a memo showing that Cutter's own attorney recommended as early as 1982 that plasma products carry warnings about AIDS. Cutter and Armour didn't begin including the warnings until 1984.

DOC.HEAD: Reservists Remembered As Volunteers Committed To Peace
DOC.TEXT: With songs, prayers and tears, the families and friends of nine Air Force reservists killed in a military plane crash celebrated the airmen's lives on Saturday. ``Life was lost, but not in vain. It was given by volunteers who selflessly served the cause of peace and freedom in an unprecedented United Nations effort,'' Gen. Hansford T. Johnson told about 2,000 people. More than 300 relatives of the men attended the ceremony in a hangar at Kelly Air Force Base. It followed two days of funerals for the officers and enlisted men, who were part of the 433rd Military Airlift Wing at Kelly. The volunteers were among 13 people killed Aug. 28 when a C-5 cargo plane crashed and burned on takeoff at Ramstein Air Base in West Germany. The plane was taking supplies to the Persian Gulf region under Operation Desert Shield. Wreaths decorated the hangar for the service. Patriotic songs recorded by Ray Charles and Elvis Presley resounded through the breezy building, and sunlight beamed in from one open side. Air Force officers began the non-denominational service by placing neatly folded American flags beneath the identification tags of each of the dead reservists. Staff Sgt. Lorenzo Galvan Jr. _ the only surviving 433rd reservist on the ill-fated flight _ placed a single red rose on each flag. Galvan, who has declined to give interviews since the crash, issued a statement Saturday, saying: ``Obviously, I have suffered a great loss. Our flying squadron and wing has suffered an even greater loss. But the greatest loss falls on the families of our departed crew members.'' After the service _ concluded by an F-16 flyover in the ``missing man'' formation _ dozens of family members moved outside to look at and climb around on a C-5, described by the Air Force as the free world's largest aircraft. The 433rd reserve wing operates C-5s and has been taking part in the U.S. military buildup in the Middle East for weeks. When the reservists were killed, their wing had not been called to active duty. The men were volunteers who had arranged time off from their civilian jobs to make the Middle East missions.

DOC.HEAD: Bush, Gorbachev Arrive for Summit Seeking Common Ground Against Iraq
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS grafs 8-9 to UPDATE with Saudi source reporting Soviets prepared to offer maritime transport, withdraw advisers from Iraq; subs graf 10 for transition.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev arrived Saturday for summit talks spawned by the Persian Gulf crisis. Bush said he hoped for common ground against Iraq that would usher in a ``more peaceful, stable and secure'' post-Cold War era. Gorbachev said it was important for the two men to cooperate to protect ``positive trends'' taking place elsewhere in the world. Iraq's Saddam Hussein directed pre-summit advice to the two leaders, telling Bush the prestige of the United States would sink ``if it were to slide into the abyss of war'' and telling Gorbachev that siding with the Americans would increase world doubts about Soviet status as a superpower. Saddam, in a statement read on Iraqi televison by a spokesman, said that as the two men weigh summit decisions, ``the angels will be hovering above you on one side and devils on the other.'' Bush's national security adviser, Brent Scowcroft, suggested later that the prospect of U.S.-Soviet unity on the Persian Gulf was upsetting Saddam. ``We hope it causes him to lose some sleep,'' Scowcroft said after a working dinner with Bush and other top aides. The five-hour summit held out the prospect of an extraordinary joint declaration against Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. Also on the agenda for the hastily arranged meeting were sticky arms control disputes, the future of Europe and other traditional East-West concerns as well as possible aid to the Soviet Union. In Saudi Arabia, a diplomatic source said Gorbachev came to Helsinki prepared to offer the Soviet maritime fleet to the United States to transport equipment to the Middle East and to withdraw the roughly 1,000 Soviet advisers from Iraq. The month-old U.S. military deployment has been handicapped by the lack of sealift for materiel. Here in Helsinki, the usual summit accoutrements were in evidence, from the extremely tight security to the Soviet, American and Finnish flags flying side by side by side. T-shirts showing the faces of Bush and Gorbachev superimposed on Saddam's visage were selling for $20. Bush and Gorbachev, accompanied by their wives, arrived seven hours apart to identical red carpet greetings from Finnish President Mauno Koivisto. The summit will be their third as leaders of their countries. Bush denounced Iraq sharply in his arrival remarks, saying it must be denied the ``fruits of aggression.'' Gorbachev spoke in more restrained terms of the need to ensure that positive trends in the world are not ``thwarted by any development.'' He did not mention Iraq or Saddam by name. Both Bush and Gorbachev made it clear they were hoping to use the summit to continue the improvement in relations between their two countries. ``If you want to think of a complicated situation, shift the clock back several years and think about how difficult it would be to work this equation now, get the international support that has been gotten, but try to do it without the Soviet Union being a part of it,'' Bush said. ``Clearly I hope that we'll come out of this meeting tomorrow not with every difference ironed out but with a common purpose so that ... the United States and the Soviet Union will be seen by others around the world to be in accord in our determination to stop this ugly aggression,'' he added. He called Gorbachev ``not some adversary,'' but the leader of a country ``with whom I think we're going to have increasingly productive relations.'' ``If the nations of the world, acting together, continue, as they have been, to isolate Iraq and deny Saddam the fruits of aggression, we will set in place the cornerstone of an international order, more peaceful, stable and secure than any that we have known.'' He added: ``Much is at stake and there is much the world stands to gain if we succeed. Gorbachev said it was important for the two men to meet personally to ``discuss the acute crisis in the Persian Gulf and a number of other issues'' and to cooperate. The White House took pains to minimize the chances for an arms control breakthrough at the summit, even though talks are moving slowly to reduce nuclear stockpiles as well as to cut conventional forces in Europe. ``This is not a negotiating session,'' said one official. Helsinki is no stranger to important international meetings. Finlandia Hall, where Bush and Gorbachev will hold a news conference after their talks, was the site for the signing in 1975 of an international accord on human rights. Secretary of State James A. Baker III arrived shortly before Gorbachev after a trip to the Middle East to drum up increased support for the effort to isolate Iraq. Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak pledged more troops to defend Saudi Arabia and said the summit participants should stand firm on sanctions ordered by the U.N. Security Council against Iraq. ``I hope that Gorbachev and Bush have one line for dealing with this problem,'' he said. ``This would be a hell of problem in this area if there are differences.'' Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze arrived with Gorbachev, one day after declaring he was ``ready if necessary'' to go to Iraq to seek a peaceful resolution of the gulf crisis. Bush plunged into a schedule of appearances lasting through the morning and early afternoon despite his overnight flight from Washington. He stopped his limousine to shake hands briefly with the crowds along his route between stops. Mel Hughes told reporters he was the mayor of Rancho Palos Verdes, Calif., and that it was terrific to shake the president's hand, even if ``we had to come all the way to Finland to do it.'' Gorbachev had barely arrived when he waded into a crowd along the street. Before arriving, Bush told reporters he would be interested in pursuing a possible deal with Gorbachev in which the United States would give the Soviets oil-producing technology, perhaps involving pipelines. In exchange, the Soviet Union would make some of its vast oil reserves available to the West to make up for supplies lost from the Persian Gulf. Bush said he did not plan to ask Gorbachev to send ground forces to supplement the U.S.-led deployment in Saudi Arabia. The Soviets have been urging a diplomatic solution to the Persian Gulf crisis, but Foreign Ministry spokesman Gennady Gerasimov said earlier that the Soviet Union would be willing to send military forces to the Middle East under a military staff committee that included officers from the five permanent members of the U.N. Security Council. Bush also said he wanted ``very much'' to visit U.S. troops in Saudi Arabia, but planned to wait until ``all our forces are there and things calm down.'' He said he hoped the American military deployment in the Persian Gulf ``will keep Saddam Hussein from doing anything reckless.''

DOC.HEAD: Animal Activists Protest Plan to Swap Dolphin With The Navy
DOC.TEXT: Animal rights activists picketed New England Aquarium on Saturday over its proposal to send an antisocial dolphin to a top-secret Navy research center, but the aquarium director said no decision has been made. Rainbow, an 11-year-old, 8-foot-2, 450-pound male, blue-gray bottlenose dolphin would be swapped for a partly deaf female in the Navy's secret underwater mammal program at the Naval Ocean Systems Center in San Diego. ``We are vehemently opposed to any dolphin being given to the Navy under any circumstances,'' said Doreen Close, a spokeswoman for the Boston Marine Mammal Coalition. ``Once they get into the Navy's hands, we have no way of knowing what happens to them.'' John H. Prescott, the aquarium's executive director, said public concern over Rainbow's future has led him to reconsider the trade. About 60 members of the coalition and other activists peacefully picketed the aquarium, protesting the proposed swap of the dolphins. ``We capture them, we use them, we abuse them, then we dump them,'' said Richard O'Barry, a former trainer of the dolphins on the 1960s television series ``Flipper.'' He was not affiliated with the marine mammal coalition. Aquarium officials say Rainbow is too aggressive and has become less compatible with other dolphins at the aquarium as he has matured. The Naval Ocean Systems Center studies and trains 142 marine mammals, 109 of which are dolphins, in underwater surveillance and detecting and marking objects for recovery. Further details on the center's purpose are classified. Prescott said the swap was considered because the Navy could use Rainbow's sonar and hearing for its research, while the partly deaf female from the center would be suitable with those at the aquarium. O'Barry said dolphins in captivity are abused simply by being placed inside steel or concrete tanks. They become ill and stressed, he said. ``You can't take a sonic creature and put it in a steel box. It's different from every other animal in that aquarium,'' he said. ``They are animals of sound.'' In May, a former trainer of the Navy center alleged that the Navy was training bottlenose dolphins with .45-caliber guns mounted on their snouts to kill enemy frogmen. Officials at the center denied those claims. A federal Marine Mammal Commission probe found no major problems with the center's program or dolphin deaths in the past 13 months. That probe was initiated because of reports in 1988 that 13 dolphins in the Navy had died between 1986 and 1988. ``Any dolphin in the world is in more danger from swimming into drift nets than (from) any training program of the Navy,'' said Kathy Krieger, curator of marine mammals at the aquarium. She said NOSC research has helped aquariums in caring for their dolphins and whales.

DOC.HEAD: Federal Government Witholds $2.8 Million in Magnet Funds for Seattle Schools
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. Education Department is withholding $2.8 million from Seattle schools while it reviews the school board's decision to relax racial-balance guidelines, district officials say. Schools Superintendent William Kendrick told board members Friday that the government wants to review the new guidelines before deciding whether to release federal funds for magnet programs designed to encourage desegregation. ``There is a strong possibility that no money will be available to us'' for magnet programs this school year, Kendrick said in a memo. The new guidelines, approved Wednesday on a 4-3 board vote, seek to reduce mandatory busing by allowing more minority and white students to attend the schools of their choice. The plan allows 75 percent of a school's population to come from a single group, including whites. It also allows 100 percent minority student population _ 75 percent Asian and 25 percent black, for example. Previous guidelines called for a maximum of 50 percent from any one minority group, 70 percent total minorities or 65 percent white. Supporters said the new guidelines would help curb white flight from the district. Critics contended the move was a step back that could lead to all-minority schools. They also said the new guidelines could jeopardize federal magnet funds, state construction funds and open the district to lawsuits. Under federal guidelines, a school is considered segregated if minority enrollment is more than 50 percent, though schools can receive money if improvements are made without meeting that standard. Board member Ken Eastlack, who proposed the new guidelines, said he would propose amending the plan to exempt schools that receive federal magnet funds. He said Wednesday he was willing to risk the federal magnet funds to keep district enrollment up. The district loses $3,400 in state funds when a student leaves the district. Magnet programs will be in place when students return to school Monday, but officials are unsure how long the programs can continue without federal funds. Five high schools and 14 elementary schools had magnet programs last year. The Education Department has requested information on how the new racial-balance guidelines will affect integration, said Patty McDonald, district community-relations director. The agency will then determine whether the district still qualifies for magnet funds. McDonald said she was unsure whether the district would eliminate the magnet programs or try to cut other parts of the district budget. The new guidelines will not take effect immediately, but would give 3,000 students on a waiting list a better chance of attending the school of their choice. Last year, the district was allotted $3.2 million in federal magnet funds. Even before Wednesday's vote, the Education Department withheld $417,000 from last year's magnet package for two high schools the agency considered segregated, giving the district until Sept. 15 to find a way to desegregate them. Seattle schools receive a total of $12.8 million in federal funds this year for other programs, including hot lunches, special education and supplementary programs for academically and economically disadvantaged children.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Considers Mistrial in Murder Trial of Lawmaker's Son
DOC.TEXT: The trial of a 20-year-old state legislator's son accused of killing his mother with a hunting arrow was recessed Saturday by a visibly angry judge responding to a defense motion for a mistrial. Defense attorney Henri Conti asked for a mistrial after state Rep. Robert Goetsch testified about a two-foot pipe weapon found at the scene of his wife's death. Conti said District Attorney Kevin Schram had not previously disclosed information about the pipe. ``It was withheld and dropped on us today,'' Conti said. ``It's substantially prejudicial. It's poisoned the well. It's grounds for a mistrial.'' Court rules require the prosecution to disclose evidence and testimony that is expected on the stand so the defense can adequately prepare its case. Goetsch's son, Chad, is charged with first-degree intentional homicide for fatally shooting 51-year-old Carolyn Goetsch in the heart with the arrow on Nov. 8. Chad also is charged with recklessly endangering safety for pointing a second arrow at his father and fighting with him after Mrs. Goetsch was shot. Dodge County Circuit Judge Daniel Klossner said he would consider the motion for a mistrial unless prosecution and defense lawyers can come to an agreement that would allow ``curative'' instructions to the jury. Klossner said he would rule on the mistrial motion Monday after considering the attorneys' proposed jury instructions. Goetsch described the circumstances surrounding his wife's death at the family's home in the town of Oak Grove. Conti made the motion for a mistrial after Goetsch testified his son made the pipe weapon last fall to protect himself after being attacked and robbed. Schram said he learned about the pipe while talking informally to Robert Goetsch on Aug. 22. He said the conversation does not fall under the rules of evidence and did not need to be revealed to the defense. In other testimony, Goetsch said his son threatened Mrs. Goetsch so often last summer and fall that she talked about buying a gun because she was afraid her son would kill her. ``I guess she did take them (the threats) more seriously than I,'' Goetsch said. ``We talked about buying a gun. She started insisting on locking the doors. She said she was afraid of him. She was afraid he was going to kill her.'' The day his wife died, Goetsch said his wife got out of bed early in the morning after both heard a knock on the door. Goetsch said he heard his wife's voice and another voice, but went back to sleep until he was awakened by loud screaming. His wife appeared in the doorway of their bedroom and collapsed, he said. When he went to the body, he said, he saw his son standing in the hallway aiming a loaded hunting bow at him. Goetsch said he lunged over the body and grabbed the arrow pointed at him and broke it. He said he and Chad then fought for several minutes throughout the house while his daughter Shana, then 14, tried to call police. Chad broke away at least once and attacked his sister while she called authorities, Goetsch said. Goetsch said he asked his son, who was supposed to be away at college: ``Why did you kill my wife ... Why are you here?'' He said his son replied: ``I was lonesome.''

DOC.HEAD: National Baptists Revise Social Agenda, But Leadership Issues Remain
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 21st graf, ``This really . . .' to RESTORE dropped first reference to Lipscomb. Subs 23rd graf, ``The leadership . . .' to RESTORE dropped first reference to Thompson.
DOC.TEXT: Thirty years ago, bedlam broke out at the National Baptist convention in Philadelphia, forcing the denomination into a leadership battle that led to the last major split in black Baptist history. The 110th annual meeting of the National Baptist Convention U.S.A. Inc. that wraps up with a worship service Sunday has been a kinder, gentler affair, buit some say similar issues remain. The denomination raised $1 million to reduce the mortgage on its first headquarters, the $10 million World Baptist Center in Nashville, Tenn., and delegates unanimously approved a resolution urging the government to keep U.S. troops out of combat in the Persian Gulf. ``The most significant thing, I think, has been the general spirit of the convention. There has been more fellowship, more spirit, than ever,'' said the Rev. T.J. Jemison, convention president. Others say issues that led to the crisis in 1960, including perceptions of a president unwilling to share power, are rising again. The battle in the 1960 convention was over power. The Rev. Joseph H. Jackson, who ousted Jemison's father, the Rev. D.V. Jemison, from the presidency in 1953, consolidated his own power and ignored tenure requirements. In 1960, civil rights leaders such as the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr. and the Rev. Ralph D. Abernathy wanted the nation's largest black church to become a force for social change. That led to a large group of Baptists to support for president a civil rights candidate, the Rev. Gardner C. Taylor. Rival groups paraded throughout the convention, each side trying to drown out the other. ``It was extremely painful for me,'' recalled the Rev. Arlene H. Churn, who was a teen-ager at the 1960 convention. ``I can remember curtains being torn down from the convention hall, chairs being overturned, altercations.'' After Taylor won a disputed election, the issue of who controlled the convention went to the federal courts, which ruled they did not have jurisdiction in an ecclesiastical dispute. The stage was set for the fateful break at the Kansas City convention in 1961. In that convention, said historian Taylor Branch, masses of preachers supporting either Taylor or Jackson collided like a giant rugby scrum, shoving, slugging and wrestling each other out of the way to take control of the convention. In the melee, the Rev. A.G. Wright of Detroit was killed when he fell off the platform. Jackson won the battle. Many opposition preachers left to form the Progressive National Baptist Convention. Jackson was to rule the National Baptist Convention until 1982 when he was ousted and Jemison took over. The Jemison administration held promise for many of a more aggressive social agenda, and a more collegial power-sharing within the denomination. In 1984, the convention voted to begin limiting the presidency to two five-year terms. Most people agree that Jemison, who led the Baton Rouge, La., boycott of segregated busing in 1953, has been more socially active. In his presidential address this year, Jemison decried what he said was the deterioration of race relations in the nation, charging that former President Reagan gave respectability to racism and referring to conservatives on the Supreme Court as ``strict segregationists.'' Jemison also is credited with being the driving force behind the Baptist center dedicated in 1989 in Nashville. He called the denominational headquarters, the first of its kind for a black church body, ``our Vatican.'' The Rev. W. Franklyn Richardson, convention general secretary, said the center, which is designed to address social issues such as AIDS, homelessness and other denominational programs, is ``a sign of hope to National Baptists.'' But some others say the building reflects a denomination more concerned with elaborate structures than social needs. ``This really saddens me to see $10 million in the glorification of a center versus all the nation crying out for help,'' Delegate Al Lipscomb of Dallas said. While some ministers say Jemison has shown some signs of greater collegiality, including appointing more younger members to positions of prominence than his predecessor, others say there is concern throughout the church about the issue of sharing authority. ``The leadership of the president has been a strong leadership,'' the Rev. Paul Thompson of New Hope Baptist Church in Buffalo, N.Y., said. ``There is concern about trying to share that leadership more.'' The real test is expected in 1994, when Jemison would be obliged by the tenure rules he helped institute to step down from the presidency. Jemison has refused to say whether he would seek the presidency again in 1994. ``That's too far away,'' he said Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Excerpts From Saddam's Message to Bush and Gorbachev
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Following are excerpts translated from Arabic by The Associated Press from Iraqi President Saddam Hussein's message to presidents Bush and Mikhail Gorbachev on the eve of the superpower summit.

``Your meeting will be watched with keen and unusual interest by the whole world, including the peoples of a region which God blessed, by making us a part of the Arab nation. ... ``I will neither plead with you nor dictate what decisions you must adopt because each of you has his own will and freedom of decision. ``But before you make whatever decisions you will, I would like to begin by saying that Iraq's army did not invade either of your countries and has no intention to harm anyone or jeopardize the legitimate interests of anyone. Iraq is a peace-loving nation. We desire peace which is based on justice. Iraq respects the free decision of others. ... ``Before either of you make a decision on Kuwait, you should remember that the Arab nation is one nation, even though it is split now; that this is a fact that cannot be denied by its rulers, leaders, peoples, or sons; that the overwhelming majority of its sons, rulers, and peoples are honored to be part of this great nation; and that they are longing to be one political entity, regardless of the specific characteristics of this or that country. ... ``Kuwait is part of Iraq. The Kuwaiti people are part of the Iraqi people. British colonialism severed it from Iraq for colonial reasons. Iraq did not recognize this measure. ... ``Any attempt to reverse the situation to what it was before Aug. 2, 1990, is an impractical and sterile attempt that will push the region into chaos. Furthermore, the attempts aimed at promoting the instability constitute a premeditated conspiracy against the Arab nation, at the head of which is lofty Iraq. ... ``When you consider these facts in their proper perspective and show humility once you know the rights of mankind, you will realize that the Arabs, by their recollection of the relevant background on the basis of these facts, are more capable than others of resolving all inter-Arab affairs. ``You will also then realize that foreigners, including yourselves, are incapable of offering the proper solution. ``Neither of you is capable of providing a proper settlement of an Arab problem, whose parties are Arabs. We can swear, and God and history are witness to this, that the foreign intervention is complicating matters and will not provide a settlement. ... ``The occupation and invasion of the prophet's birthplace and tomb is an insult directed not only against the 200 million Arabs, but the 1 billion Moslems. ... ``They will join and pool all resources to resist this obscene act and defeat the oppressors.'' ``Every politician knows the United States, and for awhile now, has been manipulating the world and dictating its terms with no one standing up to confront it as the case was before. ``Those concerned with this problem should take advantage of this crucial time in history and employ this critical problem to restore to the Soviet Union its respect as a decisive power ... through adopting a position that is in harmony with all that is just and fair, and rejecting the discriminatory approach the United States is pursuing. ``I pray that the merciful allow you to take decisions that would allow some light into the hearts of the heartless, espcially Bush, in the interest of humanity at large. ... ``President Bush must not bring his country and its status down to a lower level, because we are certain that its position will drop on the scale of appreciation and effectiveness if it falls into the abyss of war, and if its armies and the armies of its allies remain in the land of our sanctuaries, and if it continues this unjustified and cruel blockade which is depriving the people of Iraq of food and medicine and cutting off the supply of milk from children who need it. ... ``The Iraqi people will stand united against injustice and the unjust, and against the invasion and the invaders. The traitors, who encouraged those who have been deluded, will be a small minority. ``When the battle has taken place, then the Iraqi people, whom God has chosen to be in the forefront, will triumph ... and all the invaders will be defeated, their banners torn apart, and deafened by the shouts of `God is great and damned be the invaders.''

DOC.HEAD: Sen. Kennedy's Daughter Marries
DOC.TEXT: Kara Kennedy, the daughter of Sen. Edward M. Kennedy, was married Saturday in this Cape Cod town to Michael Allen, a 33-year-old architect. The 30-year-old bride served as a campaign manager for her father's re-election in 1988. Most recently, she has been a producer for a Boston television station. ``The easiest job was walking Kara down the aisle,'' the senator said through a spokesman. ``The hardest job was giving her away.'' His daughter had 14 bridesmaids, including cousins Robin Lawford, Victoria Lawford Pender and Kerry Kennedy Cuomo. Kara Kennedy and her bridesmaids all wore designer gowns, as did her mother, Joan Bennett Kennedy. For the day of the ceremony, Sen. Kennedy placed nautical flags on all of the Kennedy family sailboats that spelled out ``Kara and Michael.'' Keeping with the Cape Cod theme, the wedding cake featured a replica of the family sailboat, The Victura. A private reception was held at the home of Rose Fitzgerald Kennedy, the bride's grandmother. The couple will live in Washington, D.C., where Allen works.

DOC.HEAD: Equipment Containing Secret Data Retrieved
DOC.NOTE: Eds: RETRANSMITTING to fix cycle designator.
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. Justice Department believes it has recovered all of the computer equipment containing secret data inadvertently sold as surplus from the U.S. attorney's office, a department spokesman said. Michael W. Robinson in Washington declined to elaborate in his statement Friday, but a lawyer in Kentucky said federal agents are trying to determine whether anyone tampered with the information. Robinson would not comment on whether anyone viewed the files or distributed the data. The Justice Department's announcement came a day after businessman Charles Hayes of rural Pulaski County identified customers who bought surplus computer equipment from him believed to contain the secret files. Hayes paid $45 for a broken word processing system from the U.S. attorney's office in Lexington on Aug. 3., but a technician failed to erase the computer's memory, giving Hayes seven years' worth of secret files. The data contained names of FBI informants, federally protected witnesses and details of pending criminal and civil cases, according to court records. Retrieval of the computers is significant. The Justice Department feared the secret files might land in the wrong hands and ruin pending criminal and civil cases handled by the office of U.S. Attorney Louis DeFalaise. To complicate matters, Hayes later sold some of the computer equipment. Hayes owns Challenger Ltd., which buys government surplus equipment for resale to the public. Hayes' attorney, Bill D. Gregory, said government officials told him the equipment would be examined for signs of tampering. Gregory said he is contemplating a countersuit against the government for its handling of the case. He contends a deposition Hayes gave Thursday will show the Pulaski County businessman is cooperating fully with the government. Justice Department lawyers did not file a transcript of Hayes' five-hour secret deposition, the U.S. District Court clerk's office said. Government attorneys had said they would file the transcript but would censor any sensitive details.

DOC.HEAD: Hundreds Toast Ellis Renovation in Black Tie Affair
With AM-Ellis Renovations, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Politicians and celebrities at a black-tie benefit on Ellis Island rubbed elbows Saturday with corporate leaders who helped finance the restoration of the so-called Golden Door that received 12 million U.S. immigrants. And, yes, the descendants of immigrants also dotted the crowd. Denise Benmosche of Suffern, N.Y., waiting for a ferry to take her to the benefit, said she wanted to see what her father had seen when he first came to the United States. ``That's exciting for me to see where he actually first set foot in the United States. It's very emotional,'' she said. Between 1892 and 1924, Ellis Island, which adjoins Liberty Island and the Statue of Liberty, was the Golden Door _ immigrants' main port of entry for New York City. At its peak, the island processed 5,000 immigrants a day. The U.S. government 25 years ago gave the island to the National Parks Service, stipulating that it become a national museum to honor those who entered the United States there. ``It's a great monument,'' said Lee Iacocca, chairman of Chrysler Corp., who spearheaded the restoration drive. ``Half the country can trace its roots to here. The people who came here; they made the country. If you don't honor them, who are you going to honor?'' As Iacocca spoke, numerous bands scattered throughout the island played folk music from a variety of countries. ``I think it's a wonderful thing for us, particularly at time where there are such divisions in the city _ to realize that we all came from somewhere else,'' said Nancy Ticktin. She said she visited Ellis Island before the renovation project and said she ``felt the ghosts of the past. It was a thrill to be at the entry way to the country.'' After the black-tie dinner, a program by Emmy-winning producer Don Mischer was scheduled to show the island's role in the American dream. It featured actor Hume Cronyn, writer Art Buchwald, singer Leslie Uggams, amd Metropolitan Opera tenor Jerry Hadley. The hoopla Saturday night anticipated Sunday's ribbon-cutting ceremony for the Ellis Island Immigration Museum. The museum opens to the public Monday, after a $156 million restoration project that lasted eight years.

DOC.HEAD: Second Planeload of Americans Arrives in Jordan
DOC.NOTE: Eds: To CORRECT number of American evacuees to about 165 sted 171, SUB 11th graf pvs, `A U.S. ....' Pickup 12th graf pvs, `The latest...'
DOC.TEXT: An Iraqi Airways charter flight arrived late Saturday carrying 130 Americans from Kuwait, including a woman who gave birth to twins while fighting raged around her in the conquered nation. ``I could hear the bombs while I was in labor,'' said Claudia Ledesma of San Diego, Calif., who delivered her babies on Aug. 26 while some resistance activity continued against the Iraqis 22 days after they invaded Kuwait. Mrs. Ledesma and her fellow passengers, women and children who had been allowed to leave Kuwait by Iraqi president Saddam Hussein, arrived thirsty, hungry and exhausted. Iraq, meanwhile, said it would no longer fly evacuees to Jordan. The U.S. State Department said evacuation flights will continue to other destinations despite the order, which was to take effect Sunday. The charter flight arrived in Amman just before midnight with 130 people on board, U.S. Embassy sources said. Embassy officials said earlier the plane was carrying about 150 Americans. There was no explanation for the discrepancy in figures. The charter stopped over in Baghdad, where the passengers were issued with exit permits before flying on to Amman, which has been the primary transit point for thousands of evacuees fleeing Iraq and Kuwait. Some of the Americans, including several infants, were examined by physicians while they were crowded in a terminal waiting room at Queen Alia International Airport. One woman in a purple shirt and glasses held a small, white poodle. A teen-age boy was wearing an Oakland Raiders cap and black T-shirt. A U.S. Embassy spokesman said they were to board a Northwest Airlines charter to Frankfurt, West Germany, and then after refueling would continue to a U.S. Air Force Base in Charleston, S.C. About 165 American evacuees who arrived on a similar charter on Friday will join them on the trip home. The latest group of evacuees applauded as an embassy representative gave a brief statement, but they were behind glass windows and reporters could not hear what he said. Other embassy representatives took care of their needs with bottled water, sandwiches and soft drinks. Later, Mrs. Ledesma held one baby in her arms and a friend stood by her holding the other while they talked briefly with reporters, describing the difficulty of choosing to leave their husbands behind for safety outside Kuwait. ``He said that he wanted the children to have an opportunity and that since the U.S. Embassy was giving it to us we wouldn't lose it,'' Mrs. Ledesma said. Saddam banned the men from traveling and is holding some of them at key installations to fend off an attack against Iraq by thousands of U.S.-led forces that assembled in Saudi Arabia after the Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. A woman who identified herself only as Renee said the Kuwaitis were very much opposed to Saddam and that people she knew there were suffering. ``They don't deserve this. They are being attacked. There is looting,'' she said. Naji al-Hadithi, director general of Iraq's Information Ministry, told reporters in Baghdad earlier that Jordanian airport officials had complained they could no longer handle the hundreds of foreigners that have been pouring into Amman for the past week. He said a charter flight on Saturday to the Jordanian capital of Amman would be the last. Al-Hadithi said the two regularly scheduled Iraqi Airways flights daily from Baghdad to Amman would not be affected. He said Iraq would be willing to reroute the charters to other destinations. ``We are ready to take them to any other capital or city, even to the farthest point,'' he said. The director general also said that the short-haul charters to Amman, paid for by the passengers' governments, were not profitable. A spokesman for the Amman airport denied there was a crowding problem. ``Everything is fine, the airport is not crowded,'' said Mashhour El-Kurashi. Jordan's official news agency reported that 14,000 evacuees from Iraq and Kuwait, including Arabs, Asians and Westerners, departed from Amman airport aboard 66 charter flights Friday. Those arriving Iraqi Airways charters usually transfer imediately to other planes for the journey to their home countries. Iraq had been allowing up to three charter flights a day from Baghdad to Jordan.

DOC.HEAD: Hurricane Isidore Loses Steam
DOC.TEXT: Hurricane Isidore lost strength and became a tropical storm Saturday as it moved northwest at 14 mph over open water. The storm's maximum sustained winds were 65 mph and it was about 1,050 miles northwest of the Cape Verde Islands, the National Hurricane Center reported. The storm was located near latitude 28.4 north and longitude 39.9 west at 4:45 p.m. The weather service predicted that the storm would continue to weaken and the same course was expected for the next 24 hours. Isidore reached hurricane strength late Thursday, only a day after it had formed into the ninth named storm of the 1990 Atlantic hurricane season. A hurricane has sustained winds of at least 74 mph, while tropical storms have a threshold of 39 mph.

DOC.HEAD: One Inmate Killed, Three Injured in Charlotte Prison Fights
DOC.TEXT: One inmate was stabbed to death Saturday and three others injured in a series of fights at the Charlotte Correctional Institution, prison officials said. Guards quickly broke up the fights that began in the yard at the high-security prison, and no officers were injured, said state corrections spokesman Bob Macmaster. ``One inmate died, stabbed to death in an altercation with at least one other inmate,'' the spokesman said. ``They had several other individual fights involving inmates at about that time or right after, and the guards moved in immediately.'' Three other inmates were treated for injuries they suffered in the disturbance, he said. The prison, located on the Gulf Coast 40 miles south of the Tampa Bay area, has been locked down, and all weekend visits canceled, he added. Macmaster said investigators were trying to determine what touched off the incident.

DOC.HEAD: Exiled Opponent of Saddam Dies
DOC.TEXT: Salim Fakhri, a prominent exiled opponent of Iraqi President Saddam Hussein, has died. He was 69. Fakhri died after collapsing at the Grosvenor House Hotel on Thursday. Scotland Yard police headquarters said Saturday he died of natural causes. ``There is no suspicion of any crime and there is no inquiry,'' it said. Newspapers reported that Fakhri was a potential target of the Saddam regime, which invaded Kuwait Aug. 2 and since has been squeezed by an international economic embargo. The Sunday Telegraph newspaper said its reporter Nicholas Farrell was interviewing Fakhri when he collapsed. Farrell said Fakhri had spoken with him before going to a meeting of Iraqi opposition groups and then returned for further conversation minutes before he collapsed. He described Fakhri as a retired Iraqi army colonel who became a liberal democrat and secretary of the Democratic Rescue Movement, which was aimed at establishing a Western-style democracy in Iraq. Farrell said Fakhri had been instrumental in engineering a coalition of secularist groups such as his and the two main Iraqi Shiite fundamentalist groups. He quoted Fakhri as having said, ``The Iraqi opposition is powerful. With time we can topple him. It's probably within months rather than years.''

DOC.HEAD: Shortages of Bread Spreading in Soviet Union
DOC.TEXT: Bread shortages have spread from Moscow to other cities, including Leningrad, and soldiers have been mobilized to help bakers in the capital, Soviet media reported Saturday. ``There is a terrible shortage of flour and yeast,'' the head of Leningrad's central baking plants told Pravda, the Communist Party newspaper. ``Suppliers are letting us down. And they in turn, as far as I understand, don't have enough grain. We've had to tap even our normally inviolable reserves,'' said the bakery chief, identified only as V. Ivanov. Long lines for bread appeared in Moscow during the past week for the first time since the early 1960s. Soviet officials blamed hoarding, antiquated equipment and a sudden rise in demand as residents returned from their traditional August vacations. The shortage initially was reported only in the Moscow region, where the military newspaper Red Star reported that hundreds of soldiers were ordered to temporary duty as bakery workers and delivery men. On Saturday, Pravda said long lines for bread also had appeared in Leningrad and Tula, about 125 miles south of Moscow. The workers' newspaper Trud also reported a bread shortage in Archangel, a White Sea port 620 miles northeast of the capital. A bakery official in Tula blamed reports from Moscow, which he said had touched off a wave of panic buying. The bread shortage comes at the end of a long summer of other shortages that have tried the patience of Soviet consumers, including a lack of cigarettes, medicine, gasoline and paper. There have been street protests in Moscow, Leningrad and other cities, and a riot in the Siberian city of Chelyabinsk. A leader of the traditionalist faction with the Communist Party, Ivan Polozkov, said Tuesday that the lack of goods was causing people to question President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's economic reform program. The bread shortage is occurring in the midst of a record Soviet grain harvest, estimated by the U.S. Department of Agriculture at about 215 million tons. The problem, analysts say, is that a shortage of fuel and machinery is preventing the crop from being harvested quickly and transported efficiently to market. According to Soviet press reports, a quarter of the country's combine harvesters are idle for lack of spare parts. Deliveries of other vehicles and supplies are behind schedule. As a result, grain had been harvested from only 28 million acres by midsummer, down from 40 million acres at the same time last year.

DOC.HEAD: One Mohawk, Two Soldiers Injured in Scuffle at Oka Reserve
DOC.TEXT: A Mohawk warrior and two soldiers were injured Saturday in a scuffle on the Kahnesatake settlement west of Montreal where Canadian troops were locked in a standoff with a group of armed Indians. Mohawk spokesmen said a 51-year-old Mohawk was awakened in his sleep and ``severely beaten'' by soldiers. The army said the Mohawk drew a knife and attacked a soldier. The soldier was on a reconnaissance patrol to check out defensive positions put up by the Indians, the army said in a statement. Troops have surrounded the Indians within a small wooded area and have put up a barbed wire fence. The soldier told the Mohawk that he had no aggressive intentions, but the Indian attacked him, the army said. The patrol of four soldiers subdued the Indian, who suffered a gash near an eye that required stitches. One soldier was slashed on the face and another stabbed four times in the abdomen, but their injuries were not considered serious, the army said. A doctor who examined Mohawk, identified only by his warrior code name of Spudwrench, said he had suffered ``multiple lacerations and a possible depressed skull fracture.'' After lengthy negotiations, the Mohawk was taken to a Montreal hospital by ambulance under an army escort in the early evening, more than 12 hours after the clash. Joan Lamontagne, a spokesman for Montreal General Hospital, said the Mohawk was undergoing medical tests and that she did not know the extent of his injuries. The incident raised tensions among the Mohawks, who were also upset by a decision by the Canadian Broadcasting Corp. to pull its camera crews out of the Indian encampment. About 20 Mohawk men and 30 women and children are holed up in a detoxification center in the wooded area in the Kahnesatake settlement, 18 miles west of Montreal. They are surrounded by about 400 soldiers. They retreated to the center after the army moved in last weekend to dismantle barricades set up by the Indians. Also Saturday, the Iroquois Confederacy held a news conference to present a proposal to end the conflict, which began July 11 when Quebec provincial police stormed a Mohawk barricade erected to protest a decision by the town of Oka to expand a municipal golf course onto land claimed by the Indians. The Iroquois proposal, similar to one rejected earlier by federal negotiators, calls for ending the standoff by imposing Indian control over the area occupied by the troops _ with Indian peacekeeping officers investigating anyone suspected of committing crimes. Natives say they fear reprisals from the Quebec police for the death of one of their officers in the botched raid in July. Federal Indian Affairs Minister Tom Siddon quickly dismissed the proposal as unacceptable ``because it would cede Canadian sovereignty to the Mohawk people.'' Quebec Premier Robert Bourassa broke off talks late last month with the Mohawks and ordered the army in to remove barricades set up by the Indians. The dispute over the golf course expansion was resolved when the federal government purchased the land and said it would give it to the Indians. But the Mohawks have raised a wider range of grievances, including demands for sovereignty.

DOC.HEAD: Dumped Lieutenant Governor Nixes Party Tribute
DOC.TEXT: Lt. Gov. Martha Griffiths, dumped by the governor from his re-election ticket, on Saturday nixed plans to hold a tribute for her at the Democratic state convention. The 78-year-old Griffiths said she didn't want the party tribute that had been scheduled for Sunday, ``because I hate to hear a bunch of hypocrites up talking.'' Gov. James Blanchard, 48, announced in August his plans to drop Griffiths, who served as his lieutenant governor for two terms, saying he felt she was no longer ready to step in at any moment and take over as governor. Griffiths said she didn't want a tribute because ``I already have been extended the greatest tribute by the people of Michigan. It is their support, encouragement and love that have made my long career in public office possible. To the people, I owe a deep debt of gratitude.'' Griffiths had said earlier she wouldn't be at the convention, but she played hostess at a breakfast for legislative candidates Saturday and spoke at a Women's Democratic Caucus luncheon. Olivia Maynard, Blanchard's pick to replace Griffiths, must be approved by delegates Sunday. Maynard, 54, previously served as state party chief and has been director of the state's Office of Services to the Aging since March 1983. In an interview taped Friday with CBS News' ``Face to Face With Connie Chung'' _ scheduled for broadcast Monday night _ Griffiths was asked if she thought her replacement on the ticket was qualified. She replied that Maynard had never been an elected official. But on Saturday, Griffiths, a former congresswoman and a longtime campaigner for women's rights, said she didn't mean Maynard was unqualified. ``What I said, I think, is that Libby doesn't have parliamentary experience,'' Griffiths said Saturday. Griffiths said the lieutenant governor's main duty is to bring votes to the ticket and Maynard would accomplish that. ``I'm sure she will do a wonderful job,'' Griffiths said. Maynard, known as Libby, has been head of the state Office of Services to the Aging since 1983. She is to be nominated Sunday.

DOC.HEAD: Liberal Groups Still Holding Fire on Souter, But They're Wary
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Subs last graf to add name of 14th senator: Arlen Specter of Pennsylvania
DOC.TEXT: Supreme Court nominee David H. Souter has yet to face strong opposition as he goes into Senate confirmation hearings this week, but some groups still have doubts about his positions on abortion and other contentious issues. Souter's hearings begin Thursday, and some Senate Judiciary Committee members say they will press the New Hampshire judge for his views on the vexing social issues he'd face on the nation's highest court. But Souter may prove a reluctant witness, disappointing those senators and angering liberal groups worried about his future votes on such issues as abortion, affirmative action and church-state relations. Souter, because of his relative anonymity, did not face the same immediate and fierce liberal opposition that confronted Robert H. Bork before his high court nomination was rejected by the Senate in 1987. But many of the groups that helped defeat Bork say the onus is on Souter to dispel their doubts. Nan Aron of the Alliance for Justice said Souter's record ``points to rejection. It is incumbent on him to reassure us that he would respect individual rights. If we are not satisfied with his answers, we will ask the U.S. Senate to reject'' his nomination. The liberal National Organization for Women and the National Lawyers Guild already have announced their opposition. Other liberal groups, such as People for the American Way, the National Abortion Rights Action League and the Leadership Conference on Civil Rights, have refrained from opposing Souter's nomination outright. Ralph Neas of the Leadership Conference said ``There is nothing, or little, in Judge Souter's record to demonstrate a commitment to civil rights or social justice.'' The consensus so far: There is not enough to derail his nomination. Even some Souter opponents concede that the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait, which has focused public attention elsewhere, benefits Souter's chance of being confirmed as the Supreme Court's 105th justice. Some conservative groups, such as Coalitions for America and Concerned Women for America, are backing Souter's nomination. The groups supporting Souter say he should not be asked about his personal views on social issues and past Supreme Court rulings. That would preclude, for example, asking Souter his opinion of the 1973 decision in Roe vs. Wade that legalized abortion. The groups opposing Souter or leaning that way say such questions, or some very similar, are precisely what the Senate must ask to determine Souter's fitness for the high court. Liberal groups point to a brief filed by New Hampshire when Souter was attorney general in voicing fears that he is anti-abortion. They also point to a speech he gave in the late 1970s to question his commitment to affirmative action. As attorney general, Souter once defended a since-invalidated New Hampshire law that provided for the flying of flags at half staff at state office buildings on Good Friday. The liberals say that action indicates Souter's insensitivity to the constitutionally required separation of church and state. Liberal groups also have found about a dozen opinions Souter wrote while he was a New Hampshire Supreme Court justice. They say the opinions show a lack of commitment to the rights of minorities and women. The preliminary infighting about the Senate's proper role reflects the stakes. Souter, if confirmed, would replace retired Justice William J. Brennan, the court's leading liberal for three decades, at a time when the court is closely divided on abortion, affirmative action, church-state relations and criminal justice matters. In contrast, the 1986 nomination of conservative Antonin Scalia caused few waves. He was nominated, and won easy confirmation, to replace another conservative, retired Chief Justice Warren E. Burger. Among the Judiciary Committee's 14 members, Souter's most probing interrogators likely will be Democratic Sens. Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts and Howard Metzenbaum of Ohio. They are the committee's two most ardent liberals. But Sen. Charles Grassley, R-Iowa, a conservative, also says he intends to ask Souter to flesh out his views on significant legal issues, including abortion. Grassley is strongly anti-abortion. The committee's other members are Democrats Joseph Biden of Delaware, Patrick Leahy of Vermont, Paul Simon of Illinois, Herb Kohl of Wisconsin, Dennis DeConcini of Arizona and Howell Heflin of Alabama, and Republicans Strom Thurmond of South Carolina, Orrin Hatch of Utah, Alan Simpson of Wyoming, Gordon Humphrey of New Hampshire and Arlen Specter of Pennsylvania.

DOC.HEAD: Carper Wins Nomination for Fifth Term as Delaware's Congressman
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 4 grafs to UPDATE with 96 percent of vote, fresh quotes. Deletes outdated material. Picks up 4th graf pvs, `His supporters ...
DOC.TEXT: Rep. Thomas R. Carper trounced his challenger in Saturday's Democratic primary as he sought a fifth term in Congress. With 96 percent of the vote counted, Carper had 24,978 votes to Daniel Rappa's 2,535. ``I've never won more than 68 percent of the voters on anything. Winning over 80 percent is hard to believe,'' said Carper, 43, proclaiming victory. Rappa told his supporters, ``You have my heartfelt thanks. You did the best you can do. It just wasn't enough.'' His supporters wanted Carper to defeat Rappa, who was making his first bid for public office, by a landslide to set the stage for a gubernatorial bid in 1992. Rappa is challenging Carper's actions in the savings and loan crisis. Saturday's winner will face Republican businessman Ralph O. Williams, also a political newcomer, in the November elections. The state elections commissioner's office said 126,160 Democrats were registered to vote in the only statewide race in the primary.

Rappa, 66, a millionaire developer and one-time contributor to Carper's campaigns, engaged in name-calling and accused Carper of becoming a millionaire while in Congress. In a direct mail leaflet concerning the savings and loan industry scandal, Rappa said Carper was ``wined and dined'' while taxpayers were being robbed of $500 billion, referring to the estimated cost of the savings and loan bailout. He criticized Carper for accepting about $150,000 in campaign contributions from financial institutions, including about $9,000 from savings and loans. Carper, a member of the House Banking Committee, defended his efforts in the savings and loan bailout. He attempted unsuccessfully to recapitalize the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corp. by tripling savings and loan insurance premiums rather than using taxpayers' money. Carper said the primary challenge resulted from spite. Last year, he led an effort to oust New Castle County Democratic Party Chairman Eugene T. Reed Sr., who has since been indicted on charges of political corruption. Reed backs Rappa. ``When I led the effort to reform the Democratic Party to throw out the old leadership, I knew there would be a price I had to pay for doing so,'' Carper said. ``This primary is payback that I had anticipated.'' Carper said he wanted to win by a large margin because a close victory would send ``the wrong kind of signal and message to those who might like to take our party back to the old days of smoke-filled rooms, closed doors and deals under the table.''

DOC.HEAD: Justice Department, Again: Roe vs. Wade Should be Overturned
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration reiterated in a Supreme Court court brief Friday that the 1973 decision legalizing abortion should be overturned. But it stopped short of asking the justices to do so in pending cases involving New York City family planning clinics. The Justice Department stated its well-known views on the landmark Roe vs. Wade decision in a brief filed to defend Reagan administration regulations that prohibit government-financed family planning clinics from providing abortion counseling. The regulations promulgated by the Department of Health and Human Services in 1988 have been challenged by family planning clinics, Planned Parenthood and other organizations. The brief filed by Solicitor General Kenneth Starr said ``we continue to believe that Roe was wrongly decided and should be overruled.'' The Supreme Court's ``conclusions in Roe that there is a fundamental right to an abortion and that the government has no compelling interest in protecting pre-natal human life throughout pregnancy find no support in the text, structure, or history of the Constitution,'' Starr argued. But the Justice Department stopped short of asking the court to use the two cases before it as the occassion for undoing Roe vs. Wade. Instead, the Justice Department offered a narrow defense of the 1988 regulations. The executive director of the National Abortion Rights Action League seized on the brief as an occasion to emphasize its concern about the nomination of David Souter to the court, which it said should be opposed if Souter does not recognize a right to abortion. ``This is direct evidence that there is reason to fear Judge Souter,'' said Kate Michelman. ``The administration must feel confident they will soon have the votes to overturn Roe.'' The National Right to Life Committee, on the other hand, said it was glad the administration had presented a ``firm, principled defense of unborn babies.'' The clinics are financed under a $200 million a year program under Title 10 of the Public Health Service Act. The law forbids the clinics from performing abortions but earlier regulations had allowed counselors to advise women that terminating a pregnancy was an option. The court is considering two cases from New York City in which the 2nd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals upheld the 1988 regulations on a 2-1 vote. But some other federal appeals courts have ruled the regulations were unconstitutional. The Justice Department disputed the petitioners claim that the regulations violate the constitutional protection of freedom of speech. ``The grant recipients's employees, as a matter of the employment relationship, are obligated to comply with the grant recipient's directions,'' the department said. ``Thus, any limitation on the employees' freedom of expression arises from their voluntary decision to enter a particular employment relationship. Nor do the regulations infringe on the right to abortion that is recognized by Roe vs. Wade,'' said the department. ``While under Roe the government may not prohibit a woman from choosing to have a first trimester abortion, this court has repeatedly held that the government is not obligated to provide the means to exercise any such right,'' the department said.

DOC.HEAD: Attorney General Resigns Over Dismissal of Rape Charges
DOC.TEXT: Attorney General Godfrey de Castro resigned his post following the dismissal of charges against a 15-year-old who confessed to more than a dozen rapes. Gov. Alexander Farrelly accepted de Castro's resignation and named attorney Rosalie Ballantine of the Justice Department as acting attorney general. Officials said local newspaper articles this week detailing the dismissal of charges led to de Castro's resignation on Thursday. De Castro had been the target of a woman's group, a senator and several police officials who said they were ``outraged'' the case against the self-confessed rapist was dropped. De Castro said in a letter to the governor a report that he submitted to the governor on Tuesday contained ``misleading information'' he received from his staff. The report apparently concerned the rape case. ``In accordance with my own personal code of honor I am, therefore, constrained to resign,'' de Castro said. ``I regret that this had to take place, but I cannot rely on representations by my own staff, and I will not hold you responsible for the failures of my department,'' de Castro wrote.

DOC.HEAD: August Brought Record Monthly Homicide Tally in L.A. County
DOC.TEXT: A record 233 murders were committed in Los Angeles County last month, pushing the homicide rate for the first eight months of this year up 20 percent over the same period last year, an official said Friday. The old record of 227 was set in July, said coroner's spokesman Bob Dambacher. He said 104 of the August murders occurred in the city of Los Angeles. Dambacher said 1,628 killings were reported in the county between January and August, 20.1 percent more than the same period last year. Police Cmdr. William Booth said drugs and gang activity fueled much of the violence. ``Fifty-five percent of the homicides are narcotic-related in one way or another,'' Booth said. ``Gang violence is 30 percent of the cases, but the gang problem and narcotics go hand in hand.'' The county's murder rate rose steadily over the past two years, Dambacher said. There were 2,091 unnatural deaths reported in 1989, a 10.5 increase over 1988, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Teen Charged With Kidnapping 53 in School Hostage Situation
DOC.TEXT: A Forsyth County teen-ager who held classmates at gunpoint inside a local school was charged Friday with 53 counts of kidnapping. Authorities also filed nine counts of kidnapping by ransom and two counts of aggravated assault with a deadly weapon against 17-year-old Randy Floyd Addis, said Forsyth Deputy Sheriff Kevin Wallace. Addis, a high school sophomore, was charged as an adult Thursday with kidnapping and weapons violations. The kidnapping charges Friday represented one count for each of the 53 hostages he initially held Thursday, Wallace said. Addis, armed with several guns, released hostages throughout the day until he held only nine, police said. He demanded a school bus and $3,000 before becoming dizzy and surrendering to police. No one was injured during the five-hour ordeal. Addis, who reportedly suffers emotional and health problems, underwent psychiatric testing Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Burma Announces Arrests of Opposition Leaders
DOC.NOTE: Eds: To ADD U.S. comment, INSERT 2 grafs after 5th pvs, `Thursday's arrests...' Pickup 6th pvs, `The government...'
DOC.TEXT: Burma's military government, which ignored May's election landslide for the opposition, announced Friday it had arrested the acting opposition leader and five other key dissidents. Col. Than Tun, deputy chief of military intelligence, said six leaders of the National League for Democracy were arrested Thursday. They included its acting leader, Kyi Maung, and his deputy, Chit Hlaing. Gen. Saw Maung's government put the League's two main leaders, Aung San Suu Kyi and Tin Oo, under house arrest in July 1989. Tin Oo was later sentenced to three years in jail at hard labor. On Thursday, Japanese diplomats reported that Saw Maung told a visiting Japanese legislator last week he was willing to free Ms. Suu Kyi if she accepted foreign exile or gave up politics. Thursday's arrests deprive the League of the leaders who steered it to victory in the May 27 national election, Burma's first free poll in three decades. The League won 392 of 485 contested seats, but the military has ignored its demands to transfer power. In Washington, State Department spokesman Mark Dillen said, ``We strongly deplore continued arrests by the Burmese military regime on political charges.'' He said the United States regarded the arrests as an attempt by the military to stifle legitimate political activities and thwart implementation of the May election results. The government has issued warnings recently against protests to mark the anniversary of the military's seizure of power in September 1988. At that time, troops killed several thousand people in crushing a national movement for democracy. At a news briefing Friday, Saw Maung repeated the warnings. He also ordered Buddhist clergy, who have been at the forefront of recent anti-government dissent, not to meddle in politics. ``(The government) is ruling the country according to martial law. Our duty is to maintain law and order, and any attempt to disrupt these objectives will not be tolerated,'' he said. Western diplomats in Rangoon have reported a heavy troop presence in the capital in recent days. One diplomat, contacted by telephone from Bangkok, gave two possible explanations for the latest arrests. ``One is that they are pre-emptive; the other that they are a deliberate ploy to stir up unrest to create an excuse for an even heavier clampdown,'' he said, speaking on condition of anonymity. Both Kyi Maung and his deputy are members of the League's Central Executive Committee. Both won parliamentary seats in the May election. Than Tun said they were detained under the Official Secrets Act and would be tried soon. He gave no details of the alleged offenses. However, the diplomat said the pretext for the arrests appeared to be that the two had circulated to regional League leaders a confidential letter written by the powerful head of military intelligence, Maj. Gen. Khin Nyunt. The four others arrested Thursday were from Mandalay, Burma's second- largest city. Ohn Kyaing, Thein Tan, Ye Myint Aung and Sein Hla Aung were accused of instigating unrest there on Aug. 8, the anniversary of a 1988 general strike. The U.S. human rights group Asia Watch said in an August report that thousands of political prisoners were believed to be held in Burmese jails and that torture was widespread. On Aug. 8, troops reportedly killed two Buddhist monks and two students who were demonstrating peacefully in Mandalay. Days earlier a soldier reportedly bayonetted a student protester in the face. Kyi Maung, a retired 72-year-old army colonel, was considered a moderate with the potential to mediate between the military and the more radical members of his own party.

DOC.HEAD: 81-Year-Old Slams Door in Would-be Robber's Face
DOC.TEXT: Ray Ball was watching the news with his wife, Twyla, when the would-be robber came to the door. So Ball, an 81-year-old retired timber worker, did the only thing he could do. He slammed the door in the man's face and went for his .38. ``I saw a guy come across the lawn by this window,'' Ball said Thursday morning. ``I didn't wait for him to knock on the door; I don't know why. ``I opened the door and he had the gun like this,'' Ball said, standing like a marksman with his right arm held straight out from his shoulder. ``He was pointing it straight at me and said, `Get 'em up!' The very second he did that, I slammed the door shut,'' Ball said. ``I hollered at my wife to get down and I went in another room and got a .38 Special of my own.'' The incident occurred shortly after 10 p.m. Wednesday. Ball said he shut off the lights and checked each window while his wife called police. When a police officer arrived minutes later, Ball was in the yard with his pistol. ``I think he was a little surprised when I got out there,'' Ball said of the officer. ``He didn't know me from the other guy.'' Police questioned two men and a woman nearby, including a man with a handgun, but the investigation continued.

DOC.HEAD: Unions Agree in Principle to Negotiate Concessions with Post
DOC.TEXT: The unions at the New York Post conditionally agreed Friday to yield $17 million in concessions that the Post says it needs to stay in business through next week. The unions said they believed the Post needs concessions and agreed in principle to negotiate them. They also asked for and got an outside audit of the Post's books and urged the paper not to change its contracts with labor. ``We are going to do everything possible to help the Post stay in business,'' said George McDonald, president of the Allied Printing Trades Council, an umbrella group for unions at the tabloid. ``If we happen to fail, neither side is going to blame the other.'' Post spokesman Howard Rubenstein said changing the contract would not be necessary as long as the newspaper got economic relief. ``We continue to be optimistic that working with our unions will lead to a resolution,'' he said. On Tuesday, Post Publisher Peter S. Kalikow said the paper was running an annual deficit of $25 million to $27 million and that he needed the unions to kick in $17 million in concessions or the paper would close by Sept. 15. If the unions are satisfied with a weekend audit by Peat Marwick Main & Co., negotiations could begin Monday or Tuesday. Any cuts would be effective for the life of the current contracts, which expire March 30. Since Tuesday, the unions have been meeting with Post officials, learning what each group would have to sacrifice. The Newspaper Guild, which represents 337 reporters, editors, sales and clerical workers, was asked to take a 30 percent pay cut and drop about 40 jobs from its jurisdiction, union members said. Guild President Barry Lipton said the pay cut actually amounted to a 46 percent cut: a 30 percent cut, a 2{-hour increase in the work week (equalling an 11 percent cut) and a 5 percent hike in workers' out-of-pocket health costs. At a raucous membership meeting Thursday night, 300 members unanimously rejected the package as ``obscene and degrading,'' Lipton said. Michael Alvino, president of the drivers' union, said his union was asked to take $8 million in cuts or 54 percent of its payroll, the largest hit asked of any union. He said the Post asked for personnel cuts and slashed overtime. After assessing the proposals each union was given, the Allied met Friday with Daniel F. Cremins, Post executive vice president, and Richard T. Nasti, vice president. Lipton said the 40-job jurisdiction cut was dropped. The unions told Cremins and Nasti that they, too, wanted certain concessions in order to negotiate. Aside from Peat Marwick's audit and the contract remaining intact, the unions also want stock in the Post and at least one seat on the board of directors, said Theodore Kheel, an unpaid legal adviser to the unions. ``I think the Post will agree to this. There was no violent reaction'' at Friday's meeting when the items were brought up, Kheel said. Kheel said they wanted the stock and board seat because they would expect The New York Times, which is financially healthy, to seek concessions equal to any the unions give the Post. Kheel said it would, in effect, block the Times from asking for concessions since the Times is unlikely to place any union members on its board.

DOC.NOTE: EDs: Note language in 8th graf
DOC.HEAD: Ousted Lt. Gov. Griffiths Resumes Criticism Of Blanchard
DOC.TEXT: Lt. Gov. Martha Griffiths resumed her criticism of Gov. James Blanchard on Friday by hinting her replacement on the Democratic ticket is unqualified.
