Griffiths said in an interview for ``Face to Face with Connie Chung'' on CBS News that Olivia Maynard, 54, of Flint, had no experience as an elected official. ``I don't know what she knows about government,'' Griffiths said. ``She has never been in the government except for this running the (Office of Services to the Aging).'' The 78-year-old Griffiths also criticized her boss when asked if she thought he was hiding behind a woman's skirts by offering Maynard for a network interview rather than himself. ``Well, he always wants somebody else to take the blame for everything,'' she said. ``But everybody else does, and he's real good at this. At letting somebody else take the blame. He takes the credit. Every politician does that if they can, every politician.'' Griffiths was dumped from the ticket after Blanchard decided she was unable to step in and take over the governor's duties at a moment's notice. She reacted bitterly to the decision at first, then seemed to make up with the governor in a visit to Mackinac Island, Mich., last week where she kissed him and then walked arm and arm with him. She also told him at that meeting that she was not referring to him directly when she said the worst thing about politics is that some ``son of a bitch'' will dump someone after getting what he or she wants. Griffiths is widely credited with helping Blanchard, 48, to his first gubernatorial victory in 1982. Maynard is a former chair of the Michigan Democratic Party and has been director of the state Office of Services to the Aging since 1983.

DOC.HEAD: China Asks Kissinger to Help Improve U.S.-Chinese Relations
DOC.TEXT: China wants a speedy restoration of relations with the United States, China's vice premier told former Secretary of State Henry Kissinger on Friday. Kissinger arrived Friday afternoon on what the Chinese described as a goodwill visit at the invitation of the Foreign Ministry. It is his 16th trip to China since 1971, when he visited secretly and helped open the way for establishment of diplomatic ties. The official Xinhua News Agency said Vice Premier Wu Xueqian told Kissinger at a welcoming banquet that his past visits helped promote relations between their countries. ``We believe this Beijing visit by Dr. Kissinger is bound to achieve positive results,'' Wu added. The Foreign Ministry has refused to answer questions about the visit or say who Kissinger will see. China considers him an old friend and on past visits he has met with top leaders, including Premier Li Peng and Communist Party chief Jiang Zemin. Kissinger also remains influential in Washington, and China apparently hopes he will press for restoration of full U.S.-Chinese contacts. The United States has cut off most high-level exchanges since the June 1989 army killings of pro-democracy protesters and continues to block all but ``humanitarian'' loans by the World Bank. Business, cultural and education exchanges also have not fully returned to their levels before the protests. Washington wants Beijing to improve its human rights record and release thousands of people still jailed for taking part in the pro-democracy protests. Kissinger has argued against isolating China, and he visited Beijing last November.

DOC.HEAD: Media Mixed on Showing Sniper's Suicide
With AM-Pittsburgh Sniper
LaserPhotos PGS3, PGS5
DOC.TEXT: A sniper's rooftop suicide before hundreds of transfixed onlookers was captured by cameras Friday, and local Pittsburgh newscasts did not air the videotape while national CNN Headline News did. Paul Fisher, a Pittsburgh man in his mid- to late 30s, used a rifle and handgun to keep police at bay for 5{ hours before shooting himself in the head and falling from atop a 16-story building. The city's three network-affiliated television stations _ WTAE, WPXI and KDKA _ did not broadcast their footage of the suicide. ``We have a stationwide policy regarding suicides. We don't broadcast them, and that applies to this case,'' said KDKA executive news producer Jocelyn Howe. ``More so, in this case footage lent nothing to the telling of the story.'' ``That's not our style. We don't do things like that here,'' said Tom Loebig, executive producer of news at WPXI. ``I don't feel anyone taking their own life should be shown on television.'' In 1986, Pennsylvania state treasurer R. Budd Dwyer killed himself at a news conference he called to discuss a federal indictment against him. WPXI, which has since changed management, broadcast videotape of Dwyer placing a gun in his mouth and firing. KDKA and WTAE broadcast parts of the news conference but not the suicide. At WTAE, News Director Joe Rovitto told the Pittsburgh Post-Gazette it was against station policy to broadcast suicides. Before Fisher died, Rovitto said: ``We've alerted everybody that if he makes a move that looks like he's going to jump to get the camera off him immediately, even if it's a sloppy pan.'' The station broadcast a freeze-framed image of Fisher's hat in the air during his fall. The three stations, Cable News Network and the CNN Headline News broadcast live reports from the scene throughout the day. Headline News, a division of Atlanta-based Turner Broadcasting System, broadcast videotape of the suicide. ``The reason we did it is that we were covering the story when it first broke and we were continuing to tell the story,'' said Meg Andre, a supervising producer at Headline News. The station aired the suicide once every hour Friday evening and planned to reduce that overnight, she said. CNN received the same footage but ``saw no reason to run it,'' said supervising producer David Bernknopf. ``No one other than the gunman himself was harmed. It didn't make sense to run it.'' Saturday's editions of the Pittsburgh Post-Gazette included a front-page photograph of Fisher tumbling from the apartment building. ``We may get some mail on this,'' said David Guo, staff development editor. The Associated Press transmitted two photographs, one showing Fisher falling and the other showing him holding a rifle as he stood on the building's edge. At The Pittsburgh Press, editors intended to meet late Friday to decide on photo coverage of the suicide in Saturday afternoon's paper.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Sending Tons of Food to Refugee Camps in Jordan
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS 2nd graf and adds 6 grafs on White House announcement of additional refugee aid
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Gulf-Refugees
DOC.TEXT: The United States will dispatch 27,000 metric tons of emergency food supplies _ worth more than $12 million _ to Jordanian camps holding tens of thousands of refugees from Iraq and Kuwait, Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter said Friday. The White House, meanwhile, announced that President Bush had released $10 million from an emergency fund to aid refugees in Jordan and other Middle East countries. Yeutter said his department, in cooperation with the government's Agency for International Development, has started buying 20,000 metric tons of rice, 2,000 tons of vegetable oil, and 5,000 tons of wheat flour. The food is to be shipped from ports on the Gulf of Mexico by Sept. 30, the announcement said. Spokeswoman Kelly Shipp said the rice was valued at $6 million, the oil at $5 million and the wheat flour at less than $1 million. Yeutter said the commodities are being made available through the World Food Program under the U.S. Food for Peace program. Title II of the program provides for emergency and long-term humanitarian food aid. ``This action is being taken for humanitarian reasons to help alleviate the suffering of the large number of people of many nationalities who have fled Iraq and Kuwait following the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait,'' he said. Jordanian officials have estimated that more than 250,000 foreigners have crossed into Jordan since Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. Nearly 100,000 are still stranded at refugee camps. In addition, an estimated 225,000 Egyptians are trying to cross into Jordan from Iraq, Jordanian officials said. On Air Force One carrying President Bush to his summit with Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev, the White House announced Friday night the $10 million released by Bush would be divided $7.5 million for transportation of refugees to their homes and $2.5 million for private relief organizations. The sum brings the total U.S. cash emergency relief aid to $28 million. Richard Haass, a Middle East specialist on the National Security Council staff, said Secretary of State James A. Baker III and Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady were asking allies for commitment of ``spare air assets'' to help move refugees to their homes. ``People are at their breaking point,'' Haas said. ``That's clearly our priority, to get people back home to their countries. ... We don't want to build a permanent refugee population.''

DOC.HEAD: Former Union Boss Pleads Innocent To Murder Charges
DOC.TEXT: A union boss accused of ordering the 1981 deaths of two union activists who opposed Philippine dictator Ferdinand Marcos pleaded innocent Friday to two counts of aggravated first-degree murder. Constantine ``Tony'' Baruso, who earlier was found liable for millions of dollars in damages in a civil lawsuit filed by the victims' families, said nothing but his name during the hearing before King County Superior Court Judge Frank Sullivan. A pretrial hearing before Judge James Bates was set for Sept. 24. Baruso, a prominent member of the Seattle Philippine-American community and a longtime ally of Marcos, who died in exile last year, was arrested Wednesday at his home in Tacoma. If convicted, the 62-year-old Baruso would face either the death penalty or life in prison without possibility of parole. He remained in the King County Jail on $500,000 bail. Baruso is accused of arranging the fatal shootings of Silme Domingo and Gene Viernes in the Alaska Cannery Workers Union offices June 1, 1981. Baruso was the union president when the two were killed. Besides their union work, the men opposed Marcos, who as president imposed martial law. King County Prosecutor Norm Maleng said prosecutors hoped to prove Baruso conspired with Marcos and Dr. Leonilo Malabed, a Marcos friend in San Francisco, to kill the activists. Three men, members of a Filipino gang called Tulisan, were convicted of the murders at a criminal trials in 1981 and 1982. Authorities identified Baruso's handgun as the murder weapon, but said he claimed the gun had been stolen. Maleng said the charges against Baruso arose from information revealed during the trial of a civil lawsuit filed by the victims' families. A U.S. District Court jury last December awarded the families $15.1 million from Marcos' estate and from his widow, Imelda. U.S. District Judge Barbara Rothstein later found Baruso and Malabed liable for an additional $8.4 million. Baruso testified in both the criminal and civil trials, but repeatedly invoked his Fifth Amendment right against self-incrimination.

DOC.HEAD: Georgia Man Was One Shot in Iraq, Mother Says
DOC.TEXT: An American wounded by Iraqi police in Kuwait while trying to evade capture was identified Friday by his mother, who said State Department officials were trying to get U.S. authorities in to see him. The State Department said Thursday that Iraqi authorities informed U.S. officials that an American was wounded at his apartment in Kuwait City. Officials said he is expected to be discharged from a hospital shortly but will remain in Iraqi custody. State Department spokesman Mark Dillen refused to identify the American Thursday, but Mrs. Cullen Hoffman of Columbus told The Associated Press late Friday that her son, Miles Hoffman, was the victim. Mrs. Hoffman, who refused to give her first name, said she didn't know her son's condition. ``The State Department only said that he had been entered into the hospital and they were trying to see him,'' she said. ``He was admitted to the hospital and they finally had been granted the privilege of somebody seeing him.'' Hoffman was a financial analyst and investor for the Kuwaiti government. His brother, Chancellor Hoffman, said in an earlier interview that the family had not heard from Miles Hoffman but that they did not believe he was among the thousands of Americans held hostage by Iraq. On Thursday, Dillen said an account of the shooting was provided to a U.S. consular officer, who interviewed a friend of the victim's. The friend, who was taken into custody by the Iraqis, said the American was wounded in the forearm while trying to escape through an apartment window. He was taken initially to one hospital in Kuwait, then to another. Dillen said Iraqi officials in Baghdad confirmed the injury Thursday but said it was not serious. ``They say that he will be discharged from the hospital within 24 hours, but will remain in their custody,'' he said. ``They promise us consular access at that time.''

A statue of a partially nude woman was removed from a sculpture exhibit in the same city where members of the rap group 2 Live Crew were arrested on obscenity charges. The 42-piece exhibit that opened Thursday at the Art and Culture Center did so without a life-sized statue called Ms. America. The statue's exposed nipples are pierced with hoops held together by a gold chain and the torso is covered with colorful tattoos. After consulting with Mayor Sal Oliveri, center Director Wendy Blazier decided this week to pull the statue from the show, Oliveri said. The mayor said Blazier, a city employee, told him she was concerned the sculpture would offend someone. Oliveri, who has had no qualms about criticizing art and music in Hollywood, said he never implied to Blazier that Ms. America be banned from the exhibit, which features the work of Florida artists.

Hundreds of people looked on as a man shot himself in the head and tumbled from the top of a 16-story building after a standoff with police. ``All he wanted was attention,'' Police Chief Mayer DeRoy said after the gunman committed suicide Friday. ``It ended in tragedy and we're sorry about that.'' Paul Fisher, 30, shot himself after holding police at bay for 5{ hours with a rifle and a handgun from the rooftop of an apartment building near his home in the city's densely populated Oakland section, authorities said. ``This is a suicide note. I just wanted the police to kill me,'' said a message that WTAE-TV reported was found on Fisher's body. ``He said he was going to jump since we wouldn't assassinate him,'' DeRoy said. Fisher, who had a history of mental illness, fired at least 12 shots, one at an unmarked police car and 11 randomly into the air, authorities said. No one was injured by those shots.

A section of a Titan 4 rocket booster burned fiercely when it fell and ignited, killing a man, injuring nine others and sending a toxic mushroom cloud high above the Mojave Desert. The bottom section of the solid-fuel booster fell 100 feet while being hoisted to a desert test stand Friday by a 900-ton crane, igniting upon impact, Air Force Maj. Dick Cole said. The fire forced the evacuation of about 1,200 people from a 65-square-mile test complex called ``The Rock.'' There was no radiation hazard. ``It actually started burning. We call it an ignition rather than an explosion,'' said Lt. Col. Jan Dalby. ``Rocket fuel burns very fast. It's hard to fight a fire with rocket fuel burning. It's best to just let it burn out.''

Two Maryland teen-agers are being sentenced to probation and community service work for the June 7 beating of Rep. Gerry Studds. U.S. Magistrate Patrick Attridge told the two youths Friday that he seriously considered sending them to prison. He opted for probation, saying drunkenness impaired their judgment at the time of the assault. The two had pleaded guilty and Attridge also said their admission of guilt played a part in his decision. James L. Byrne, 19, of Silver Spring, faces one year of probation, 100 hours of community service and will pay $170 in restitution. Thomas E. Carter, 19, also of Silver Spring, will serve three years of probation, provide 100 hours of community service, pay $170 in restitution and enroll in a program for alcohol abusers. Attridge said Carter received a more severe sentence because he had an undisclosed prior record.

The United States needs to solve the Persian Gulf crisis at the negotiating table rather than on the battlefield, the nation's largest black church body has declared. ``We recall that our Christ reminds us that he or she who lives by the sword will perish by the sword,'' said a resolution approved Friday by delegates to the 110th annual meeting of the National Baptist Convention U.S.A. Inc. The 7.8 million-member denomination supported President Bush's decision to send U.S. troops to the Middle East, but said the nation must deal with Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein at an international conference table. ``I just can't see lives being taken, fighting over oil,'' the Rev. T.J. Jemison, convention president, said after the vote. The resolution was unanimously approved without discussion by about 1,500 delegates representing the nation's third largest Protestant denomination.

DOC.NOTE: $adv10
For Release PMs Mon, Sept 10
DOC.HEAD: From Debt: No More Places to Hide
DOC.TEXT: Americans are getting to the point where they will have no other choice but to cut public and private spending and, who knows, maybe even taxes. As the economy slows, the strains and the pains are showing up in the form of bank and savings and loan failures, personal and business bankruptcies, late and often incomplete repayments everywhere, and in government budget deficits. Recognition that spending must be supported by income was a long time coming, because government, business and individuals had myriad ways in which to avoid facing the facts. There were lots of ways to hide. The federal government, for instance, simply tossed certain costly items off the budget, business kidded itself into believing sales would soar and enable it to pay off junk bonds, and individuals discovered easy credit. The latter also discovered the bankruptcy laws and utilized them. Purdue University's credit research center reports that the number of filings for personal bankruptcy in 1989 was 3.5 times the filings of a decade ago. Past-due real estate loans at banks climbed $3.2 billion in the April-June period. Corporate junk bond defaults so far this year total $9.4 billion, or $600 million more than all of last year. State governments are in deep trouble. Even Massachusetts Gov. Michael S. Dukakis, who once suggested his colleagues lacked courage in seeking to avoid spending increases, has been forced to cut. The biggest blow to state budgets is the economic decline, which has cut deeply into revenues. But if it weren't for higher tax rates, the deficits in many states would be higher still. State tax revenues in fiscal 1989 rose nearly $20 billion to $284 billion, a 7.5 percent one-year jump, according to the Tax Foundation. To a great extent, those tax increases had hidden the problems _ until the downturn. And now, with economies receding, outrage against high taxes is growing. The foundation study showed state tax collections from personal income last year rose 10.7 percent; from corporate income, 10.4 percent; and from sales tax, 7.3 percent. Still, the financial problems persist. Cuts are inevitable. Now that individuals, governments and businesses seem to have few additional places in which to hide from reality, several other factors may have turned against them. Interest rates, for example, may remain stuck at fairly high levels because the tenuous Mideast situation could deprive the Federal Reserve of rate-cutting options. That same Mideast problem could create higher energy prices, add to domestic inflation and conceivably add to the Federal budget deficit. Evidence of budgetary strains are everywhere. Credit as a percentage of individual income is near record highs. Debt has replaced equity in thousands of companies. Corporations are forced to cut down on employee benefits. Still, economists who have observed the developing strains do not view the situation as hopeless. A good many of them say the renewed sense of reality is the first step toward putting the financial house in order, and that without more orderly finances any future upturn would be endangered. In that sense, the inability of Americans to find any more financial deceits to hide behind might, in the long run, be good news.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv PMs Mon, Sept 10
$Adv12
For Release Wednesday AMs, Sept. 12, and Thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Beauties, Beasts and ``Biff!'' ``Bam!'' ``Pow!''
DOC.TEXT: Sam Raimi has this thing about monsters. Take ``King Kong.'' So what if the great ape gets fresh with Fay Wray and bumps off several others? As the movie ends in gorilla warfare from the top of the Empire State Building, Raimi's hoping the big guy comes out unharmed. ``There was something fascinating about King Kong on the Empire State Building,'' said the filmmaker, who has a surprise hit with the comic-horror film ``Darkman.'' ``When they began shooting him, I thought, `Don't hurt him, he just wants to be loved, to be understood.' I was fascinated when they were able to terrify me with a character and then make me feel sympathy for him. You had something that you're repulsed by and attracted to at the same time.'' So Raimi asks forgiveness for the title character of ``Darkman,'' a monstrous looking fellow beyond the pale of love and plastic surgery. Liam Neeson stars as Dr. Payton Westlake, an affable young scientist whose face is scarred beyond recognition by a gang of vicious hit men. Initially, all Westlake wants is a reunion with the woman (Frances McDormand) he has asked to marry. But his anger brings out the beast in him, making Darkman dangerous to villians and amusement park vendors alike, turning his life into a publicity campaign that asks, ``Who is Darkman?'' ``This is a story about a man who was handsome and becomes physically and emotionally a hideous man,'' Raimi explained. ``Darkman is just a comic book character, but we did try to show him as a man who wanted to be loved and wanted to be accepted. Because of his growing alienation and frustration, dealing with rejection by the woman who loves him, the fact he continously failed. That's why he becomes a bad character as opposed to just the way he looks.'' Who is Sam Raimi? He's a native of Royal Oak, Mich., who began making films at age 11 and collecting comic books much sooner (he has thousands of them). Outside of The Three Stooges and Jerry Lewis, he didn't watch movies as a kid, so ``Darkman'' is not simply a takeoff on horror films but also a personal statement about beauty and self-esteem. ``All men at times think they're the ugly ones,'' he said. ``Maybe they're rejected because they're so hideous. I'm sure I've been in a role like the Darkman. You consider yourself ugly and are frustrated with your failure and feel low about yourself. ``I understand the loneliness aspect and rejection aspect.'' After graduating from high school, he planned on studying film but was encouraged by his father to major in literature and history instead. He attended Michigan State University, dividing his time among Shakespeare, ancient Greece and the rise and fall of modern movie-making. ``My brother, Ivan, and I created a film society, the Michigan State University Society for Filmmaking,'' he recalled. ``It was a mechanism by which we could show our movies on campus and charge $1.25 per ticket. ``That was the best training I ever had. Kids were vocal and would shout out `This sucks.' They didn't know the filmmaker was running the projector and the star was taking the tickets.'' Two years of college were more than enough for Raimi, who dropped out in 1978 for a life of busing tables and plotting stories. ``The Evil Dead,'' a low-budget horror film, came out in 1982 overseas and 1983 in the United States, and the sequel, ``The Evil Dead II: Dead by Dawn,'' was released in 1986. In between, Raimi made ``Crime Wave,'' which the director dismissed as ``not very good.'' He began writing ``Darkman'' three years ago, submitting a 30-page story to Universal Pictures. The studio liked the idea and suggested to Raimi he get a screenwriter to help flesh out the story. ``We hired Chuck Pfarrer, who wrote the original script for `Navy SEALS,' which I liked very much. I said, `Chuck, here's the story. Would you be interested?' He wrote the first script, then my brother wrote the second, third and fourth.'' Twelves drafts were needed before everyone was satisfied (Raimi and four others share screenplay credits) and the director's friends, filmmakers Joel and Ethan Coen offered advice and jokes. Comparisons to ``Batman'' and ``Dick Tracy'' are inevitable, but Raimi was more interested in the comic strips than the films. Watching a movie doesn't have to be different from reading the funny papers, he figures, that's why he carefully strung the sight gags together, making ``Darkman'' a comic phantom story that pumps a little life into ``Biff!,'' ``Bam!'' and ``Pow!'' ``Comic books approach each frame that mostly clearly depicts the action and is their most dramatic representation of the action. I took a similar appraoch when I directed `Darkman,' even at the cost of losing reality or drama or melodrama,'' he said. ``I wanted to keep the audience jumping, laughing, keep them entertained.''

DOC.HEAD: Opium Warlord Claims To Fight for Oppressed Minority
LaserPhoto planned
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: The writer trekked into a remote valley of the Golden Triangle drug region to meet the man U.S. officials describe as one of the world's main narcotics traffickers.

``They say I have horns and fangs,'' opium warlord Khun Sa declared with a laugh, curling fingers at his temples to illustrate. ``Actually, I am a king without a crown.'' ``They'' are American narcotics officials, who indeed describe Khun Sa in devilish terms like ``The Prince of Darkness.'' They say he is one of the world's main drug traffickers, exporting death from opium poppy fields and jungle laboratories that refine the sticky extract into heroin. His ``kingdom'' is a large slice of the Golden Triangle, the tri-border area of Burma, Laos and Thailand where Khun Sa has been an often dominant and ruthless figure for three decades. The 56-year-old survivor of battles, imprisonment and double-crossing deals boasts that he controls 80 percent of the drugs in Burma's Shan State. Khun Sa also claims his ultimate aim is to eradicate narcotics, which flow by the ton to what he describes as ``the drug-crazed West.'' American officials, citing evidence of his involvement in large-scale heroin shipments to the United States, indicted Khun Sa in March and threatened to ``go after him if he can be located.'' Going after Khun Sa would appear difficult, but his location is no more secret than was that of Gen. Manuel Noriega, the Panamanian strongman and alleged drug trafficker ousted and captured by U.S. military forces. Khun Sa's headquarters is in a long, idyllic valley about nine miles inside Burma, astride a road leading from the Thai frontier. The few reporters invited to visit receive a friendly reception after a grueling 11-hour mule ride. Ho Mong is neither the stereotype of a smuggler's lair nor a plush hideaway like those of Latin American cocaine lords. It includes an orderly village of several thousand people, schools, an 87-bed hospital, a large Buddhist temple and Tiger Camp, where Khun Sa's Muang Tai Army is trained. ``The world sees me in a different way,'' he said in an interview. Khun Sa wants the world to view him as a rebel general fighting the Burmese government to liberate the Shan, one of many ethnic minority groups suffering under an autocratic regime. With a motley group of Shan and Chinese, Khun Sa has built a non-military organization they claim has won the loyalties of several million people in Shan state. It includes a constitution modeled on that of the United States and several political organs, the most powerful led by Khun Sa's uncle, Khun Seng. He clearly commands the loyalty of many Shans, in Burma and across the border in Thailand, but has a poor record of fighting the Burmese government, which he described as ``the great enemy.'' In fact, he has been on its side in the past and is shunned today by the Karen, Kachin, Karenni and other rebel ethnic groups. Khun Sa acknowledges taxing opium that moves through his territory, but denies refining it or trafficking in heroin. Western and Thai narcotics sources say his empire includes laboratories along the Thai-Burmese border and inside Laos. The opium warlord argues that, for 17 years, he has proposed that the West buy the opium harvests he gathers and cooperate with him to eradicate the drug problem at its roots. There have been no takers. ``We have the opium; we have the heroin,'' said Seng Joseph, one of Khun Sa's aides. ``We're the only ones who can stop the flow.'' ``The DEA cannot stop it in a hundred years,'' he said of the U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration. Several U.S. officials have visited Khun Sa over the years, and he recently sent a videotape to President George Bush. It urges Bush to accept what Khun Sa presents as a six-year plan to eradicate narcotics and turn the poverty-stricken Golden Triangle into a ``World Garden'' of all-weather roads, tourist hotels, international airport and prosperous peasants who no longer must grow opium for survival. It was midmorning at Tiger Camp. Lingering mists swept the surrounding hills as Khun Sa inspected recruits on the training field. He was dressed neatly in light blue trousers and a striped, white shirt. When asked if he was wealthy, Khun Sa said his expenses were too high, especially for the army. ``Shan state is like a lawless state,'' he said. ``The people who own more guns have the power.'' He claims to have 20,000 men under arms, most of them teen-agers from peasant families who apparently are happy to join up for the monthly pay of 150 baht, the equivalent of $6. U.S. estimates place his armed strength at just under 10,000. Khun Sa was in an expansive, jocular mood, shouldering a recoilless rifle for photographers and giving soldiers tips on firing a 60mm mortar. Beneath the swagger were signs of anxiety. He admitted all was not well in his domain. A day earlier, reinforcements from Tiger Camp had marched out to face the Wa in a months-long conflict over an important smuggling corridor to the Thai frontier. Wa tribesmen once fought the government under the Burma Communist Party's banner, but now are muscling in on Khun Sa's territory with government help. The new arrangement is typical of the Triangle's shifting alliances and bloody rivalries. The Wa are not Khun Sa's only worry. Because of the U.S. indictment, there is pressure on the Thais to cut links indispensable to him. Thailand is Khun Sa's major source of supplies and weapons, and aides say he has built a network of relationships with Thai businessmen, officials and military officers. Khun Sa scoffs at America's ``showcase war'' on drugs, directed by what he describes as incompetent DEA agents, but admits to having tightened security. He travels in a pickup truck mounted with a machine gun, accompanied by six bodyguards carrying battlefield weaponry. ``If the Americans put me into custody, they will have to feed me,'' he said. ``What's the use? The poppy cultivation will just go on and on.'' Analysts generally agree getting rid of Khun Sa would merely leave a temporary vacuum that other warlords would fight to fill. They also agree with his assessment that the opium trade is flourishing. The U.S. government estimates Burma's opium output doubled to 2,600 tons from 1988 to 1989. Western officials say that mountain of narcotics is the core of Khun Sa's organization, not the Shan nationalism he professes.

DOC.HEAD: Bungee Jumping, or This Is How a Yo-yo Feels
LaserPhoto planned
DOC.TEXT: EDITOR'S _ One of the latest crazes for thrill seekers, bungee jumping, has reached Australia. To find out what the fuss is about, an Associated Press reporter took the plunge.

They wait their turns in a special area. Some sit quietly, alone. A few stretch muscles or pace nervously on the patch of artificial grass. Others chat boisterously with friends who came to watch, have jumped already or plan to go later. All steal glances at the oversize rubber bands to which they will entrust their lives. Will they prove thick enough when, suddenly, there is nothing below the feet but shallow water and your body plunges toward it? This is bungee jumping, the sport of pumping adrenalin, pounding heart and an unlikely blend of cold fear and wild exhilaration. Cameras click and whir. Second thoughts skitter across a few faces when two candidates decide, after looking down from a steel cage suspended 140 feet in the air by a crane, that bungee jumping is not a good idea after all. They forfeit their $69 ($55 U.S.). Black clouds roll in. A rainstorm suspends operations as gusty winds buffet the cage, making it sway. Nerves tense and minutes drag by. Then the skies begin to clear and, below, the yacht pennants droop. Jumpers are weighed to determine which of several cords will be used to stop the fall 6 to 8 feet above water. Ankles are strapped snugly into heavy fabric-and-Velcro bracelets that are attached to each other, with a loop for the long cord. The other end is hooked to the bottom of the cage. What bravado there was seems to continue until the jumper is put into the cage with two crew members, secured with a seat belt, and the crane begins lifting it. On the way up, the jumper is coached in what to do on the way down, how to overcome fear and get the most from the jump. The spiel also seems designed to give the mind a focus and keep terror away. ``If you look down and start to get scared, look at the horizon,'' one crew member suggests. ``Put your toes on the edge of the cage, then on our signal, jump.'' Sounds simple, but a glance at the water below dries the mouth and churns the stomach. The height looks great enough from the ground, but the concept of 140 feet changes drastically with the new perspective. In parachuting, the ground is so far down as to seem unreal. Here, it's easy to pick out details. The people look like ants; the yachts moored nearby are unfriendly shoals. A crewman unstraps the seat belt and opens the gate. The cage moves in the breeze. Before there's too much time to think, and freeze, there's a count of ``Three . . . two . . . one . . . BUNGEEEEEEEE!!'' Suddenly, there is nothing below but shallow water and the body hurtles downward. The adrenalin that had started the heart pounding now pours in. The queasy stomach seems to be left up there, somewhere, and the weightless sense of free fall sets in just before the cord stretches, stretches . . . and then ends the dive. It contracts again, then relaxes, contracts, like a rubber band, and the jumper gets a feel for manipulating the bounces, like a yo-yo or someone on a reverse trampoline. By the time the cage, and the jumper, are lowered to the ground, the initial fear has been replaced by disappointment that it is over. A crew member grabs dangling hands and leads the body to a soft landing on a padded platform. Some of the spectators applaud as the anklets are removed. The jumper stands, a bit unsteadily, and turns his attention to sorting out the sequence and feelings of the last few moments. Another jumper is strapped into the cage. The roots of bungee are in Pentecost Island, part of the Vanuatu chain in the South Pacific. Every May, when the yams are ready to be harvested, young males go through a manhood ritual by jumping from a homemade tower with vines attached to their ankles. The lowest platform is 30 feet and the highest more than 120. As men gain stature in the village, they move up to higher platforms. Inauguration of the high-tech version is credited to the Dangerous Sports Club of Oxford University in Britain. Members dressed in tuxedos, among them Graham Chapman of Monty Python, made several jumps from bridges about a decade ago, including San Francisco's Golden Gate. In 1987, New Zealander A.J. Hackett made headlines when he and a friend hid on the Eiffel Tower overnight and plunged through the open center from the second level, a height of about 360 feet. Hackett brought bungee jumping back to New Zealand and commercialized it. Thousands of people take the plunge there each year and, in January at Auckland, the Commonwealth Games featured a demonstration. A few of the comparatively rich and famous have given it a try, including boxer Jeff Harding, rugby star Wally Lewis and singer Deborah Harry, who went topless. John Fahey, industrial relations minister of New South Wales state, delayed the Sydney operation for three months because of health concerns, then gave the go-ahead to what he called ``glue-sniffing for yuppies.'' One fatality and a serious injury have been recorded in New Zealand. France, where there were three deaths in 1989, recently introduced regulations.

DOC.HEAD: FALL BOOKS: Fiction Looks Strong but Some Worry About a Recession
With AM-AP Arts: Pantheon Books
DOC.TEXT: New novels by Gabriel Garcia Marquez, John Updike, Ann Rice and Stephen King should make for brisk sales this fall, but publishers and booksellers worry a recession could turn many buyers into browsers. The publishing boom of the past decade may be the problem. Net sales in the United States jumped from $1.4 billion in 1982 to $3.4 billion in 1989 and some worry the industry has become too big for its own good. ``In the past we were recession-proof,'' said David Schwartz, a retailer for 31 years and president of the Harry W. Schwartz Bookshop, which owns six stores in the Milwaukee area. ``But since our last recession in 1982 we've expanded our book publishing beyond that core population. We have more than doubled the buying public and we have a lot of new people whose commitment to books is a lot more fragile.'' ``The horrible truth is if you want to play in the sandbox you might get sand thrown in your eyes,'' said Brigitte Weeks, editor in chief of the Book of the Month Club. ``But the larger the sandbox the better. There can't be any such thing as too big a book industry.'' ``I think I pretty much share the concerns about the economy,'' said Stephen Rubin, president and publisher of Doubleday Co. ``There's a general feeling we're in a recession, but there are certain books I hope will be recession-proof.'' Fiction looks strong this fall, with Alfred A. Knopf leading the way. This is the publishing house's 75th anniversary and Marquez, Updike, Rice and Geoffrey Wolff all have books coming out. New writers Nicholas Shakespeare and Walter Kirn may also attract favorable attention. ``I think we have five or six selections from Knopf on our list,'' Weeks said. ``It's the most I've ever seen in the two years I've been here. We usually have at most two or three by one publishing house. We try to swing around.'' ``The General in His Labyrinth'' is the latest novel by Marquez, the Nobel Prize-winner whose previous works include the best-selling ``Love in the Time of Cholera'' and the classic ``One Hundred Years of Solitude.'' Based on the life of Latin American revolutionary Simon Bolivar, ``The General in His Labyrinth'' is being published this month. Harry ``Rabbit'' Angstrom was last seen cradling his grandchild at the end of ``Rabbit Is Rich,'' Updike's Pulitzer Prize-winning novel published 10 years ago. He was also operating a thriving car dealership and had moved into a new home with his wife, Janice. Now, in ``Rabbit at Rest,'' Rabbit has heart trouble, a second grandchild and a condo in Florida. This is the conclusion to Updike's acclaimed ``Rabbit'' series, which began in 1960 with ``Rabbit, Run'' and was followed a decade later by ``Rabbit Redux.'' The new book is due in October. Rice, author of the popular Vampire chronicles, a trilogy that includes ``Interview With the Vampire,'' ``The Vampire Lestat'' and ``The Queen of the Damned,'' has a new book in November. Called the ``The Witching Hour,'' the book's story of a woman descended from witches who saves a drowning man covers four centuries and runs 800 pages. ``Publishers like to present their best foot forward in the fall,'' explained Barbara Morrow, co-owner of Vermont's Northshire Bookstore. ``I think this year will be strong. I don't think it's unusually strong, but it'll be a good fall. There are a number of strong titles, the John Updike, the Jean Auel, Garcia Marquez.'' Other major books include King's ``Four Past Midnight'' and T. Coraghessan Boyle's ``East Is East,'' both published by Viking; Larry McMurtry's ``Buffalo Girls,'' and fiction by Allende, J.M. Coetzee, Muriel Spark and Nadine Gordimer. ``Plains of Passage,'' the fourth book of Auel's popular earth children series, will be published by Crown in October. ``I think it'll be great,'' said Lou Haggerty, a buyer with the Tattered Cover in Denver, which at 40,000 square feet is one of the country's largest bookstores. ``I think there's something for everyone ... but I didn't see anything that I thought was a blockbuster. Among non-fiction books, Simon & Schuster Inc. will be heavily promoting Ronald Reagan's autobiography, ``An American Life,'' scheduled for a November release. Doubleday will cap the baseball season with Bo Jackson's ``Bo Knows Bo,'' and Simon & Schuster has just issued ``Preston Sturges,'' the autobiography of the late director. Civil War readers will have several books to consider: _ ``The Civil War: An Illustrated History,'' is a companion volume to the nine-part PBS series scheduled for the end of this month. Geoffrey C. Ward, whose biography of Franklin D. Roosevelt won him the 1989 National Book Critics Circle Award, wrote the text along with Ric Burns and Ken Burns. Five historians contributed essays and the book contains more than 500 photographs. _ The Library of America is issuing memoirs by two Civil War generals, Ulysses S. Grant and William Tecumseh Sherman. _ ``Lincoln on Democracy'' is an anthology published by HarperCollins of the president's speeches, writings and conversations. New York Gov. Mario Cuomo contributed an introduction and will help publicize it. Schwartz criticized the non-fiction list as ``very weak'' and said it continues a trend of the past years. ``Serious nonfiction is expensive to do. You need long lead times, and you have to support the author doing research,'' Schwartz said. ``Publishers are looking for a quick return and less expensive commitment to the books. Major publishers ... are simply not willing to put out the kinds of dollars it would take to do these books.'' Bill Shinker, senior vice president and publisher of the adult trade division at HarperCollins, insisted the commitment to non-fiction books was still strong. ``We're willing to make investments and allow writers the time to do books,'' Shinker said. ``This fall we are publishing Ronald Hayman's biography of Marcel Proust, and that took four years. ``We're also doing a complete revision of `Roget's Thesaurus,' an investment the previous management didn't want to do. It will be about four years in the making.'' Bernard Rath, executive director of the American Booksellers Association, dismissed criticism of current books as based on the idea that in ``the good old days everything was better.'' More publishing houses means writers have more places to go, Rath says, and that means more opportunities for solid writing of all kinds. Weeks also defended the quality of the fall list and thinks sales will be strong. She notes the publishing industry survived the 1982 recession and will probably do fine this time. There's always the chance of a slump, she says, but the publishing industry may still be the safest part of the sandbox. ``I've developed the following comfortable scenario,'' Weeks said. ``People come to the conclusion it's cheaper to stay at home with a book. There's a certain reality with books that's not associated with restaurants or movies or the theater. Books have a different niche in the consciousness.''

DOC.HEAD: Bill and Katherine Baker: Bringing the Middle East Crisis Home to America
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf to DELETE incorrect reference to Indian summer.
DOC.TEXT: After Katherine Baker finishes telling the tale of her escape from the Middle East, an awkward silence spreads across the gymnasium bleachers at Central Catholic High. ``Any questions? Come on, no one has any questions?'' Katherine asks, looking out at the teen-age audience wilting in the late summer heat. Katherine sees the kind of wide-open Midwestern faces she, her brother and sister knew as students in this rural city about an hour northwest of Indianapolis. She is trying to reach them with images of Kuwait's modern downtown, its ancient gold souks, the Arabic people's warmth. Telling these students about that foreign, faraway life is all she can do now. Because that life, as if a mirage, is gone. Like her brother, Bill Baker, Katherine lost everything on Aug. 2, when Saddam Hussein's troops crossed from Iraq into Kuwait. She awoke on that day to the sound of artillery. She since has slept fitfully, if at all. For the Bakers, this international crisis is a personal crisis. But more than the financial stability and treasured possessions lost, they are mourning and fighting for what Kuwait was to them. ``She's making (the Middle East) real for the kids,'' said Steve Eddy, a social studies teacher at Central Catholic. ``Some Americans feel the hostages deserved to be victims. The kids have asked what Americans were doing there anyway.'' Katherine, 37, was a retail manager happily settled in a house near the sea. After 3{ years in Kuwait, she finally had made a home for her two wrinkle-faced pups, artwork, antiques and other souvenirs collected over a decade living abroad. Bill, who was on vacation in France when Iraq invaded, was a contractor and consultant in Kuwait. In the Middle East, he'd found a place to start anew after divorcing his wife 11 years ago. He was financially well-off, enjoying a Porsche and 42-foot sailboat. He'd cultivated an international circle of friends and an understanding of Arab culture. ``That country is a little gem,'' said Bill, 40, his ruddy and animated face momentarily wooden. ``But it's gone. That life, my loves, my boat ... my baby mug.'' The Bakers have lost their touchstones. They now live nowhere and own next to nothing: a pair of sneakers, some jeans, a few photos, whatever Katherine stuffed into her hastily packed bag. Suddenly, these independent world travelers have come home to bunk with their middle sister, Sarah, or maybe with their widowed mother in Springfield, Ill. Young Americans have never known war and, studies indicate, would likely have trouble finding Kuwait, which is one fifth the size of Indiana, on a map. And yet, since summer's calm was shattered, they have heard daily reports on Americans held hostage and soldiers deployed in the Middle East. ``Be aware ... know the world and that it is very small today,'' Katherine urges the kids at her alma mater. ``I wouldn't be here if it weren't for my Kuwaiti friends.'' The first student tentatively raises a hand, then more follow with questions. They want to know: Was Kuwait a democracy or a dictatorship? What exactly are American troops over there to protect? Would she live there again? Katherine is grabbing their attention with a real story about how accepting people with a different religion, looks or culture saved her life. She is talking both about the European friends with whom she toughed out the siege's first days and about the natives who helped her to safety after 12 days in hiding. At great risk, a Kuwaiti family she'd never met before and may never see again brought Katherine and her German boyfriend _ disguised in traditional black religious robes _ along in their caravan across the desert. Iraqi troops twice turned the four-jeep convoy back at the city's outskirts before the group navigated a route out under the desert's 120-degree sun. Her Kuwaiti allies never flinched. The group stopped only briefly during their four-hour dash. Once, to pick up a disoriented and dehydrated Arab whose car had broken down hours earlier. The second time to free a jeep stuck in the sand. ``I saw a lot of abandoned cars. A lot. And that's sad,'' Katherine said. ``I know a lot of my friends, their families, have died.'' Katherine crouched in the jeep's rear, wedged between gas cans and her trembling dogs. ``Two weeks before, things were fine, I was living a normal life,'' Katherine said. ``Then all of a sudden you're running through the desert with a dog hugging you.'' When Katherine finally reached the Saudi border, she was not elated. Too many people had been left behind, along with the baby photos, letters and other possessions of a lifetime. ``I feel a great debt to those people,'' said Katherine, running a hand through the hair she cropped short after friends reported Iraqi troops were raping women. ``I owe them my freedom.'' Bill, too, feels an allegiance. His friends, who helped Katherine escape, now are penniless and frozen out of their homeland. ``We've got to build back,'' he said. ``When the doors open, we'll be ready.'' Bill plans to organize a group of contractors, technicians, computer specialists and others to go in and rebuild when Kuwait is freed _ as he is sure, one day, it will be. Katherine plans to work with the Coming Home Committee, a group based in Champaign, Ill., that is working to help hostages and their families. ``Brush it off, get on, keep busy,'' says Sarah, 38, a professor of radiologic technology at Indiana University. Her Indianapolis home is a refuge for Bill and Katherine, whose spirits are bolstered by seeing Uncle Bob, eating corn on the cob, sailing and other hallmarks of childhood summers. But the Bakers can't wipe their slates clean and begin fresh in the United States. They have brought something of Kuwait back with them and are sharing it with whomever is willing to listen. ``A whole country has been robbed and raped,'' Katherine said. ``But crying about it doesn't do anything but bring everyone's morale down.'' Added Bill: ``We just have to pick up the pieces. Start over again.''

DOC.HEAD: Junk Bonds Earn Nickname in August
DOC.TEXT: Bond defaults, recession fears and explosives piling up near some of the world's largest pools of oil helped junk bonds earn their nickname last month. August was one of the worst months on record for the risky bonds, according to indexes compiled by analysts who watch the market. Salomon Brothers Inc.'s High-Yield Market Index had a total negative return of 3.87 percent in August, and Merrill Lynch & Co.'s high-yield index posted a total negative return of 3.83 percent. ``The stars were aligned just right last month,'' said Joseph C. Bencivenga, director of high-yield research at Salomon. High-yield bond issuers were defaulting at an annual rate of 5.8 percent in the first half of the year, the highest in 20 years, according to Moody's Investors Service Inc. Also, many economists believe the economy is headed for a recession or already in one, which could accelerate defaults. Threat of war in the Middle East and higher oil prices has pushed down bond and stock markets since Iraq invaded Kuwait Aug. 2. Investors fear higher inflation that could result from the sharp increase in oil prices. If there's any good news in the junk-bond market's poor performance, it's that the market performed as expected in light of world events, said Martin Fridson, head of high-yield research at Merrill Lynch. ``In a general way, it should mirror the trends in other markets,'' he said. The 30-issue Dow Jones industrial average, for example, fell 10 percent in the month and the broader Standard & Poors 500 Index was off 9 percent in August, its worst month since October 1987. As a result of the slumping junk market, new issues have slowed to a trickle. ``Given the lackluster tone in the market today, the investors have taken a wait-and-see attitude,'' Bencivenga said. Last week, Stone Container Corp., a Chicago-based paper and packaging company, canceled plans to peddle $200 million worth of new junk bonds on a tour around the country. Arnold Brookstone, chief financial officer at Stone Container, said the issue was postponed until the market improves. The derth of investors willing to put their money into the junk market has forced issuers to offer higher yields. For some, the yields are apparently too burdensome to warrant selling the notes. The shortage of new issues has also spilled over into the more secure investment-grade market. Bondweek, a trade publication, last week reported that three frequent debt issuers with strong credit ratings wanted to sell three-year notes at around 9 percent in the last week in August. Investment bankers, however, warned them away from the market, the newsletter said, quoting unidentified syndicate and corporate officials. Without any major developments in the Middle East, the next bit of news that could have a profound impact on the junk-bond market is the Commerce Deparment's release this Friday of retail sales figures. ``It should be flat. If it comes in above or below that, (the price of) high-yields could jump up dramatically or see further deterioration,'' Bencivenga said.

DOC.HEAD: Airline Stocks: High-Fliers No More
DOC.TEXT: What a difference a year makes for investors in airline stocks. As summer 1989 drew to a close, shares of leading airline companies were soaring along at record highs, and the industry was brimming with takeover plans and rumors. Today, many of these same stocks are virtually grounded, beset by recession worries and the surge in oil prices. Over the 12 months through the end of August, the Dow Jones index of airline stocks suffered a decline of 54.49 percent, ranking 79th in a field of 82 groups. During that span the air carriers barely edged their beleagured cohorts in the homebuilding, hotel and Eastern banking businesses to stay out of last place in the stock-market performance derby. Consider UAL Corp., which traded as high as $294 last year as a group mapped plans for a $300-a-share buyout of the company. Last week, the stock hovered around $92. AMR, parent of American Airlines, has tumbled over roughly the same span from $107 to $45, and USAir from just under $55 to around $17. At Delta Air Lines, the ride was not quite so bumpy, with the stock down ``only'' about 35 percent, from $85 to $55 or so. The airline group has been directly in the line of fire of just about every unsettling development that has hit the stock market over the past year _ from the collapse of the takeover boom to the showdown in the Middle East. The first blow came Oct. 13 of last year, when a group putting together a planned acquisition of UAL disclosed that it was having trouble lining up financing for the bid. That set off a shock to investors' confidence that drove the Dow Jones industrial average down 190 points in what was billed as a ``mini-crash.'' Efforts persist to devise a new buyout plan involving United Airlines employees, management and outside investors. Even before Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2 of this year, airline stocks suffered further damage as oil prices crept upward and talk of a recession spread. Then, when the crisis hit in the Persian Gulf and the oil market skyrocketed, the industry's fortunes took another abrupt drop. ``The same factor that has created a panic in the broad market is working overtime on the transports, and it's easy to see why,'' says Stephen Leeb in his investment advisory letter Indicator Digest. ``Transportation companies are among the nation's largest consumers of oil. So higher oil prices escalate operating costs, reducing margins. And higher airline rates reduce overall passenger travel.'' Paul Nisbet, an analyst who follows the group for Prudential-Bache Securities, put out a ``sell'' recommendation after the Iraqi invasion. ``We expect the jump in jet-fuel prices and slowing traffic due to a sluggish economy to cut earnings for the major airlines dramatically,'' he said in a subsequent report. With all the negatives weighing on the industry, however, some analysts say the time may soon be ripe to look for bargains among these depressed stocks. Given expectations earlier this year of higher oil prices, Leeb said, ``we've been bearish on the transports, but enough is enough. ``As long as America is in business, there will be a need for transportation. In fact, as the world continues to become more integrated economically, the need for transports will increase. ``There's a risk that higher oil prices will further torpedo earnings in the short term. But with the recent selloff, that's already reflected in these stocks' prices.''

DOC.HEAD: Making Ruble Convertible Is Complex Problem
LaserGraphic planned
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 7th graf ``Government economists'' to update with reform proposals
DOC.TEXT: How to make something worth nothing worth something? The Soviet Union is trying to turn its practically worthless ruble into an internationally accepted currency, and the task is putting the world's leading economists to the test. So far, the verdict is that making something of value of the bills that carry the hammer and sickle won't be easy. But it's an essential step on the Soviet road toward the modern economic world. Rubles are worth nothing outside the Soviet Union because the government has refuses to back them with hard currency, gold or silver. Tourists are allowed to take only a few rubles into or out of the country, and even that was prohibited until recently. This has insulated the ruble from the ups and downs of world money markets, but has reduced Moscow to conducting much of its foreign trade as barter _ trading Stolichnaya vodka for Pepsi-Cola, for instance. The government sells its precious natural resources to earn foreign currency. As Soviet economists debate how to establish a market-driven economy, they are increasingly aware of the need for a convertible currency. President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and Boris Yeltsin, president of the Russian republic, have proposed separate plans for quick change to a market economy. Transforming the ruble will be complex. To begin with, a ruble's comparative worth is unclear. The government maintains two official exchange rates that allow foreigners to buy a ruble for either $1.59 or 16 cents, depending on the nature of the transaction. The second rate, available only to tourists, is widely regarded as more accurately reflecting the ruble's real value, said Ed Hewett, an economist at the Brookings Institution in Washington. Making the ruble freely convertible would allow the world market to determine its worth, but that could bring substantial pain to Soviet consumers, said Jeffrey Sachs, a Harvard University economist who has been an architect of Poland's ``shock therapy'' economic reforms. Soviet citizens have an extraordinarily high savings rate because there is little for them to buy and subsidized prices of many staple goods are artificially low. According to Sachs, if the ruble became convertible overnight, people would have a large amount of money to spend on Western goods _ the classic ``money chasing goods'' form of inflation. That could create inflation so severe that the government might fall, said Josef Brada of Arizona State University. Sachs suggested the danger of inflation could be lessened by having the government simultaneously double prices and wages, effectively reducing the potential strength of savings. Raising prices is the least popular element of proposed economic reforms, however, and plans for a gradual change to convertibility have been put forward. Brada led a panel of experts that proposed a five-step plan last year. In the first phase, some hard currency would be made available at auction for state enterprises to buy with rubles. The auction would gradually be broadened to include cooperatives, private enterprise and joint ventures. After that, households would be allowed to own foreign currencies and foreigners would be given the right to exchange their currencies for rubles at a rate determined by the market. In August, the government said some businesses would be allowed to trade rubles for hard currency at a market rate beginning next year, as a step toward making the ruble convertible. Brada said his step-by-step approach would protect consumers from the first volatile days of convertibility and act as a ``whip'' to drive industry. He said Soviet industries that produce the best products, and would have the best chance in world markets, are probably the richest in rubles and in the best position to buy large amounts of hard currency. They could use the hard currency for successful foreign ventures, and inefficient factories without the rubles to buy hard currency would fall aside. ``If convertibility accomplishes anything, it reallocates resources from inefficient to efficient'' industries, Brada said. Proposals with many of the same concepts, but in different sequences, were among the winners of a suggestion contest sponsored by an American philanthropist this year. In those proposals, creation of an efficient, market-oriented economy is seen as a necessary precursor of convertibility. Hewett, one of the contest judges, said the Soviet Union must be able to offer ``a range of products that is broad and deep enough'' to compete on the world market before the ruble becomes fully convertible. Otherwise, he said, rubles would be spent on foreign goods and the Soviet Union would have no way of earning hard currency. To that, Brada added that having a healthy manufacturing base is better support for a currency than gold reserves. ``Gold is readily indentifiable . . . but the value (of a currency) in international terms is the country's ability to export,'' he said. After determining how to make the ruble convertible, the Soviet government would have to consider the extent to which it was prepared to intervene in the exchange market, buying rubles with gold or foreign currencies to support the ruble if its price started to fall. ``My suspicion is that the Soviets would do a lot of intervention,'' Brada said. ``Psychologically, they have a strong preference for stability.'' In the initial stages, convertibility will be just a ``look at what the ruble can do in various activities,'' Brada said. If it can't do much, winners of the convertibility competition won't have to worry. The prize money was in dollars, 42,000 of them.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Sunday Sept 9
$adv 08
$adv 09
For Release Weekend Editions Sept. 8-9
DOC.HEAD: A Sigh of Relief, Economic Disappointment, and New Computers
DOC.TEXT: Is it an economic crisis yet, or still just political? That was the question on business minds as the Persian Gulf standoff dragged through its fifth week. The financial markets, hit hard when Iraq invaded Kuwait Aug. 2, have tried to reach an uneasy peace with the Mideast situation. But oil prices resumed their climb during the past week, causing periodic retreats in the stock market. While panic has largely subsided, the threat of calamity remains. A crisis resolved peacefully would have mostly political consequences. A war might spell economic disaster. Experts likened the market's current conundrum to the strain of past war scares. A headline in Forbes magazine's Sept. 17 edition screamed, ``Remember the Maine!'' _ in reference to the market's performance after saboteurs blew up a U.S. battleship in Havana harbor in February 1898. The market lost about 16 percent of its value within a month of that incident, but then rebounded strongly in a so-called ``sigh-of-relief'' rally. Some would argue the markets have already heaved their sigh this time _ about two weeks ago _ and are getting jittery all over again. That's the other lesson of history, observers pointed out. Even after shaking off political fears, the markets may be hit by a second wave of worries over the longer term economic impact of a crisis.
DOC.HEAD: ECONOMY: What the Signs Are Saying
DOC.TEXT: If the economic crisis theory holds, the markets may be in for even tougher sledding. The signals dispatched from the economic front during the week were mostly discouraging: Unemployment rose from 5.5 percent in July to 5.6 percent last month. Retail store sales, auto sales and manufacturing were all sluggish in August. Among the reports, the manufacturing outlook may have been the most disappointing. The National Association of Purchasing Management said its index of business activity fell to 47.0 percent from 47.4 percent in July. A reading below 50 percent is bad news for the economy. The unemployment report, which came at week's end, added insult to injury. Some observers said the worst part wasn't the increase in the jobless rate _ that was expected. More depressing was the idea that the increase might not be bad enough to prompt an emergency rescue of the economy by the Federal Reserve. In the shadow of rising oil prices and inflation, the job picture didn't appear to warrant a quick move by the Fed to loosen credit. Contributing to the uncertainty, a Bush administration official predicted oil supplies could get tight this fall as a result of the Gulf confrontation. ``The last half of the fourth quarter gives us concern,'' Assistant Energy Secretary John J. Easton Jr. told a congressional committee.
DOC.HEAD: BANKS: The Biggest Are the Sickest
DOC.TEXT: Among the sickest sectors of the economy is banking, reports confirmed. Moody's Investors Service, in a status report on the industry, said troubled loans for real estate and leveraged buyouts have added substantially to the burdens of the nation's biggest banks. Once upon a time, all they had to worry about were bad loans to developing nations. The exposed giants include BankAmerica Corp., Bankers Trust New York Corp., Chase Manhattan Corp., Chemical Banking Corp., Citicorp, Continental Bank Corp., First Chicago Corp., Manufacturers Hanover Corp. and J.P. Morgan & Co. The report said all the money centers except J.P. Morgan and Bankers Trust were undercapitalized. A government report on bank profits confirmed the pessimistic reading. Commercial banks earned $5.3 billion in the second quarter of the year, down 24 percent from the same period in 1989, according to the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. The pinch was worst in the Northeast. Other big players seemed to be just as frustrated. An international credit agency said major Japanese banks faced ratings downgrades as a result of the tumble in the Tokyo stock market. IBCA Ltd. of London predicted life for Japanese banks ``is going to be more difficult from here on.''
DOC.HEAD: COMPANIES: New Computers and a New Nordstrom
DOC.TEXT: Companies made news with assorted unveilings. Fujitsu Ltd. of Japan beat IBM Corp. to the punch in a duel to promote new mainframe computers. Fujitsu announced a new line on Tuesday, followed by International Business Machines Corp. on Wednesday. Nordstrom Inc., the West Coast retailer known for superhuman service, splashed into the Northeast market with a store in a Paramus, N.J., mall. The entrance of such a formidable competitor was no good news to stores struggling to woo ever more reluctant shoppers. But Macy's, a neighbor at the Paramus center, made the best of it, welcoming Nordstrom in a full-page newspaper ad that gave Macy's credit for spurring the rival's move East. J.C. Penney Co., meanwhile, was pulling a line of boys clothes off its shelves in response to hunters' complaints about the not-so-subtle anti-hunting messages affixed to the garments. One set of instructions appearing on shirts advised, ``Absolutely No Hunting of Wild and Free Animals While Wearing This Garment.'' Penney apologized for the misguided promotion. Elsewhere, Chrysler Corp. Chairman Lee Iacocca said he had ordered his managers to excise another billion dollars in costs by the middle of next year. The cuts must come on top of $1.5 billion previously prescribed. The savings and loan saga produced another strange tale with courts removing, then reinstating federal regulators at Franklin Savings Association in Kansas. The first court ruled the government had acted rashly in taking control of the ailing thrift. A quick appeal won the government a temporary reprieve.
DOC.HEAD: SALE OF THE WEEK: Japanese Buy Pebble Beach
DOC.TEXT: Pebble Beach, the ultimate in trophy sports properties, was sold to the Japanese for an undisclosed price estimated at between $800 million and $1 billion. Minoru Isutani, an investor and golf course developer, was the lucky buyer of the West Coast resort property made famous by its legendary golf links. The sale seemed to dispel the notion that the Japanese hunger for American businesses and real estate had been curbed by economic worries. Back East, there was talk of Japanese interest in another sports prize _ the New York Yankees. With George Steinbrenner on suspension and the fabled team in disarray, some minority partners were reported shopping their stakes overseas.
DOC.HEAD: SIGN OF THE TIMES: The Crayon Index Peaks
DOC.TEXT: Surer than any signal in the markets or the economy may be the Crayola crayon index, offered by Robert Prechter, well-known stock watcher. Prechter warned readers of his most recent newsletter that the Crayola announcement of new colors for the '90s was ominous. The introduction of wild strawberry, tangerine and fuchsia was a sign of an immiment ``mood top'' in America that could presage a bear market, the forecaster said.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv Weekend Editions Sept. 8-9
$adv 10
For Release Monday, Sept. 10
DOC.HEAD: OPEC Marks 30th Anniversary - But With Little to Celebrate
DOC.TEXT: In just a few days, OPEC marks its 30th anniversary. But, with one of its founding members occupying another, there is little to celebrate. ``It's a birthday, but not a happy birthday,'' said Peter Bogin, associate director for oil markets at Cambridge Energy Research Associates in Paris. ``They can celebrate their survival _ that's all they can celebrate,'' said Pierre Terzian, editor of the Paris-based newsletter Petrostrategies. The Sept. 14 anniversary of the founding of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries will pass with little fanfare. No ceremony is planned at its headquarters in Vienna. Some countries may issue commemorative stamps, hold news conferences or otherwise mark the day. But, as it enters its fourth decade, OPEC is in crisis. A little more than a month ago, Iraq invaded and occupied its tiny neighbor, Kuwait, in a dispute over oil wealth. The United States launched a massive military buildup in Saudi Arabia, another OPEC member, also in the oil-rich Persian Gulf. An international embargo was slapped on Iraqi and Kuwaiti crude, pulling 4 million barrels of oil a day off the market. With tensions running high, OPEC appears to have given up exerting control over its members. A majority of nations recently agreed to throw out temporarily the cartel's output quotas to allow as much pumping as possible. They intend to make up most of the shortfall of banned Iraqi and Kuwaiti oil. ``What we have done is put OPEC to sleep until the crisis is over,'' said Sheikh Ali Khalifa al-Sabah, the finance minister for Kuwait's government-in-exile and its former oil chief. Terzian argued that by suspending its quota system, the cartel ``has abdicated its role of market leadership'' to Western nations. ``It is no exaggeration that the price of oil in the coming months will be mainly determined by what the Americans want,'' he said. In recent years, the organization had worked hard to adopt an attitude of cooperation, not confrontation, with Western countries that are the key consumers of its product. Demand for OPEC's oil grew, supplies were abundant, and prices were generally good. But with Iraqi President Saddam Hussein's lightning strike against his neighbor, years of hard work vanished. ``OPEC's reputation has been badly tarnished,'' said Bogin. The West's impression is that the cartel's oil is in the ``the hands of very belligerent, unstable countries,'' he said. The outcome of the crisis will determine the cartel's future _ and Iraq's power to dominate the group and push for higher pricing policies. If Saddam's annexation of his neighbor holds, Iraq will gain additional oil reserves and eliminate OPEC's main ``dove'' _ Kuwait _ which had fought for lower prices. Western countries, fearful of Iraq's muscle, might rush to find other fuels to replace oil in running their economies. But Saudi Arabia and others could refuse to accept the annexation of Kuwait, creating a permanent split in OPEC. Iraq and Libya stayed away from the cartel's latest meeting. If, on the other hand, Iraq's power is weakened, Saudi Arabia and others will emerge in a stronger position and likely pursue more moderate pricing policies in the future, analysts said. Despite the critical situation, few are ready to predict the cartel's imminent demise. ``OPEC member countries ... are slaves to oil and therefore they need OPEC,'' said Terzian. He was referring to the heavy dependence of the group's members on crude exports to get badly needed money for their economies, some of which have rung up heavy debts with Western nations. ``It's not the end of OPEC by any means,'' said John Lichtblau, chairman of the Petroleum Industry Research Foundation in New York. ``OPEC has been a fairly important organization in influencing world oil prices. It will continue to play a role in the 1990s,'' he said. With little publicity 30 years ago, five key oil-producing nations _ Saudi Arabia, Venezuela, Iran, Iraq and Kuwait _ banded together in Baghdad, Iraq, and set up a group to fight for higher prices. Qatar, Indonesia and Libya joined soon after. The ranks were filled out by the United Arab Emirates, Algeria, Nigeria, Ecuador and finally Gabon. Altogether, the countries hold about three-quarters of the world's oil reserves and pump about one-third of its oil. In its early years, the cartel attracted little attention _ some say only ridicule _ from the major oil companies, which controlled crude prices then. It wasn't until the 1970s that consumers took notice. An Arab embargo on crude supplies to the United States for helping Israel in the 1973 Arab-Israeli war sent oil _ and gasoline _ prices skyward. Crude prices again surged _ approaching $40 a barrel _ when oil production from Iran fell after the 1979 revolution. The price shock sent the world economy into a tailspin. ``In the 1970s and 1980s, (OPEC) kept prices higher than they would have been (otherwise),'' said Lichtblau. OPEC's main function, he said, has been to regulate its members' production so there is not too much oil on the market for the demand of the United States and other consuming nations. ``OPEC is irrelevant while there is a world oil shortage,'' he said. ``It is designed to keep members from overproducing and driving prices down.'' But its regulating mechanism hasn't always worked. Earlier this year, crude prices plunged mostly because of overproduction by Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates, which persistently ignored their OPEC supply quotas and flooded the market with crude. The fall in prices touched off Saddam's wrath. He complained his country had lost $14 billion in oil revenues over the past year because of low prices. And he threatened to use force against countries ignoring their OPEC quotas. A few weeks later, his troops rolled into Kuwait.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv Monday Sept. 10

DOC.HEAD: 5,000 Workers Occupy Mines Demanding Job Security
DOC.TEXT: About 5,000 workers on Friday occupied underground uranium mines jointly owned by the Soviet Union and East Germany demanding job security, the official news agency ADN reported. The Soviets plan to pull out of the uranium operations located in and near an East German area called Thuringia. Uranium from the mines has in years past been used in the Soviets' nuclear-weapons program, and for atomic energy. ADN said East German workers refused to leave the shafts at five uranium mines on Friday, demanding new jobs be created for them after the operations close. Negotiations between labor and East German officials were under way to try to resolve the dispute.
