DOC.HEAD: No Break in Recession Clouds Over Wall Street
DOC.TEXT: As the debate keeps raging over whether the United States faces a recession or not, many Wall Street investors are resigning themselves to a long wait for a clear-cut answer. Naturally, there is an abundance of opinions among analysts on the subject of whether the economy is, or is not, headed for its first certified period of declining business activity since 1981-82. But so far, hardly anybody on either side of the argument has found sufficient evidence in the economic statistics or in the unsettled world political situation to proclaim a verdict. Many analysts see no reason to expect that stalemate to be broken any time soon, given such imponderables as the eventual outcome of the crisis in the Persian Gulf. And that uncertainty looms as a particular problem for the stock and bond markets. ``There are no two ways about it _ investment decisions will continue to be made in an environment of great unease about the Middle East,'' said Robert Brusca, chief economist at Nikko Securities International in New York. In theory at least, the unsettled stock market would get a big boost if the chances seemed to increase that a recession could be avoided and prospects for corporate profits could somehow brighten. Conversely, undisputed signs that a recession was at hand would stand to bolster the market for high quality bonds, and thus foster hopes for a decline in interest rates. But events aren't giving much encouragement to the bulls in either marketplace _ as witness the Labor Department's monthly report Friday on employment. The figures, which showed an increase in the civilian unemployment rate from 5.5 percent in July to 5.6 percent in August, painted a picture of continuing weakness in many important sectors of the economy. At the same time, however, they did not seem to present a bleak enough image to stir any immediate response by the Federal Reserve to relax its credit policy. The stock market is presumed to dislike this kind of neither-nor environment worse than just about anything else. Indeed, some say, the outlook for stocks might actually start to improve once the existence of a recession were confirmed. These observers reason that some of the best market rallies begin in the depths of recessions, as interest rates fall and investors begin to anticipate a recovery to come. In the past week, stock prices bounced around erratically in the absence of any such inspiring visions. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials closed Friday at 2,619.55, up 5.19 from the week before. The New York Stock Exchange composite index rose 1.45 to 177.51; the NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market slipped .83 to 380.38, and the American Stock Exchange market value index was up .38 at 323.77. Volume on the Big Board averaged 115.74 million shares a day, against 127.88 million the week before. James Stack, publisher of an investment advisory service called InvesTech, says stocks face a volatile environment over the next year fraught with both danger and opportunity. Past experience shows, he adds, that ``it's only after the smoke clears, and final economic statistics are compiled, that it becomes apparent we were already in a recession long before it became `headline material.' ``Not one of the past four recessions was forecast in advance by a poll or group of economists.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv Weekend Editions Sept. 8-9

DOC.HEAD: Asbestos Fund To Get More Money in Financial Restructuring
DOC.TEXT: Manville Corp. has agreed to inject up to $520 million over seven years into an asbestos trust fund to reverse a cash shortfall jeopardizing compensation payments to tens of thousands of victims. The agreement is the first step toward meeting more than 130,000 pending and untolled future claims by people who contracted lung cancer and other respiratory ailments inhaling fibers from Manville-made asbestos. The cash infusion, which would not begin until late 1991 at the earliest, is part of an overhaul ordered by a federal judge after the trust ran out of cash and said it would not meet new claims until well into the 21st century. Asbestos is a mineral that can cause cancer when its fibers are inhaled. Compensating asbestos disease victims and their families is the biggest product liability issue in U.S. history, with cases clogging courts nationwide. Many victims have died before receiving payment. U.S. District Judge Jack B. Weinstein, who ordered the Manville trust restructuring, in August froze all payouts except in emergency health cases. Attorneys involved in the negotiations said they expected some form of a payment freeze to remain until the trust receives the new Manville money. That would delay even longer payments to many victims or their families, some of whom have waited more than a decade for compensation from Denver-based Manville and other asbestos manufacturers. The Manville Personal Injury Settlement Trust was created as part of Manville's 1988 bankruptcy court reorganization. The trust faces a $30 million deficit by March 31, 1991, and officials have blamed the drain on more claims and bigger settlements than expected. Attorneys said negotiations are continuing on a plan expected to result in paying Manville trust claimants based on the severity of illness and financial need rather than the date of filing. A group of judges also is trying to fashion a nationwide solution to 90,000 pending lawsuits involving the trust and dozens of companies that made asbestos. The new payments by Manville will be made as special distributions to all common stockholders. Manville will turn the trust's convertible stock into common stock, giving the trust about 80 percent of the company's 120 million outstanding common shares, compared with about 50 percent today. The trust then would receive 80 percent of a maximum total of $650 million in special distributions to be made over the next seven years, or $520 million. The first $100 million payment would be made on Dec. 1, 1991, or after the final payment plan is approved by Weinstein, whichever is later. Another $100 million would be pumped into the trust one year later, with $40 million infusions in each of the following two years. In the fourth through seventh years, the trust will receive an annual distribution based on Manville's performance, up to a maximum $240 million. But Manville cautioned that all payments after the initial $100 million would depend on the company's ability to secure financing through bonds and other sources in the financial markets. Under the bankruptcy court reorganization, insurance payments and company contributions made the trust initially worth about $3 billion. Manville still is required to make regular cash payments into the trust and pay 20 percent of its profits annually starting in 1992 as part of the original plan. Manville was not required to contribute to the trust overhaul and is legally shielded from further liability for asbestos health claims. But the company's future success also depends on putting the asbestos issue behind it. The company filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in 1982 because it couldn't meet mounting asbestos claims. Manville Chief Executive Tom Stephens said the new agreement ``is a good balance between directing cash to all of our shareholders and reinvestment in our businesses.'' He said the extra payments were not expected to hurt the performance of the company, which makes a variety of building and engineering products, including fiberglass, industrial insulation and paper and wood products. Manville stock rose 75 cents to $6.75 in afternoon trading Friday on the New York Stock Exchange. The trust to date has settled close to 24,000 claims for more than $1 billion, but has paid out only about two-thirds of the amount. Payments have averaged about $43,000 per claim, compared to an initial estimate of $25,000. In addition, judges have been harshly critical that about one-third of payments have gone to pay lawyers' fees. Weinstein last month restricted contingency fees to plaintiffs lawyers to 20 percent of all hardship settlements. Asbestos, which has natural heat resistance and insulation properties, was used widely for decades in shipbuilding and other construction industries. Companies have been held liable on the grounds they failed to warn workers about its potential hazards.

DOC.HEAD: OTS Controversy Puts Kansas Bank in Spotlight
DOC.TEXT: Employees cheered when Ernie Fleischer walked in the front door of Franklin Savings Association, after winning it back from federal regulators in a bitter court battle. Just six hours later, an appeals court forced him out again. Regulators moved back in. And even Thursday's events won't be the end of the roller coaster ride for the once-tiny Franklin, which boomed in the 1980s on a complex investment strategy that the government now contends it mishandled. ``I'm optimistic we'll win,'' Fleischer, the thrift's chairman and the man credited with its growth, said Friday. ``It will just take time.'' Franklin was seized Feb. 16 of this year by regulators with the Office of Thrift Supervision. Attorneys contended the thrift used improper accounting tricks to avoid $119 million in losses from the futures market. They ordered the bank to take the losses immediately, which placed it below required capital requirements and triggered the takeover. The Resolution Trust Corp. took control. Fleischer and other officers filed suit, saying regulators had changed their accounting rules in midstream. After a four-week trial, U.S. District Judge Dale E. Saffels ruled Wednesday that regulators had acted in an arbitrary and capricious manner. Fleischer and fellow managers regained control of Franklin on Thursday morning. But six hours later, the 10th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in Denver granted the government's request for a temporary stay in the order until it can appeal. Regulators re-seized Franklin, and Fleischer walked out of the suburban Kansas City branch office where he was visiting employees. ``He can't go back for now,'' Franklin's attorney, Roger Stanton, said Friday. ``They had a nice day yesterday and got to see some employees, but that's that. It was good for the employees to see Ernie again.'' On Friday, Fleischer, 57, was busy answering calls in the home office he has used since Franklin was seized. Analysts say Franklin, which was founded in 1889 in the small town of Ottawa, Kan., was different than other thrifts in its operations. About 10 years ago it began to move beyond the traditional S&L business of simple home loans and passbook savings accounts and sought out so-called brokered deposits, in which depositors from anywhere in the nation ask brokers to seek out the highest possible interest rates. It then used that money to buy mortgage-backed bonds, and protected itself against resulting swings in interest rates by buying and selling futures contracts. ``Franklin operated in an entirely different way than just about any thrift I know,'' said Henry Peltz, an analyst with Keefe, Bruyette and Woods in New York. ``They were not a lending institution, they were an investing institution. And Ernie Fleischer taught Wall Street a good deal about hedging.'' Franklin's $11.4 billion in assets made it the 21st largest savings and loan in the nation a year ago and the largest in Kansas. More than 90 percent of those assets were in mortgage-backed securities. Fleischer, a Kansas City tax lawyer, had acquired Franklin in 1972 with other investors. Although Franklin kept its headquarters in Ottawa, he and his investment team worked out of an office building in this Kansas City suburb. RTC officials were back in those offices Friday. Fleischer said he had time to do just a cursory examination of the thrift's books Thursday before the government's re-seizure, but it appeared stable. He said RTC agents have sold some assets and the thrift appeared to have lost between $400 and $500 million in deposits. Franklin also lost about 50 of its 350 employees. But Fleischer said he's optimistic the thrift would prosper if he regains control. ``Everyone I talked to yesterday was prepared to go back to work and build on what exists,'' Fleischer said. ``There remains a very highly skilled and highly qualified group of employees.''

DOC.HEAD: Capitalists Ahead at Last Leipzig Fair Under East German Flag
DOC.TEXT: American businessmen at this year's Leipzig Fair see bright times ahead as East Germany converts to capitalism, but Soviet traders found far gloomier prospects. ``Because the Berlin Wall went down, I thought the prospect of selling our wooden homes would be better than before, and we've had quite a lot of success,'' said Orrelle Trent, president of Blueberry Hill Cedar Homes in California. But a few buildings away from where the Business Center USA exhibition was housed, the mood was tense at the Soviet pavilion. The introduction of the powerful West German mark throughout East Germany following the economic merger of the countries July 1 has made it hard for the Soviets to do business at the fair. ``There are far fewer exhibitions because we have to pay for everything in hard currency,'' explained Vladimir Krol, a representative of Elektrointorg, a state-run electronics trading company. The Leipzig Fair is an ancient trade meeting that since World War II has been the showcase for products and technology from the Communist countries of the Soviet bloc. The fair, which traces its origins to 1175, developed in the Middle Ages as a main crossroads for metal trading in central Europe. Its low point was in World War II, when the site was destroyed by Allied bombing and the fair was closed. But after the war, the fair was revived into a major trading thoroughfare. The democratic revolution that reversed communism in Eastern Europe and the unification of the two German states this year tempted many Western businesses to try their hand at the event. ``It's part of our all-around strategy to move into Eastern Europe. We came to Leipzig to demonstrate that we're serious,'' said Christian Foster, a senior representative of Bell Atlantic Corp., a regional telephone company. Things are different for the Soviets, whose pavilion seemed strikingly out of place amid showy outdoor exhibitions from Mercedes-Benz and Shell Oil Co. A huge bust of Lenin stands sternly outside the massive concrete showroom, which is topped with a red star. Krol said the biggest interest in his exhibit was for model Soviet cars and bronze miniatures of pedigreed dogs that his company also markets. Plastic lamps, oversized televisions and primitive video games elicited little enthusiasm among fair-goers. East German products were very few. Those exhibited drew giggles. ``Can you imagine driving that?'' muttered one West German man as he looked at a pickup truck version of the Trabant, the car East Germans are trading in for West German cars. The Business Center USA attracted 19 American companies, while dozens more were scattered throughout the massive complex on the edge of Leipzig. Among the companies represented were the financial concern J.P. Morgan & Co. Inc. and consumer and industrial products giant General Electric Co. Thousands of exhibitors were on hand from 55 countries. Attendance figures weren't available. Roger Schulz, representing the Duracell battery company, an American firm with German headquarters in Cologne, said his company has been coming to the fair since the 1960s. ``Because we were here before, it has been easier for us to penetrate the East German and Soviet-bloc markets since all the changes last year,'' Schulz said. Since last fall, his company has opened 800 sales points in East Germany and is still expanding, he said. Bell Atlantic also has business in mind. It has signed a marketing agreement with Robotron, East Germany's largest computer manufacturer, and wants to set up a joint venture with part of the former state monopoly, which is being broken up. ``We felt working with Robotron would give us access to the whole East European Market, rather than starting from scratch ourselves,'' Foster said. The company plans to work out a training program with Robotron employees to help regenerate the economy of East Germany, he said.
